 [2] "                                        Summary\n        This report reviews the performance of the California ISO’s real-time energy and\nancillary services markets over the past 18 months, with particular emphasis on the\nrelative performance of these markets during the summer of 1999 versus the summer of\n1998. We offer recommendations for correcting some of the remaining market design\nflaws identified in previous MSC reports. We also identify several flaws in the market\ndesign that have revealed themselves since our March 1999 report was submitted.\nRecommendations for correcting these market design flaws are provided. Finally, we\ndescribe several long-term changes in market design that we believe should be\nimplemented to facilitate the transparency of hourly wholesale market prices to retail\nelectricity customers.\n        The performance of the ISO’s ancillary services markets during the summer of\n1999 appears to be significantly improved relative to the same month during the summer\nof 1998, based on market prices, market requirements, and bid sufficiency frequencies.\nHowever, a substantial proportion of this improvement in market performance can be\nattributed to lower average hourly total system loads during the summer of 1999 relative\nto the summer of 1998.\n        We find that significant market power remains in California’s wholesale energy\nmarket during periods of high total system load, which primarily occur during the\nsummer months. We find that for the majority of summer months in 1999, for the same\nlevel of total system load, real-time energy prices were higher in 1999 than in 1998.\nNevertheless, the total amount of market power exercised during the summer month of\n1999 that we have data for appears to be significantly less than that exercised during that\nsame month in 1998. We also present evidence that suggests that the opportunities for\nthe exercise of market power in the ISO’s ancillary services markets are greater when\nthese markets are cleared on a zonal versus statewide basis.\n        The outstanding market design flaws identified in previous MSC reports are: (1)\nrules for dispatching Reliability Must-Run (RMR) contract generation units, (2) the lack\nof a price-responsive hourly wholesale electricity demand, and (3) the inability of utility\ndistribution company loads to forward contract for their energy and ancillary services\ndemands outside of the PX markets.\n        Market design flaws identified since the April 1999 MSC report are: (1) the\nincentives for generation unit owners to create and profit from resolving intra-zonal\ncongestion, (2) non-compliance of generation unit owners with ISO technical standards\nfor providing energy and ancillary services capacity, and (3) the lack of incentives for\nprice-responsive retail demand caused by the current California “stranded asset” recovery\nmechanism.\n        Long-term market redesign issues analyzed are: (1) ISO policy for new zone\ncreation, (2) ISO policy for new generation interconnection, (3) retail competition\npolicies when any one of the three investor-owned utilities ends its stranded asset\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 1 of 148\n"  [3] "recovery period, and (4) mechanisms for selling Pacific Gas and Electric’s hydroelectric\nfacilities to enhance the competitiveness of the California wholesale electricity market.\n         This report provides recommendations for addressing each issue. We continue to\nadvocate pre-dispatch and mandatory day-ahead scheduling of RMR capacity as market-\nefficiency enhancing, consistent with the market design principles of the California\nmarket, and necessary for a workably competitive wholesale electricity market.\n         Because of remaining market power in the California wholesale electricity market\nand the lack of incentives for a price-responsive hourly retail demand created by the\nCalifornia market’s stranded asset recovery mechanism, we continue to advocate that the\nISO have the authority to impose a purchase price cap on its energy and ancillary services\nmarkets, at least until all remaining major market design flaws are eliminated. We\nadvocate that the ISO maintain the current $750/MW price cap at least through the end of\nthe summer of 2000. At this time, enough information on the performance of the ISO’s\nmarkets under the new ancillary services market design and new RMR contracts (with the\npre-dispatch and day-ahead scheduling reforms suggested above) will be available to\nevaluate whether removal or raising of this price cap is warranted.\n         We recommend revising the ISO’s intra-zonal congestion management protocols\nto create strong incentives for market participants to eliminate rather than cause intra-\nzonal congestion. A framework for determining the advisability of creating new\ncongestion zones from a market power perspective is given. Based on the market power\nanalysis presented in this report and incentives for creating intra-zonal congestion under\ncurrent ISO protocols, we believe that the ISO should exercise restraint in creating new\ncongestion zones, unless it feels that system reliability will be significantly enhanced by\ncreating a new congestion zone.\n         We also recommend that the ISO monitor the FTR market and establish position\nlimits on the quantity of FTR capacity controlled by any single market participant\n(including affiliates) during the initial stages of the operation of this market. Because of\nthe several features of the FTRs offered by the ISO, there may be opportunities for\ncertain market participants purchasing a large fraction of the FTR capacity on certain\ntransmission paths to profit from subsequently creating inter-zonal congestion in the day\nahead energy market.\n         To provide incentives for retail competition that increases the responsiveness of\nhourly retail demand to hourly wholesale electricity and ancillary services prices, we\nrecommend the adoption of a default provider retail rate in the post-rate-freeze period\nthat reduces the original rate-freeze retail rate by some fraction of the previous year’s\nannual average stranded asset recovery, rather than one that passes-through hourly\nwholesale energy and ancillary services costs according to a representative load profile.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 2 of 148\n"  [6] "1.       Introduction and Summary\n         This report analyzes the performance of the ISO’s energy and ancillary services\nmarkets since the previous Market Surveillance Committee (MSC) report was submitted\nto the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) on March 25, 1999. We offer\nrecommendations for correcting some of the remaining market design flaws identified in\nprevious MSC reports. We also identify several flaws in the market design that have\nrevealed themselves since our March report was submitted. Recommendations for\ncorrecting these market design flaws are provided as well. Finally, this report describes\nseveral long-term changes in market design that we believe should be implemented to\nfacilitate the transparency of hourly wholesale market prices to retail electricity\ncustomers. These changes should be implemented before the Competition Transition\nCharge (CTC) period, during which the original investor-owned utilities (IOUs) receive\npayment for their \"stranded assets,\" ends.\n         A.      Assessing the Performance of the ISO's Markets\n                 1.     Status of Redesign of Ancillary Services Markets\n         Since our last report, the ISO has implemented or will soon be implementing a\nnumber of ancillary service (A/S) market reforms.                   These reforms and their\nimplementation dates are summarized below and many are described more fully in the\nbody of this report.\nMarket Reform unavailable in real-time.\n• Rational Buyer Protocol                                         August 17, 1999\n• Additional Replacement Reserve procured to make                 August 17, 1999\n    up day-ahead under-scheduling of load and under-\n    production of generation\n         Requirement criteria\n         Cost allocation\n• Automated BEEP                                                  February 2000\n• Separate upward and downward regulation prices                  August 17, 1999\n• Improved facilitation of load participation in A/S              No definite date\n    markets\n• Inter-SC trades of A/S                                          September 13, 1999\n• Improved ISO control of regulation units                        December 31, 1999\n                         MSC  [7] "                  2.        Data Currently Available\n        Because many of the major ancillary services market redesign changes have only\nrecently been implemented, the MSC has been unable to analyze comprehensively many\nof the issues FERC requested that the MSC address in this report. In particular, the vast\nmajority of the design changes in the ISO’s ancillary services markets were implemented\non August 18, 1999, leaving the MSC with, at best, less than one-month’s worth of data\non market outcomes to use to determine the impact of these changes on market\nperformance. Given the dramatically different load conditions between August and\nSeptember 1999 and these same two months during 1998, these limited data are\ninsufficient to provide any definitive assessment of the success of the ancillary services\nmarket re-design process. Several of the other ancillary services market re-design\nelements were implemented very recently, and others have yet to be implemented.\nBecause of the comprehensive and interrelated nature of these market reforms, any\nassessment of their success given the data available at present would be premature.\n        The major Reliability-Must-Run (RMR) reforms were implemented effective June\n1, 1999. A complete assessment of these reforms is also constrained by data availability.\nThe ISO’s settlement data on actual metered unit-level electricity production and take-\nout-point electricity consumption on an hourly basis is currently only available through\nJuly 26, 1999.1 This information is an essential input to a full assessment of the\nperformance of the California energy market. Nevertheless, we offer a detailed analysis\nof the performance of the California energy market up to this date.\n        Although our focus is on the ancillary services markets and real-time energy\nmarkets, because of the very strong interactions among these markets and the PX markets\n(as emphasized in the our previous reports), the ISO's markets cannot be understood in\nisolation from the PX day-ahead and hour-ahead markets.\n        Despite the fact that data constraints prevent us from assessing the impact of\nISO’s recent market design changes, we note number of outstanding design flaws,\nincluding several that have become more noticeable since the March 1999 report.\n                  3.        Performance of the ISO’s Markets is Improving\n        From October 1998 to June 1999 market performance in the California energy\nmarket is what would be expected from a workably competitive market. We attribute this\nin no small part to the fact that this period was characterized by low levels of total ISO\nload relative those that occur during peak hours in the summer months. In addition,\nduring many of these months, electricity from hydroelectric facilities was plentiful. The\nperformance of the California energy market over this time period is encouraging. Given\nsystem and weather conditions over this time period, it is not surprising, and certainly\ndoes not imply that the ISO's markets will be workably competitive under more\ndemanding load conditions.\n1\n  Some of our data is available more recently than July 1999. For example, we are able to track bids and\nmarket-clearing prices through August 31,1999. We also analyze selected data on market-clearing prices\nand quantities recently through October 1, 1999.\n                             MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 6 of 148\n"  [8] "        Our basis for concluding that the performance of the market has improved comes\nfrom analyzing many of the indices discussed in our previous reports. We find that the\nfrequency of price spikes in the ancillary services markets that cannot be explained by\nhigh load conditions has been significantly reduced. Generally, the price caps have been\nhit in the energy and ancillary services markets during late 1998 and early 1999 when\ntotal ISO load has been fairly high. This observation tends to support the view that, at\nleast most of the time, prices reflect underlying demand and supply conditions rather than\nthe exercise of market power. We are also encouraged by the fact that total ancillary\nservices costs as a fraction of total energy costs have continually fallen from late 1998\nthrough August 1999.\n        There are several reasons for the apparent improvement in the performance of\nthese markets. A number of market design changes have been implemented; these\nshould improve the efficiency of the market. Furthermore, the ISO continues to learn and\nimprove its operations. Specifically, we present evidence that the ISO has managed to\nuse less of certain ancillary services to provide reserve capacity for the same level of total\nISO load. In addition, the ISO has embarked on a comprehensive plan to improve the\ncompliance of market participants with the technical standards associated with providing\nthe various ancillary services. For example, when the ISO procures a 10-minute\nresponse-time service it can easily verify if that is what it is actually getting. This\nincreased monitoring, combined with penalization for non-compliance, has improved the\nquality of ancillary services capacity submitted to the various ISO markets. These\nmonitoring and enforcement activities also have increased the likelihood that, if called on\nto provide real-time energy, a unit owner can and will actually provide that energy under\nthe terms at which the associated capacity was bid into the market.\n        The very mild weather conditions experienced in California during the summer of\n1999 are probably the single most important factor behind the apparent improvements in\nmarket performance. The ability of firms to exercise market power requires sufficiently\nhigh load conditions, which is typically due to very hot weather. During these time\nperiods, all generators know that they stand little likelihood of not being called to provide\neither energy or ancillary services, even if they bid significantly in excess of their\nproduction costs. However, when the weather is mild, the demand for electricity is\nsignificantly lower relative to available generation capacity. All generation unit owners\nknow that under these load conditions they stand a significant likelihood of not being\ncalled to provide energy or ancillary services if they bid sufficiently in excess of their\nmarginal cost of production. Consequently, a true test of the success of the ancillary\nservices and other market reforms must await a time period when system load conditions\nare at or above those experienced during the summer of 1998, a period with very high\nsystem loads.\n                4.      Market Power Persists\n        Despite these improvements, our analysis of the recent data from the summer of\n1999 reveal that market power persists in the ISO's markets, particularly during periods\nof high system load. During these time periods, price movements across hours of the day\nare significantly in excess of the increased costs of supplying power during these hours.\n                          MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 7 of 148\n"  [9] "During these time periods, even the highest-cost generation unit supplying energy is\nbeing paid according to a price significantly in excess of its marginal production cost in\nthat hour. This is a direct indication of market power.\n          We have limited data from the summer of the 1999 with which to perform a\ndefinitive analysis of the exercise of market power during these months. However, for\nthe one month we do have data, July 1999, we see evidence of continued exercise of\nmarket power. Specifically, we calculated market clearing prices assuming a “pure”\ncompetitive market benchmark, compared them to actual energy costs in those hours, and\nfound the actual costs to be on average 20% above those predicted by this benchmark\nmarket outcome. Although below the value of this spread in July 1998 of 38%, the\nspread for July 1999 remains unacceptably high.2 It is important to note that the\nexistence of this amount of market power in the California wholesale electricity market\ndoes not imply that the annual total cost (including wholesale electricity and ancillary\nservices costs) of delivering electricity to final consumers in California is higher than it\nwould have been if the vertically-integrated monopoly regime had continued.\n          Our analysis of market conditions following the recent increase in the price cap in\nthe ISO’s energy and ancillary services markets from $250/MW to $750/MW (on\nOctober 1, 1999) shows that under certain system conditions (which could occur with\nsome frequency during the summer and early fall), prices in both the energy and ancillary\nservices markets can rise to their maximum levels, well above marginal production costs.\nThe evidence therefore supports the need for some level of price protection for buyers\nuntil we can review market performance next summer and confirm that the extent of the\nexercise of market power has substantially decreased.\n                  5.       Underlying Causes of Market Power\n          The underlying causes of market power in the ISO's markets are no different from\nthose leading to market power in other markets. Buyers have a limited ability to\nsubstitute to other products (inelastic demand). Suppliers from outside the market have\nlimited ability (usually due to transmission constraints) to offer their product for sale\n(inelastic supply). There is also concentration among sellers, and certain existing\nregulatory rules further reduce flexibility on the supply and demand side of the market.\n          Final hourly retail demand is virtually price inelastic with respect to the hourly\nwholesale price of electricity. This is due in large part due to California’s retail rate\nfreeze that severs the link between hourly wholesale energy costs and retail prices paid\nfor electricity consumed. The current combined retail rate freeze and stranded asset\nrecovery mechanism eliminates any incentive retail customers have to install hourly\nmeters and purchase their electricity according to rates that vary with hourly wholesale\nenergy and ancillary service prices. This mechanism eliminates virtually any incentive\nenergy services providers (ESPs) have to install real-time meters and bill their customers\naccording to rates that vary with hourly wholesale energy and ancillary service prices.\n2\n  This figure was computed using the methodology described in \"Diagnosing Market Power in California's\nRestructured Wholesale Electricity Market,\" Severin Borenstein, James Bushnell, and Frank Wolak,\nUniversity of California Energy Institute, July 1999. Available from http://www.ucei.berkeley.edu/ucei/.\n                            MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 8 of 148\n" Still, particularly\nduring hot weather days, demand conditions are such that certain suppliers are “pivotal”\nand their bids can have a large effect on the price of energy or any of the ancillary\nservices during certain hours of the day.\n        Concerns about market power for a given ancillary service are exacerbated during\nperiods of peak demand for that service and during periods of inter-zonal transmission\nconstraint in the day-ahead energy market. Periods of peak demand for certain ancillary\nservices need not coincide with periods of peak demand for electricity. For example, the\nISO's peak demand for regulation typically arises during the shoulder periods on days\nwhen energy demand is peaking. Inter-zonal transmission constraints creates smaller\ngeographic markets which can lead to greater opportunities for generation unit owners to\nexercise market power within each congestion zone.\n        Finally, it is important to emphasize that the California energy and ancillary\nservices markets remain a work in progress. Key elements of this market are still not in\nplace: complete reform of the RMR contracts, meaningful compliance (e.g., the ability of\nthe ISO to verify that suppliers of ancillary services indeed stand ready to offer those\nservices as promised), and various ISO operating practices, software upgrades, and the\nlike.\n        B.      Short-Term Recommendations\n                1.      Complete the Design of California Markets\n        The ISO is still in the process of implementing various market designs that,\nhopefully, will improve the efficiency of the ISO's markets. Over the past year, this\nprocess has focused on the redesign of the ancillary services markets, although significant\nefforts are underway which are aimed at improving the responsiveness of the real-time\nenergy BEEP stack.\n        A major outcome of the ancillary services re-design process is the implementation\nof the Rational Buyer protocols. The ISO has also adopted ancillary services\nprocurement practices that have improved the liquidity of the hour-ahead ancillary\nservices market, by delaying some of its ancillary services purchases from the day-ahead\nto the hour-ahead market. Finally, ISO has taken steps to reduce its role as the major\npurchaser of ancillary services by allowing Scheduling Coordinators more flexibility in\nself-providing their ancillary services requirement through inter-SC trades. A major\ncomponent of the project to increase the responsiveness of the real-time BEEP stack is\naimed at increasing the speed and accuracy with which dispatch instructions are sent to\ngenerators and responded to. The other component is concerned with ex post verification\nof actual compliance with ISO technical standards for providing each of the ancillary\nservices, and confirmation that all ancillary services purchased are actually supplied.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 9 of 148\n" [11] "                2.      Retain Price Caps for an Interim Period\n        Perhaps the single most important policy issue we address in this report is\nwhether the FERC should continue to grant the ISO the authority to impose purchase\nprice caps on its energy and ancillary services markets. Several outstanding design flaws\nidentified in our previous reports have not yet been adequately addressed, so that the\nISO's markets cannot yet be relied upon to be workably competitive. This is particularly\ntrue during hours of high ISO system load, which primarily occur in the months of July to\nSeptember. Consequently, we strongly believe that the FERC should continue to grant\nthe ISO the authority to impose purchase price caps.             Indeed, under current market\nconditions, we believe that removing the ISO’s authority to implement a purchase price\ncap would pose a significant risk in that very high prices for energy and ancillary services\ncould prevail during hours with a high ISO system load and/or high demand for a specific\nancillary service. We therefore urge the FERC to extend the ISO’s authority to impose\npurchase price caps on all ISO markets until it is clear that significant market power\ncannot be exercised in the ISO's markets. The current $750 maximum price should be\nretained at least until RMR reform is completed. The price cap should remain at this\nlevel through the end of the summer of 2000.\n                3.      Remove Regulatory Barriers to Demand Response\n        The current CTC recovery mechanism and the associated retail electricity price\nrate freeze is a major barrier to the development of the price-responsive hourly retail\ndemand necessary for a price responsive hourly wholesale demand for energy and\nancillary services. As discussed in previous MSC Reports, a price-responsive hourly\nwholesale demand is essential to limit the exercise of market power by generators during\nperiods expected to have high system loads. During periods of low system loads,\ncompetition among suppliers is usually sufficient to discipline the exercise of market\npower because a significant fraction of available generation capacity is not needed to\nmeet anticipated demand. Currently, during periods forecast to have high system loads,\nall generation unit owners know that a very large fraction of their capacity will be\nrequired to meet the ISO’s energy and ancillary services needs, regardless of the bid\nprice. With a credible price-responsive hourly wholesale demand (which is only possible\nwith a price-responsive hourly retail demand), generators bidding high prices know that\nthey stand a significant chance of not selling their capacity, even during periods predicted\nto have high system loads. For this reason, generation unit owners will bid prices closer\nto their marginal costs because they recognize that if prices are too high, the price-\nresponsive wholesale demand will decide not to purchase.\n        We show that the current CTC recovery mechanism and associated retail rate\nfreeze dulls the incentives ESPs have to install the hourly meters necessary to enable\nmeaningful hourly pricing of retail electricity. This regulatory mechanism also\neliminates virtually any financial incentive retail customers have to install their own\nhourly meters or purchase electricity according to retail rates which reward hourly price-\nresponsiveness to wholesale electricity and ancillary services prices. The only market\nparticipants with financial incentives to reduce wholesale energy and ancillary services\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 10 of 148\n" The\nthree original IOUs also currently have significantly less ability to reduce wholesale\nenergy and ancillary services prices relative to the summer of 1998 because of the sale of\na significant amount of their in-state fossil fuel generating capacity since that time.\n        We also show that the requirement of the CTC recovery mechanism which\nprohibits forward contracting for energy and ancillary services by the utility distribution\ncompanies (UDCs) outside of PX reduces the opportunities for final demand in the\nCalifornia market to respond to high energy and ancillary services prices. Because of the incentives caused by other requirements of\nthe CTC mechanism described above, this role of the PX is even more valuable during\nthe retail rate freeze period.\n        We also believe that the end of the CTC recovery mechanism for an UDC, such as\nSan Diego Gas & Electric’s announcement to end on July 1, 1999, presents a unique\nopportunity to develop the incentives for price-responsive retail demand necessary for a\ncompetitive wholesale energy and ancillary services market. To foster a price-responsive retail demand and\nencourage true value-added retail competition, the default provider retail rate should be\nset at the current rate freeze price less some fraction of the expected reduction in per\nMWh CTC payments by the UDC’s customers as a result of ending the rate freeze. [13] "per unit transmission and distribution charges and other per unit unavoidable charges\nunless the customer already has an hourly meter installed. Charging a customer with a\nconventional meter according to this rate requires the use of load-profiling, which\ndestroys any incentive the customer has to reduce its hourly demand in response to high\nwholesale prices in that hour. For this reason, such a default provider rate locks-in a\nretail demand that does not respond to hourly wholesale price movements, while at the\nsame time virtually eliminating any profit margin for ESPs to compete for by supplying\nelectricity to retail customers. Under our suggested default provider scheme, one way\nthese retail margins can be competed away is by ESPs and the UDCs paying for the\ninstallation of hourly-metering technology. Customers on hourly meters will increase the\ncompetitiveness of the wholesale electricity market, which should result in lower average\nwholesale electricity prices to all California consumers, whether or not they have an\nhourly meter.\n                 4.     Improve FERC and CPUC Communication\n        As noted in the previous section, a price-responsive hourly wholesale demand for\nelectricity is not possible without a price-responsive hourly retail demand. This is\nperhaps the best, but by no means the only, illustration of how retail electricity market\nregulatory polices set by the California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC) have a\ndirect impact on the efficiency of wholesale electricity markets. The CTC recovery\nmechanism described above is another important example. Wholesale markets in\nCalifornia and rest of the United States would greatly benefit from retail policies that\nimproved rather than hindered the efficiency of wholesale electricity markets.\n        Another area of state-level regulatory policy that can exert a significant impact on\nthe competitiveness of wholesale electricity markets is the process for expanding, siting\nand financing new transmission capacity. Given the increased opportunities for the\nexercise of market power during hours when there is congestion in the transmission grid,\nstate policies that are consistent with increasing the efficiency of wholesale electricity\nmarkets are crucial to the success of wholesale electricity industry re-structuring efforts.\n        Consequently, we recommend that the FERC coordinate its policies to enhance\nthe competitiveness and efficiency of wholesale electricity markets with CPUC policies\nfor the design of state-level retail electricity market policies. The ultimate goal of\nelectricity restructuring--lower delivered electricity prices for California consumers--can\nbe best achieved with greater communication and coordination between the CPUC and\nFERC along this dimension. A useful step in direction would be to organize a conference\non this topic between relevant FERC and CPUC staff and California market participants.\nThis would be an ideal forum to discuss the major issues associated moving the\nCalifornia market from one with few incentives for market-efficiency-enhancing\nbehavior, caused in part by the CTC recovery mechanism, to one which provides all\nmarket participants with the price signals necessary to market-efficiency-enhancing\ndecisions.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 12 of 148\n" [14] "                5.      Implement Pre-Dispatch and Day-Ahead Scheduling of RMR Units\n        Our previous reports provided detailed analyses of the Reliability-Must-Run units\nand the contacts under which those units operate. The new RMR contracts, which\nbecame effective June 1, 1999, represent a significant improvement over the original\nRMR contracts that they replaced. However, the issue of when to dispatch and schedule\nRMR units under these new contracts has been point of disagreement between the ISO\nand the owners of these units. As we explain in detail below, the efficiency of California's\nenergy and ancillary services markets would be improved by dispatching RMR units\nbefore the start of the day-ahead energy market. Under this procedure, the pre-dispatched\nRMR capacity from each RMR unit would then be required to be part of a balanced day-\nahead energy schedule submitted to ISO. This change should greatly reduce or eliminate\nthe market inefficiencies caused by the attempts of RMR unit owners to use the local\nmarket power possessed by their unit during certain system load conditions to set high\nprices in the energy and ancillary services markets.\n                6.      Use PG&E Hydro Divestiture to Enhance Competition\n        The sale of PG&E’s hydro assets can hasten the end of its CTC recovery period,\nand thus potentially contribute to improved hourly price-responsiveness in the California\nmarket. However, there should be no rush to complete this divestiture unless it reduces\nconcentration in the markets to provide ancillary services and energy. We recommend\nselling PG&E’s hydro assets in watershed-size increments to entities not currently\nowning significant generation capacity in California. We much prefer a “structural”\nsolution of this type, which genuinely reduces market power, rather than a “behavioral”\nsolution consisting of various regulatory rules intended to limit the exercise of market\npower by new owner. Behavioral rules may be hard to monitor and enforce, and may\nenhance the ability of other firms, besides the one subject to the behavioral rules, to\nexercise market power. Therefore, these sorts of behavioral rules may increase market\nprices even though the firm subject to these rules never sets the market price.\n                7.      Modify the ISO's Congestion Management Procedures\n        This report also analyses the impact of the ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion\nmanagement protocols on the performance of the real-time energy market. Since the\nMarch 1999 report, intra-zonal congestion costs have dramatically risen, and the number\nof intra-zonal interfaces experiencing noticeable congestion has also risen. We suggest\nseveral market rule changes that would significantly reduce the frequency of intra-zonal\ncongestion and the mitigation costs when it does occur.\n        The ISO’s current system for managing intra-zonal congestion provides no market\nparticipant with a financial incentive to reduce intra-zonal congestion costs. However,\ndepending on load conditions and the production of nearby generation units, any\ngeneration unit owner can profit from causing intra-zonal congestion that it subsequently\nrelieves. This occurs because the ISO’s intra-zonal congestion management protocols\nallows generators located on a workably competitive side of an intra-zonal interface to be\npaid as bid to relieve the congestion. The California market rules allows unit owners to\npursue their financial interests in the real-time market. Therefore, when these firms find\nthat grid conditions are such that they can earn substantial profits from alleviating intra-\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 13 of 148\n" [15] "zonal congestion along an intra-zonal path, this congestion tends to occur. Consequently,\nit appears that much of the current intra-zonal congestion in the California market is not\ncaused by bidding behavior of price-taking generators, but it is instead the result of\nstrategic actions of favorably located generators who understand the incentives created by\nthe ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion management protocols. We should emphasize\nthat we are not saying that these generators are violating the ISO market rules by these\nactions. These generators are simply attempting to maximize their expected profits\nsubject to the market rules they face.\n         Our solution to this market design flaw is to create a market participant with a\nstrong financial incentive to keep intra-zonal congestion costs down. As we argue, there\nis no meaningful economic distinction between energy provided to relieve intra-zonal\ncongestion from a local monopoly or duopoly supplier of this service and local grid\nreliability services provided by a local monopoly or duopoly supplier of this service.\nRMR units are designated to provide the latter but not the former service, although the\nISO tariff allows these units to be used to provide this service as well. We classify both\nof these services under the general category of “market liquidity,” because once a given\nquantity of market liquidity energy has been provided at certain points in the transmission\ngrid, it is possible to run an unconstrained zonal energy market. These market liquidity\nproviders have an incentive to alleviate intra-zonal congestion because under the terms of\ntheir RMR contract, they face the prospect of being called to relieve intra-zonal\ncongestion with incremental or decremental energy at their RMR variable payment rate.\nDuring high load conditions, when the zonal energy price is expected to be very high, the\nprospect of foregoing the zonal-market clearing price and receiving the RMR variable\npayment rate to relieve intra-zonal congestion gives the RMR unit owner a strong\nincentive to generate from its RMR units and other units to prevent intra-zonal\ncongestion. This will allow the firm to earn a high zonal price for all its capacity\nproducing imbalance energy during that hour.\n         To give the Participating Transmission Owner (PTO) the incentive to upgrade the\ntransmission grid on the paths where there is significant intra-zonal congestion, we\nrecommend charging the PTO for the costs of all RMR calls to mitigate intra-zonal\ncongestion. Currently, RMR energy used for local grid reliability services is charged to\nthe PTO, so that by charging the PTO for the costs of relieving intra-zonal congestion by\nRMR units, we are explicitly recognizing the equivalence of these two actions by RMR\nunits.\n         We also recommend that the ISO delay implementing any scheme for managing\nintra-zonal congestion in the forward market until it is convinced that the incentives to\ncause intra-zonal congestion in the real-time market have been significantly reduced.\nOtherwise it may simply end up paying twice to relieve the intra-zonal congestion along\nthe same transmission path--once in the forward market and again in the real-time\nmarket. This outcome can occur because even though day-ahead energy schedules are\nrequired to be balanced and are made feasible by a forward market intra-zonal congestion\nmeasure, a generation unit is free to deviate from this schedule and cause intra-zonal\ncongestion if this is profitable given system conditions in real-time.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 14 of 148\n" [16] "                8.       Monitor Firm Transmission Rights (FTRs) Market\n         We remain unconvinced that Firm Transmission Rights (FTRs) sold by the ISO\nare a socially valuable “product.” First, they are designed to be primarily used to hedge\nagainst congestion charges in the day-ahead energy market, where no energy is actually\ndelivered, and not against congestion charges in the real-time market, where all energy is\ndelivered. We also do not expect any market participant to pay more for an FTR than it\ncan expect to earn in congestion revenues by owning this right. However, the ex post\ncost to another market participant besides the ISO of selling this hedge product is exactly\nequal to these congestion revenues. Consequently, one interpretation of the ISO’s sales\nof FTRs is that it is selling a product at an expected loss (the price is less than the\ncongestion revenues the FTR owner expects to receive) to hedge congestion charges in a\nmarket where no energy is actually delivered. The ISO’s FTRs also provide scheduling\npriority in the event that there are insufficient adjustment bids to clear the market on\neither side of a transmission path. However, for a large enough default usage charge\nalong a transmission path, we would expect Scheduling Coordinators to always find it in\ntheir financial interest to submit adjustment bids across the transmission path, so that the\nISO’s scheduling priority should rarely, if ever, come into play.\n         Because of the opportunities to earn profits from day-ahead inter-zonal price\ndifferences created by the existence of FTRs, one can understand why most market\nparticipants want the ISO to offer this product. However, it is unclear why requiring that\nISO offer this product enhances the efficiency of the California electricity market. If the\nISO did not offer FTRs, we would expect similar products to be offered if there were\ngenerators and loads willing to pay prices greater than or equal to the expected\ncongestion revenues they avoid by the purchase of this product. This requirement on the\nrelationship between the privately supplied FTR price and the expected congestion\nrevenues avoided is necessary for the entity offering the product to expect to earn a profit.\nIn addition, we would also expect these privately offered transmission congestion hedge\ncontracts to be based on congestion in the real-time market, when generation unit owners\nare actually supplying energy to the grid, rather than congestion in the day-ahead market\nwhich leads to only forward financial commitments to produce electricity. As the\nincident involving Path SR3 on May 25, 1999 illustrates, a SC’s day-ahead energy\nschedule along a transmission path can differ enormously from the capacity of the path3.\nThis can then lead to significantly higher zonal or statewide day-ahead energy prices and\na very high transmission charge across that path.\n         Because of the uncertain benefits to market efficiency from the ISO selling FTRs\nand the increased profit-making opportunities they allow market participants who are\nable to cause inter-zonal congestion, we strongly recommend that the ISO be able to\nmonitor the operation of this market. We also continue to believe that if certain market\nparticipants are able to obtain a large fraction of the FTR capacity on a certain\ntransmission path, they may be able to earn profits from setting extremely high\n3\n  On May 25, 1999 a day-ahead energy schedule was submitted across Path SR3, which has a capacity of\n15MW, that was more than 100 times this value.\n                          MSC [17] "congestion prices along this path.4 Therefore, if there are going to be FTRs, in order to\nmonitor this market, we strongly recommend that market participants be required to\nreport all secondary trades so that regulators (and the ISO) can track the ownership of\nthese rights. We also believe that the ability of generators to set very high congestion\nprices will be greatly diminished if position limits are imposed on their ownership.\nThese position limits would set a maximum on the fraction of available FTR capacity of a\ntransmission path that a market participant can own. We recommend that any one entity\n(including affiliates) be limited to holding no more than 40% of the available FTRs on\nany given interface.\n                  9.        Exercise Restraint in Creating New Zones5\n         When a transmission path within a zone is regularly congested, there are good\nreasons to create a new zone. This transforms an intra-zonal interface into an inter-zonal\ninterface: doing so allows congestion over this interface to be handled using market\nprocesses based on adjustment bids (as opposed to the ISO's procedures for handling\nintra-zonal congestion). However, creating a new zone can lead to highly concentrated\nownership of generation units in the markets within each zone, which enhances the ability\nof generation unit owners to set high zonal prices. In the light of this tradeoff, it is not\nthe case that creating more zones always or typically enhances the efficiency of the\noverall market. Recognizing this tradeoff, the ISO Tariff calls for the creation of new\nzones only if generation markets on both sides of the interface in question are \"workably\ncompetitive.\"\n         Below we provide a framework for assessing whether electricity markets in\ngeneral, and zonal generation markets in particular, are \"workably competitive.\" We\nthen apply this general framework and offer an empirical analysis of market outcomes\nduring 1999, which demonstrates that zonal markets do indeed allow greater\nopportunities for the exercise of market power. We find that, controlling for the level of\ntotal system load, when the ancillary services markets in California were cleared on a\nzonal basis, day-ahead prices in the SP15 congestion zone were significantly higher than\nin comparable hours, in terms of total system load, when the markets were cleared on a\nstatewide basis. In addition, we find that what we call the pivotal bidder frequency in the\nancillary services markets is significantly higher when these markets are cleared on a\nzonal basis rather than statewide. We say that a bidder is pivotal in a market during a\ngiven hour if by removing its bids from the market there are insufficient remaining bids\nto meet market demand. This implies that at least for the amount of this bid shortfall, in\nthe absence of a purchase price cap on that market, the pivotal bidder could name any bid\nprice and that would set the market price.\n         In addition, in our analysis of the ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion\nmanagement protocols we show that there are no market participants with a significant\n4\n  In May of 1998, the MSC issued an opinion on the ISO’s transmission rights proposals. [18] "financial incentive to reduce the incidence of intra-zonal congestion, but many with\nstrong financial incentives to cause intra-zonal congestion. Consequently, it is difficult to\nargue that the same frequency and geographic distribution of intra-zonal congestion\nwould occur if the ISO’s protocols made the existence of intra-zonal congestion costly to\nsome or all market participants. We therefore provide recommendations for revising the\nISO’s intra-zonal congestion management protocols to create incentive for market\nparticipants to reduce the incidences of intra-zonal congestion.\n         Because of the increased opportunities to exercise market power during congested\ntimes in a market with more zones, we recommend that the ISO delay the formation of\nnew congestion zones unless it needs to do so for system grid reliability reasons,. If the\ncurrent location and frequency of intra-zonal congestion continues after the revised intra-\nzonal congestion management protocols have been implemented, then creating a new\ncongestion may be the only solution. However, if these revised protocols significantly\nreduce the frequency of intra-zonal congestion in the California market, then the ISO has\nsaved itself significant increased market power risk and improved market efficiency by\navoiding the creation of a new congestion zone. It has also saved the significant software\nand administrative costs associated with creating a new congestion zone.\n         The current frequency and distribution of intra-zonal congestion illustrates\nanother important implication of the fact that the California market design allows all\ngenerators substantial freedom to pursue their financial interest in the real-time market. It\nis extremely difficult, under the California market design, to disentangle system\nreliability issues from strategic issues associated with generators pursuing their economic\ninterests. In the present context, the ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion management\nprotocols create financial incentives to create intra-zonal congestion, which can\nsignificantly compromise real-time system reliability. The ISO system operators must\noften increment and decrement significant amounts of generation capacity in real-time to\nmanage a problem that is created in large part by the economic incentives that generators\nface under the current ISO protocols for managing intra-zonal congestion.\nConsequently, the success of the California market design requires aligning as closely as\npossible the generator’s financial incentives for supplying energy in real-time with the\nISO’s desire to maintain system reliability at least cost.\n         C.      Long-Term Recommendations\n                 1.     Complete the Market Design Process\n         The ISO is currently in the process of reviewing various proposed Market\nRedesign 2000 (MR2000) Projects. These projects will continue the current ancillary\nservices and real-time energy market re-design processes. Several are particularly\npromising and should improve the efficiency of the ISO’s markets. Our highest priority\nproject proposes to provide greater integration of the ancillary services management\n(ASM) software and the inter-zonal congestion management (CONG) software. The\nbasic aim of this re-design is to allow ancillary services capacity to compete for the use of\ntransmission capacity, which should increase the depth of the ISO’s inter-zonal\n [19] "congestion management markets. Allowing generators to have separate ramp rates for\nseveral operating levels for each ancillary service is another market change likely to\nincrease market efficiency because it increases the match between the generator’s\nfinancial commitments and the physical capabilities of the generating unit (under these\nfinancial commitments). The ability of a SC to bid and self-provide the same ancillary\nservice from the same unit during the same hour should give market participants greater\nflexibility to enter into commitments to buy and sell ancillary services. All of these\nMR2000 projects should significantly improve the operation of the ISO’s markets.\n                2.      Develop Rules Governing Entry by New Generators\n        California market does not yet have clear policy for connecting new generation\nunits to the ISO grid. On June 23, 1999, the ISO filed Amendment 19 to the ISO Tariff\nto implement a New Generation Connection Policy (NewGen) approved by the ISO\nBoard of Governors. On September 15, 1999, the FERC rejected this new generation\nconnection policy. As we discuss in Section 9 of this report, a major shortcoming of the\nISO’s NewGen policy given in Amendment 19 can be traced to the existing ISO\nprotocols for managing intra-zonal congestion. We therefore recommend that any\nNewGen policy implemented include a revision of the ISO’s intra-zonal congestion\nmanagement policy to eliminate the incentive that generation owners have to cause intra-\nzonal congestion.\n        A major focus of the ISO’s NewGen policy is how the incremental intra-zonal\ncongestion caused by a new entrant will be determined and mitigated. The new entrant\nshould only pay for the additional costs its presence in the grid imposes on other market\nparticipants, not for additional intra-zonal congestion costs that result from the incentives\ncaused by the ISO’s intra-zonal congestion management protocols. This NewGen policy\nshould also compensate new entrants for any benefits their presence provides to other\nmarket participants by netting out from these incremental intra-zonal costs any system\nbenefits it provides.\n        Besides our recommendations for revising the ISO’s intra-zonal congestion\nmanagement protocols, we also provide recommendations for the design of the ISO’s\nNewGen policy. Many of the features of the ISO’s current NewGen are consistent with\nthese recommendations, but the missing ingredient that has not been explicitly spelled out\nis the ISO’s revision to its intra-zonal congestion management policy. However, we\nshould also note that the ISO has made significant progress over the past month in\nformulating revisions to its intra-zonal congestion management protocols which appear\nlargely consistent with our recommended intra-zonal congestion management protocols.\n                3. If only to prevent market participants from testing the\nextremes of what is a tolerable maximum magnitude for a price spike, we believe that it\nwould be prudent for the ISO management and Board to maintain an extremely high\n“damage control” price cap indefinitely. Transmission Planning\n        The current California market design provides limited incentives for grid\nupgrades and expansions. In addition, the process by which transmission capacity\nexpansion and siting decisions will occur is still the subject of some debate. This is an\narea where greater communication and coordination between the CPUC and the FERC\ncould enhance the efficiency of the California market over the long-term.\n        Grid expansions and upgrades are highly beneficial to the competitiveness of the\nCalifornia electricity market. As our empirical evidence indicates, if the energy and\nancillary services markets always cleared on a statewide basis, ancillary services prices\nwould most likely be lower. However, the grid upgrades necessary for this to occur may\nnot justify the wholesale energy price reductions that would result from completely\neliminating congestion. Nevertheless, if the lessons from deregulation in the airline\nindustry (which greatly expanded the complexity of its network following deregulation)\nare at all applicable to the electricity industry, a competitive market in generation may\nrequire a more extensive and higher-capacity network than the historical vertically\nintegrated regulated utility regime. During this regime, the vertically integrated utility\ncould substitute between additional transmission capacity and additional generation in\nways that may not be possible under the new competitive regime. Consequently, there is\ngood reason to believe that we are currently at a point where additional transmission\nupgrades at the appropriate points in the California network can significantly increase the\ncompetitiveness of the ISO’s markets.\n        Another area for further CPUC and FERC coordination is in removing any\nregulatory barriers that prevent existing transmission capacity (ETC) owners in California\nfrom joining the ISO. For this reason, the ISO’s MR2000 project proposal to provide\nnon-firm transmission rights should be undertaken. It will allow ETC holders greater\nflexibility to participate in the ISO’s markets and give the ISO market participants greater\naccess to unused transmission capacity.\n2. [21] "         The Committee found that the ISO’s ancillary services markets were not yet\noperating in a manner consistent with workable competition. Prices in the ancillary\nservices markets were not fluctuating in a manner that reflected changes in the underlying\nmarginal costs of supplying these products. Ancillary services markets exhibited extreme\nprice volatility, even during periods when demand was unchanged for long periods of\ntime. In the Committee’s opinion, the conditions were not yet in place to rely on these\nmarkets to set efficient, cost-reflective prices. Prices for lower quality services such as\nreplacement reserve routinely exceeded the prices for higher quality services such as\nregulation. Often ancillary services capacity prices exceeded both the Power Exchange\n(PX) and real-time energy price for the same hour, despite the fact that no net energy\nneed be produced to supply these ancillary services.6 The Committee recommended that\nuntil workable competition was established, the ISO continue to utilize a price cap for\nancillary services.\n         The Committee identified nine underlying factors that were then contributing to\nthe inefficient operation of the ISO’s ancillary services markets: (1) some firms were\nsubject to cost-based price caps while others were allowed to earn market-based rates; (2)\nthe demand for ancillary services was higher than anticipated; (3) the amount of each\nancillary service demanded by the ISO did not depend on market prices and these\ndemands were not procured in a rational manner; (4) perverse incentives for generator\nbidding and scheduling behavior were created by the RMR contracts; (5) the ISO often\npurchased ancillary services separately from small geographic areas, increasing the\npotential for the exercise of market power; (6) the ISO’s dispatch practices were not\ntransparent to market participants; (7) the allocation of ancillary services costs to\nscheduling coordinators was flawed; (8) suppliers of ancillary services from outside of\nthe ISO control area were excluded from participation in these markets; and (9) the ISO’s\ncomputer systems were still facing various software difficulties that were not yet fixed.\n         While the Committee was not able to measure precisely the relative significance\nof each of these problems, its analyses did provide some insights. The quantities of\nancillary service purchased far exceeded the levels at which they had historically been\nacquired. High demand was not a direct cause of the market irregularities, but the\nsubstantial quantities acquired appears to have increased the impact of the other factors.\nPrices for ‘inferior’ ancillary services routinely exceeded those for ‘superior’ services.\nThe ISO’s inability to substitute among these services therefore appeared to have\nsignificantly impacted the cost of acquiring them. Lastly, it appeared from the MSC’s\npreliminary analysis that RMR contracts were not doing a great deal to reduce market\npower problems. Instead, they were most likely contributing to such problems by\nproviding incentives for owners of generators with RMR units to bid and schedule their\nunits less aggressively, at higher prices than they would in the absence of these\nincentives.\n    In our March 1999 report, further review of the performance of the ISO’s ancillary\nservices markets bears out the observations made in our August report.\n6\n  Any allowable net energy supplied while providing these services is paid for at the real-time energy price.\n                           MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 20 of 148\n" August MSC Report Recommendations\n        The August 1998 MSC Report recommended to the ISO seven specific measures\nthat would, in the Committee’s judgement, enable the ISO’s ancillary services markets to\nbecome workably competitive. Those recommendations are described below.\n                 1.     Adoption of “Rational Buyer” Protocols\n        The ISO should implement “rational” purchasing practices for ancillary services\nthat allow the ISO to substitute cheaper superior services for more expensive inferior\nservices in its procurement of ancillary services.\n                 2.     Reform of Reliability Must-Run (RMR) Contracts\n        The ISO should revise RMR protocols and contracts so that these contracts no\nlonger provide incentives for generating units with RMR contracts to bid and schedule\nless aggressively (higher prices for the same bid quantity) into the day-ahead energy\nmarket and ancillary services markets. This could involve creating a new class of true\noption contracts to replace most of the RMR contracts.\n                 3.     Approval for Market-Based Rates\n        The FERC should grant market-based rates for all market participants, assuming\nthe ISO retains the authority to impose a damage control price cap.\n                 4.     Retention of a “Damage Control” Price-Cap\n        The FERC should allow the ISO to retain a damage control price-cap on all\nancillary services that can be raised or lowered at the ISO’s discretion, regardless of what\ndecision is made on granting all firms market-based rates for all ancillary services.\n                 5.     Use of a Statewide Auction for Ancillary Reserves\n        The ISO should run the auction for ancillary services on a statewide basis. If the\nstatewide market-clearing prices left a shortfall of supply in a given zone, the Committee\nrecommended using RMR contracts to make up the shortfall.\n                         MSC Report, Reduce the Demand for Regulation\n         The ISO should revise its scheduling and/or energy imbalance protocols to help\nreduce its need for regulation capacity.\n                   7. ISO Market Redesign Proposals\n         On March 1, 1999, pursuant to the Commission’s direction in its October 28th\nOrder, the ISO filed the first major set of its ancillary services market redesign\nproposals.7 These proposals included:\n                   1.       Adoption of “Rational Buyer” Protocols\n         The ISO proposed to modify its ancillary service procurement process to enable\nthe ISO to purchase additional quantities on one ancillary service that can substitute for\nanother ancillary service, in order to reduce total ancillary services purchase costs.\n                   2.       Uninstructed Deviation and Replacement Reserve Allocation\n         The ISO proposed to adjust the amounts payable to the operators of resources that\nfail to comply with ISO dispatch instructions. The ISO also put forward a plan for it to\npurchase additional quantities of Replacement reserves to cover any forecast deficiencies\nin available energy, in order to reduce the ISO's reliance on out-of-market purchases for\nthat purpose. The cost of this additional Replacement reserve capacity is allocated to\nloads in proportion to the extent that their hour-ahead energy schedules are below their\nreal-time consumption, and to generation in proportion to the extent their real-time\ngeneration falls short of their hour-ahead energy schedule. In this sense loads, are\ndeterred from scheduling less than their demands in the real-time market, and generators\nare deterred from under-producing energy relative to hour-ahead schedules.\n         A major way load protects itself from the attempts of generators to set high prices\nin the PX and ISO energy markets during peak ISO load periods, is by shifting demands\nbetween these markets and routinely scheduling significantly less energy on an hour-\nahead basis than its expects to consume in the real time market. The MSC felt that this\nscheme would increase the cost of such defensive actions by demand, thereby making\nprice spikes in PX and ISO energy markets more likely.\n7\n         On December 11, 1998, the ISO filed two other tariff changes relevant to ancillary services market\nredesign: the allocation of responsibility for ancillary services based on metered demand, rather than\nscheduled demand, and the withholding of payment for uninstructed deviations from ancillary service\ncapacity. The first of these changes, billing A/S based on metered demand was implemented on August 17,\n1999. The second change, the so-called “no-pay” provision, will most likely be implemented in February\n2000.\n                             MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 22 of 148\n" Automation of Dispatch Instructions for Real-Time Energy\n         The ISO described how it would automate the communication of dispatch\ninstructions to resources supplying imbalance energy in order to allow the ISO to make\nbetter use of those resources, thereby reducing its requirements for regulation service.\n(No changes to the ISO's tariff or protocols were required for this element of the redesign\npackage.)\n                   4.       Separate Pricing of Regulation Up and Regulation Down\n         The ISO proposed to introduce separate pricing for the upward and downward\ncomponents of regulation service in attempt to increase the efficiency of the regulation\nmarket.\n                   5.       Reduced Transaction Costs for Loads Participating in A/S Markets\n         The ISO proposed to develop an agreement to facilitate the participation of\ndispatchable loads in ancillary service markets. The Participating Load Agreement\n(PLA) is the load counterpart of the Participating Generator Agreement (PGA). It is a\npro forma contract to standardize load participation in the non-spin and replacement\nmarkets. (No changes to the ISO Tariff or Protocols or to ISO software were required for\nthis element of the redesign package.)\n                   6.       Trading of Ancillary Services\n         The ISO proposed certain modifications to permit Scheduling Coordinators (SCs)\nto engage in trades of ancillary services, with the intention of providing alternative means\nfor SCs to fulfill their ancillary-service obligations.8\n         In its May 26 Order, the Commission approved these six ISO’s market redesign\nproposals.\n         D.        Status of August MSC Report Recommendations\n         The Commission and the ISO have carried out, or are in the process of\nimplementing in whole or part, most of the Committee’s recommendations, as more fully\ndescribed below. However, since most of these new market design features were not\nimplemented until August 17, 1999, there is limited market experience with which to\ngauge the effectiveness of these changes. Given this limited experience, we feel it would\nbe premature to try to assess the impact these reforms have had on the overall\nperformance of the ISO markets.\n8\n         The March 1 filing also [25] "                    1.        “Rational Buyer” Protocols\n          The ISO’s “Rational Buyer” Protocols (filed March 1, 1999 and implemented\nAugust 17, 1999) includes several features of the MSC’s rational buyer recommendation.\nWe believe that the ISO’s implementation of “Rational Buyer” represent a significant and\npositive step towards improving the performance of the ISO’s ancillary services markets.\nFundamentally, improved flexibility in the ISO’s procurement practices will tend to\nundermine any market power that suppliers of ancillary services might otherwise enjoy.\nAs mentioned in our March 25th report, there are several important features of the MSC’s\nrecommendations that were not adopted.\n          The ISO’s Rational Buyer Protocol employs different settlement procedures than\nwere recommended by the MSC in our August 1998 report. Under the ISO’s proposed\nprotocol, although the ISO indeed purchases the Rational Buyer Quantities of each\nancillary service, those ultimately paying for ancillary services, and those providing their\nown ancillary services, must only pay for or self-provide a quantity for each service equal\nto the ISO’s initial ancillary services requirements (i.e., prior to any rational-buyer\nadjustments). For example, if the ISO’s initial requirement for regulation reserve is 3% of\nthe ISO’s load, but the ISO’s Rational Buyer Protocol results in purchasing regulation\nreserve amounting to 5% of the ISO’s load, then both demanders and self-providers must\npurchase or provide regulation amounting to 3% of their load. This settlement procedure\ntends to create a subsidy to self-providers of ancillary services, because the total amount\nthe ISO pays to providers of ancillary services under this scheme will generally be less\nthan the total amount collected from purchasers of ancillary services. As a result, self-\nproviders of ancillary services will have diminished incentives to make adjustments that\nwould cause the rational-buyer prices to satisfy the inequalities that higher-quality\nancillary services sell for higher prices, which was one of the major goals of adopting a\nrational buyer protocol to begin with.\n          As discussed in our March 25th report, we recognize that both equity and\nefficiency concerns are implicated in the settlements procedure that is adopted in\nconjunction with the ISO’s Rational Buyer Protocol. We would prefer to see a settlement\nmethod that does not introduce subsidies into the system, and that conveys more accurate\nprice signals to users and self-providers of ancillary services. As a general rule, the\nCommittee is disinclined to give great weight to equity arguments based on so-called\nentitlements resulting from flaws in the market design that the ISO is in the process of\nfixing, especially if such equity considerations impede the efficient operation of the\nISO’s markets.\n                    2.        RMR Contracts\n          The Committee, and particularly its Chairman, Frank Wolak, have given\nsignificant attention to RMR issues since the August 1998 MSC Report.9 The MSC\n9\n  In December of 1998, an analysis of the impact of RMR contracts on the California energy market was\nprepared by Frank Wolak and James Bushnell for the Market Surveillance Committee. This report also contained a detailed set of recommendations for revision of the RMR Contracts.\n                               MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 24 of 148\n" [26] "strongly recommended that the ISO revise RMR protocols and contracts so that these\ncontracts no longer provide incentives for generating units with RMR contracts to bid and\nschedule less aggressively into the day-ahead energy market and ancillary services\nmarkets. The MSC believes that market incentives are much improved under the new\nRMR contract settlement, implemented June 1, 1999. However, one aspect of the RMR\ncontract reforms recommended by the MSC in its March 25, 1999 report has yet to be\nimplemented. This concerns the timing of RMR calls relative to the operation of the day-\nahead energy market and the corresponding day-ahead scheduling requirements for units\ncalled to provide RMR energy.\n        Currently, RMR calls are made following the close of the day-ahead energy\nmarket. Under the scheme recommended by the MSC in its March report, RMR calls\nwould be made before day-ahead energy schedules are submitted to the ISO. Generators\nreceiving these RMR calls would have the option to elect to receive their RMR variable\npayment rate or a market determined price for supplying the RMR quantity of energy\nfrom that unit. Under this scheme, each RMR unit owner would know the amount of\nenergy that must be provided from that unit during each hour of the following day for\nlocal grid reliability reasons before it bids into the PX day-ahead energy market or\nsubmits balanced day-ahead energy schedules to the ISO. Under the MSC’s\nrecommended scheme, after the ISO determines its RMR energy requirements, all\ngeneration owners with RMR units must submit a balanced day-ahead energy schedule to\nthe ISO which has each RMR unit that it owns supplying at least the quantity of RMR\nenergy the ISO requires from that unit.\n        Even though the major RMR reforms were implemented effective June 1, 1999, a\ncomplete assessment of these reforms is constrained by data availability. The ISO’s\nsettlement data on actual metered unit-level electricity production and take-out-point\nelectricity consumption on an hourly basis is currently only available through the last\nweek of July 1999. This information is an essential input to a formal assessment of the\nperformance of the California energy market. Nevertheless, we perform analysis of the\nCalifornia energy market up through the date that we currently have data available.\n               3.      Market-Based Rates.\n        The Commission has eliminated cost-based rates for ancillary services provided\nby all market participants, and authorized market-based rates for those services. This\nstep is a prerequisite to workably competitive ancillary services markets. However, as\nthe Committee noted in its August 1998 report, the ownership and control of the PG&E\nhydro units requires particular attention. The MSC recommends that the hydro systems\nbe divested on a watershed-by-watershed basis to a buyer unaffiliated with PG&E or\nother major generation owners in Northern California.\n               4.      Damage Control Price-Cap\n        The Commission on May 26, 1999 ordered to remove the ISO’s authority to\nimpose purchase price caps for ancillary services and imbalance energy as of November\n [27] "15, 1999. Under it’s existing authority, the ISO on October 1, 1999 increased the\npurchase price caps for ancillary services and imbalance energy from $250/MW to\n$750/MW. As discussed more fully below, the Committee strongly recommends that the\nISO retain the authority to set and change these caps, that the $750 cap be retained\nthrough the summer of 2000, and that caps thereafter be raised to the $2,500 level as soon\nas market conditions permit.\n                5.      Statewide Auction for Ancillary Services\n        The ISO has made a concerted effort over the past year to procure ancillary\nservices on a Statewide basis whenever possible. Rather than automatically splitting the\nancillary service market whenever there are significant south to north transmission\nconstraints, the ISO also considers the locational distribution of ancillary service\nresources and will run a statewide auction if it results in a acceptable combination of\nnorthern and southern resources. During the spring and summer of 1999, there have only\nbeen a few occasions where the ISO has had to procure ancillary services separately for\nnorthern and southern California. However, during the fall season, limited ancillary\nservice supplies (i.e. less hydro) and frequent south to north congestion within California\noften necessitate regional procurement. As was evident in northern California during the\nfirst week of October 1999, market power increases significantly when the market is split\non a zonal basis.\n                6.      ISO Procurement Practices\n        Two major issues that remain unresolved from the August 1998 MSC report are\nthe ISO’s procedures for procuring regulation reserve and the transparency of the ISO’s\nprocess for dispatching reserve capacity from the real-time energy bid stack. The ISO has\nimplemented several market design changes to address both of these issues. However, it\nappears that the philosophy underlying the California market design, which does not\nrequire generators to follow their net day-ahead and hour-ahead energy schedules in real\ntime, makes it difficult fully to solve these problems. This additional freedom given to\ngenerators creates greater uncertainty for the ISO about how it will meet real-time\ndemand with generation, relative to a system where energy schedules are firm physical\ncommitments to supply energy and generators face strong financial penalties for\ndeviations from these energy schedules. In addition, as discussed in our March 25th\nreport, differences in how the ISO settles “instructed” versus “uninstructed” deviations\nfrom forward energy schedules has created some undesirable, from a market efficiency\nperspective, opportunities for generators. The ISO manages this increased uncertainty by\npurchasing more regulation capacity than was used in the pre-ISO regime. This increased\nregulation capacity allows the ISO to respond instantaneously to any local energy needs\ndue to deviations by non-regulating generators from their net day-ahead and hour-ahead\nenergy schedules. However, in recent months, the ISO has been able to significantly\nreduce regulation requirements by placing a greater reliance on the real-time energy bid\nstack for managing energy imbalances, particularly during critical ramping periods.\n        In an effort to create a financial penalty for schedule deviations, the ISO, as part\nof the ISO’s Amendment 14 ancillary service market reforms, adopted a new procedure\nfor determining replacement reserve requirements and for allocating the costs of\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 26 of 148\n" [28] "replacement reserve to SCs. Under this new procedure, in addition to the replacement\nreserve procured for other reliability purposes, there are additional replacement reserves\nrequirements that are based on the difference between the ISO’s load forecast and total\nscheduled energy with some additional adjustments for expected supplemental energy\nbids and RMR dispatch. Replacement capacity is charged to both loads and generation in\nproportion to the amount that they under-schedule in the day-ahead and hour-ahead\nmarkets. It is worth noting that this proposal will increase the costs to loads and\ngenerators from shifting their demands and supplies between the day-ahead, hour-ahead\nand real-time markets. This scheme therefore increases the cost to loads of bidding a\nprice-responsive demand into the PX and therefore substituting into the hour-ahead and\nreal-time markets if generators bid too high in the PX. The result of this implicit tax on\nload shifting may be to increase prices in both the PX and real-time energy markets.\n        As discussed in our March 25th report, another remedy is to require that\nsupplemental energy bids into the real-time energy market be submitted further in\nadvance of the actual hour they may be asked to provide energy, and to impose penalties\non generators who remove these bids in advance of the market (similar to those that are\nimposed on energy bids from winning ancillary services capacity). This remedy would\nallow the ISO to reduce its purchases of all ancillary services because the BEEP stack\ncould then be treated in much the same way as reserve capacity coming through one of\nthe ancillary services markets. Making real-time energy bids a genuine commitment for\nan extended period of time would also allow the ISO to end its current practice of\nskipping over the energy bids of units providing spin and non-spin reserve capacity.\n        Because the current market design often creates incentives for generators not to\nfollow the sum of day-ahead and hour-ahead energy schedules or 10-minute instructed\ndeviations, to some extent increased procurement of regulation may simply be one of the\ninevitable costs associated with the current market design. Because price signals are the\nonly available tool to discipline deviations by generators, these signals must be\nparticularly strong and accurate. It is impossible to use an hourly price to discipline\ndeviations within the hour that are financially beneficial to the generator. Ideally, we\nwould like prices and quantities to clear second-by-second and generators to pay for\nimbalances relative to schedules at this second-by-second price.           Clearly, such a\nsettlement scheme is beyond the range of technological feasibility. Consequently, over-\nprocurement of regulation may be a necessary to correct this mismatch between the time\nintervals over which instructed deviations are paid versus uninstructed deviations.\n3.
