[29] "• During April through May of 1998, because most market participants were\n  constrained by cost-based caps for ancillary services there was very little capacity bid\n  into the ISO’s ancillary service markets. This was particularly true for the regulation\n  market which market participants perceived as a zero-net energy market, which meant\n  that they did not expect to earn much in the way of net energy payments from\n  providing regulation capacity. For all reserve services, if the capacity is called to\n  provide energy it receives the real-time price for any net energy provided. Given the\n  lack of regulation capacity being provided through the market, the ISO called on\n  RMR units to provide additional regulation. Most of the costs shown for ancillary\n  services during the ISO’s first two months of operation are payments to RMR units.\n  During the same two months in 1999, the ISO did not need to dispatch any RMR\n  units to provide ancillary services.\n• On May 21, 1998, in an effort to increase supply to the regulation market, the ISO\n  implemented a Regulation Energy Payment Adjustment (REPA). Under REPA\n  market participants received the greater of $20 or the ISO ex-post hourly imbalance\n  energy price for each MW of regulation capacity awarded. For June, 1998, RMR and\n  REPA payments constituted roughly 80% of the total monthly cost of ancillary\n  services and for July through September 1998, REPA was so effective in attracting\n  bids to the regulation market there was very little need to dispatch RMR for\n  regulation. During July through September 1998, REPA constituted roughly 50% of\n  the total monthly cost of ancillary services. On October 28, 1998, FERC approved\n  market-based rates for all providers of A/S and the REPA payment was eliminated\n  one month later. Though REPA was successful in attracting more regulation capacity\n  to the market, in retrospect, it may have been an excessive enticement during the peak\n  summer season when prices in the ISO’s imbalance market were often quite high.\n• During July through August 1998, because of transmission constraints between\n  northern and southern California, the ISO frequently ran two separate markets for\n  ancillary services, one for northern California and one for southern California. This\n  practice generally resulted in higher prices in the southern region and a greater\n  frequency of price spikes. During the same two months in 1999, the ISO rarely ran\n  two separate markets.\n• Due to software limitations, during the first five months of operation, the ISO was\n  unable to accept bids for Spinning, Non-spinning, and replacement reserves from\n  outside its control area. This changed on August 6, 1998 when the ISO began\n  accepting import bids for these three services but for reliability reasons, limited\n  spinning and non-spinning imports to 25% of the ISO’s total requirements for these\n  services. On June 1, 1999, this limit was increased to 50%.\n• Ancillary service requirements decreased significantly in 1999.\n• Loads were lower during the summer of 1999 freeing up more capacity for the\n  ancillary services markets.\n                       MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 28 of 148\n" [30] "    In April 1999, in an effort to develop a more robust hour-ahead ancillary services\nmarket, the ISO began shifting day-ahead ancillary service requirements to the hour-\nahead market. Initially, 3-5% of the day-ahead requirements were shifted to the hour-\nahead market and by mid May, this was increased to about 10%. In addition to shifting a\ncertain fixed percentage of the market requirements to the hour-ahead market, the ISO\nalso shifted additional amounts to avoid large price spikes in the day-ahead market and\nbid insufficiency. This practice reduced the overall costs of ancillary services.\n [31] "averaged approximately $5/MWh. In contrast, for July of 1999, average hourly costs\naveraged approximately $2.40/MWh of system load and never exceeded $12/MWh of\nsystem load. August 1999 cost savings are even more dramatic. In August of 1998, the\naverage hour cost of ancillary services was $6/MWh of system load compared to\n$2/MWh for August 1999. Figure 2 also shows average ancillary service costs expressed\nas a percentage of the estimated value of ISO actual system loads. ISO actual system\nloads were valued at the PX day-ahead unconstrained market-clearing price. In May\n1998, ancillary service costs was equal to roughly 35% of the estimated value of ISO\nsystem loads, but these costs declined sharply in subsequent months. During July\nthrough August 1998, ancillary service costs were approximately 16% of total energy\ncosts. During the same period for 1999, ancillary service costs were only 6% of total\nenergy costs.\n        The negative minimum hourly cost shown for May 1999 was the result of several\nsignificant negative price spikes in the regulation market. On May 16, 1999 in hour 4\nand 5, the market-clearing price for regulation was negative $3,350.28/MW. These\nnegative spikes were caused by market participants submitting large negative bids for\nupward regulation with the apparent belief that other bids for downward regulation would\nset the market-clearing price during these hours. With this bidding strategy, market\nparticipants can gain large market shares for upward regulation while receiving a positive\nprice set by high demands for downward regulation. In these particular hours, this\nstrategy backfired as market participants collectively bid enough capacity at negative bid\nprices to cover demand for both upward and downward regulation. Effective August 18,\n1999 the ISO set separate prices for Regulation Up and Regulation Down.\n [32] "        As mentioned above, during the summer months of 1998, price spikes occurred\nquite frequently in the A/S markets and were one of the main reasons for the high cost of\nancillary services during this period. As can be seen in Figure 3, the $250/MW cap on\nancillary service capacity was frequently hit in July through August of 1998. In August\nof 1998, the price cap was hit in more than 10% of the peak hours for spinning, non-\nspinning, and replacement reserve markets, whereas in August of 1999 the $250/MW cap\nwas hit less than 2% of the time for these same markets.\n                      B.           Ancillary Service Quantities\n        One of the main factors contributing to lower ancillary service costs is that the\nISO has made a concerted effort to lower overall requirements for ancillary services.\nFigures 4 and 5 show average hourly ancillary service requirements for August 1998 and\nAugust 1999, respectively. For August 1999, average hourly ancillary services\nrequirements declined from 1998 levels. Requirements were particularly reduced during\noff-peak hours. The services having the greatest reduction in requirements were\nregulation and replacement reserve. Figures 4 and 5 also plot that average hourly system\nloads to illustrate the pattern of loads throughout the day that are associated with these\nancillary services quantities.\n Specifically, is the ISO getting by with less ancillary\nservices during the summer of 1999 relative to the summer of 1999 only because of lower\nISO load during the summer of 1999? To investigate this hypothesis more formally we\nemploy linear regression techniques. This model relates the level of market-wide\nancillary services requirements for each service as of the end of the hour-ahead market to\nthe level of total ISO load as well as various dummy variables for each month from June\n1998 to August 1999. Because of the changes in ancillary services procurement policies\nthat resulted from the implementation of the Rational Buyer Protocol, we end our August\nsample at August 17, the day before Rational Buyer was implemented. This analysis will\nalso allow us to separate the impacts of better procurement practices from the old\nancillary services procurement protocols from the Rational Buyer procedure as more\nmarket data under the Rational Buyer protocol becomes available.\n                                   Define the following variables:\nREQ(i,j) = Hour-ahead ancillary services requirement for service i in hour j\nISOLOAD(j) = Total ISO load in hour j\nDAY(k,j) = An indicator variable that equals 1 if hour j is in day of week k=2,...,7\nHOUR(h,j) = An indicator variable that equals 1 if hour j is the hour of the day h=2,...,24\n                                                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 33 of 148\n" [35] "MONTH(m,j) = An indicator variable that equals 1 if hour j is in month of year\n        m = 2 ,...,12\nJUNE99(j) = An indicator variable that equals 1 if hour j is in June of 1999\nJULY99(j) = An indicator variable that equals 1 if hour j is in July of 1999\nAUG99(j) = An indicator variable that equals 1 if hour j is in August of 1999\nFor all hours from June 1, 1998 to August 17, 1999 and for each ancillary service, i, we\nregress REQ(i,j) on a constant term, a sixth order polynomial in ISOLOAD(j) (to control\nfor a potentially highly nonlinear impact of the total ISO load on the demand for that\nancillary service), the complete set of DAY, HOUR, MONTH indicator variables given\nabove and the three indicator variables, JUNE99, JULY99 and AUG99. [36] "          C.       Ancillary Service Prices\n          Prices in the day-ahead ancillary service market were on average much lower\ncompared to the same period last year and there were significantly fewer price spikes.\nFigures 8 and 9 show the total number of price spikes in excess of $200/MW and the\naverage hourly price for day-ahead regulation capacity for August 1998 and August\n1999, respectively. In August 1998, price spikes in the day-ahead regulation market were\nfairly prevalent during two distinct periods of the day, in the morning hours when\ndemand for downward regulation was high relative to supply and in the late evening\nhours when demand for upward regulation was high relative to supply. These demand\npatterns reflect the ISO’s use of regulation capacity to provide net energy counter to load\ngrowth during the hour. In order to meet the peak morning loads, imports on the interties\nand in-state generation begin ramping up several hours in advance. This causes an over-\ngeneration condition, which the ISO mitigates by backing down those units that provide\ndownward regulation. Similarly, in the evening hours, generation and imports on the\ninterties start ramping down several hours prior to the sharp drop in load that occurs in\nthe last few hours of the day. For these hours, an under-generation condition exists,\nwhich the ISO mitigates by ramping up the units providing upward regulation.\n          In August 1998, there were no separate requirements for upward and downward\nregulation. These two services were bought as a single product. REPA was also still in\neffect during this period. Average hourly regulation prices for this month are highly\ncorrelated with the frequency of price spikes and were highest during the evening ramp\ndown hours averaging a high of $98.50/MW in hour 22. Regulation prices were much\nmore moderate in August 1999 both in terms of the number of price spikes and the\naverage hourly price.\n          There were a number of important changes in the regulation market during this\nmonth compared to last year:\n     •    REPA was no longer in effect\n     •    For the first part of August (August 1-17), upward and downward regulation were\n          being procured separately but settled at a single price equal to the maximum of\n          the upward and downward market clearing prices10,\n     •    During the last part of August (August 18-31) upward and downward regulation\n          were settled at separate market clearing prices.\n     •    The ISO adopted a new practice of shifting some day-ahead requirements to the\n          hour-ahead market if doing so would avoid a significant price spike so long as the\n          ISO was confident that ample supplies would be available in the hour-ahead\n          market.\n     •    The ISO implemented a new algorithm for determining regulation requirements\n          that placed greater reliance on the imbalance market to follow load. This new\n10\n   At that time, software limitations prevented the ISO from settling upward and downward regulation using\nseparate prices. New software was implemented on August 18, 1999 to correct this.\n                             MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 35 of 148\n"                                             Operating Hour\n        Although market price performance in the day-ahead ancillary service markets\nimproved significantly in 1999, it is important to note that summer load conditions were\nunusually low in 1999. During July through August 1998, there were 154 hours when\nISO actual system loads exceeded 38,000 MW versus 76 hours for July through August\n1999. Figures 16 to 23 provide some insight into how the ancillary service markets\nperformed under different load conditions and relative to the PX day-ahead and ISO real-\ntime energy markets. These Figures show the average prices for day-ahead ancillary\nservices, the average day-ahead unconstrained PX energy price, and the average ISO real-\ntime energy price under different load conditions for two distinct periods July to August\n1998 and July to August 1999. In a well-functioning ancillary services market, one\nwould not expect the market price of ancillary service capacity to exceed the market price\nof energy. These Figures indicate that this expectation was often violated in 1998, under\na variety of load conditions, but much less so in 1999 and generally only under high load\nconditions. These results are encouraging in that they demonstrate there is a stronger\npositive correlation between ancillary service prices, load conditions, and energy prices.\nHowever, the results also demonstrate that there still remains a tendency for prices in all\nmarkets to approach the price cap under high load conditions.\n        Figure 16 shows how regulation prices for July-August, 1998 compared to system\nloads and energy prices. Regulation prices for this month are heavily influenced by the\nRegulation Energy Payment Adjustment (REPA). Recall that during this period in\naddition to the regulation market-clearing price, participants in the regulation market also\nreceived a REPA payment equal to the greater of $20/MW or the ISO real-time price.\nThis Figure demonstrates that in hours when loads were under 31,000 MW, the\nregulation price on average exceeded both the ISO real-time energy price and the PX\nday-ahead energy price. When one factors in REPA, the effective regulation price\n(Regulation MCP + REPA payment) exceeds energy prices in almost all hours except for\n                                              MSC For this period, REPA was no longer in\neffect and for most of the month (August 1-17), a single price was paid for both upward\nand downward regulation. The ISO began paying separate prices for downward and\nupward regulation on August 18, 1999. For hours where loads were in the range of\n18,000-27,000 MW, upward regulation prices were at or near the ISO and PX energy\nprices. For hours where loads ranged from 28,000 to 38,000 MW, upward regulation\nprices were generally lower than the ISO and PX energy prices. For hours were loads\nexceeded 38,000 MW average regulation prices were typically above the PX day-ahead\nenergy price but generally lower than the ISO real-time price. One explanation for these\nresults is that unit owners supplying regulation capacity must be compensated for the\nadditional wear and tear on their units caused by responding to dispatch signals in real-\ntime under automatic generation control (AGC). In addition, as noted above, the ISO\nuses regulation capacity to supply net energy counter to the direction of growth in system\nload during the hour. Units supplying upward regulation often must buy back energy in\nthe real-time market at high prices, and those supplying downward regulation must often\nsupply net energy during periods of very low prices.\n                                      MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 41 of 148\n" Price                                     Average PX Price\n        We now investigate the extent to which lower average hourly total ISO loads\nduring the summer of 1999 versus the summer of 1998 led to lower ancillary services\nprices across the two summers. We perform a similar regression analysis to the one\ndescribed above for the market requirement for each day-ahead ancillary service price in\neach congestion zone. Define the following two additional variables:\nPAS(c,i,j) = the market-clearing day-ahead price ancillary services i, for congestion zone\n       c, during hour j\nCONG(j) = an indicator variable that equals one if the ISO procures ancillary services on\n     a zonal basis during hour j.\nFor each congestion zone and each hour from June 1, 1998 to August 17, 1999, we\nregress PAS(c,i,j) on a constant term, a sixth order polynomial in ISOLOAD(j), a\ncomplete set of DAY, HOUR, MONTH indicator variables, the indicator variable\nCONG(j), and the three indicator variables, JUNE99, JULY99 and AUG99. The\nregression coefficient on JUNE99 gives the average difference in day-ahead ancillary\nservices prices in June 1999 versus June 1998, controlling for differences in the level of\ntotal ISO load across the two months. A similar interpretation holds for the coefficients\non JULY99 and AUG99.\n        Table 1 gives the point estimates and standard errors for the coefficients\nassociated with the indicator variables JUNE99, JULY99, and AUG99 for each of the\nancillary services. This table is consistent with the view that the reduction in average\nancillary services prices from the summer of 1998 to the summer of 1999 cannot be\nsolely attributed to the lower average hourly ISO loads during the summer of 1999. The\ndifference in average day-ahead prices for each ancillary service between 1999 and the\nsame month in 1998 are for the most part negative and very large relative to their\n                                Standard Errors in Parentheses\nThe results in Tables 1-3 taken together provide evidence that the ISO’s ancillary\nservices markets are operating more efficiently this summer than last summer for the\nvalues of hourly total ISO load that occurred during the summer of 1999. However, it is\nimportant to emphasis that that these results tell us less about how well the ISO’s\nancillary services markets would operate this summer if load conditions had been as high\nas they were last summer.\n        D.      Ancillary Service Bid Price and Market Price Inequalities\n        We now consider a puzzling outcome of the ancillary services market noted in\nboth the August 1998 and April 1999 MSC reports that continues to occur. The market-\nclearing price for an inferior product in terms of its technical specifications is greater than\nthe market-clearing price of a superior product in terms of its technical specifications.\nOne such example would be regulation selling for less than replacement. Regulation\nrequires that the generation unit have AGC installed. Any generation unit that can\nprovide regulation can certainly provide replacement, but opposite is not the case.\n        Table 4 shows, by month and by congestion region, the percent of times an\ninferior energy product cleared at a higher price than a superior energy product. However, the frequency in which the price of an\nancillary service exceeded either the PX day-ahead energy price or ISO real-time energy\nprice declined significantly after August 1998. August 1999 is separated into two periods\nas rational buyer was implemented on August 18, 1999. Though the frequency of price\ninversions increased under rational buyer, loads were much higher during the last week of\nAugust. So, it may not be appropriate to attribute this change to rational buyer. This\nresult illustrates the necessity of collecting more data on the market performance under\nthe Rational Buyer before an assessment of its full impacts on the ISO’s operations can\nbe provided.\n [49] "        Table 5 shows the frequency (the fraction of generation unit-level bids) in which\ninvestor-owned utilities (IOUs) and new generator owners (NGO) submitted ancillary\nservice bids that violated the bid value conventions, that the bid price for regulation\nshould exceed that for spin, which should exceed that for non-spin, which should exceed\nthat for replacement. Though this occurred fairly infrequently from June 1998 to March\n1999 (averaging about 6% for both IOUs and NGOs), it increased significantly for NGOs\nbeginning in April 1999. This change is due to the bidding behavior of one particular\nNGO.\n                           E.                                         Avg Bid Sufficiency\n        Figures 28-31 show a break down of the average quantity of day-ahead ancillary\nservice bids by various bid price categories and average ancillary service requirements\nfor peak hours. These Figures demonstrate that after the ISO’s first four months of\noperation, there was, on average, an ample supply of bids relative to demand. These\nFigures also demonstrate that in recent months there has been a large share of bids in\nexcess of $25/MW compared to the same months in 1998. In 1999, new generator owners are providing a\nlarger share of ancillary service bids.\n                                                                                                    Figure 28\n [59] "        Figures 43 and 44 show average energy prices by load category and by the\npercent of actual load not scheduled in the forward energy markets for July through\nAugust 1998 and July through August 1999, respectively. In 1998, in hours with higher\nsystem loads, a higher percentage of these loads went unscheduled in the forward market\n(Figure 43). When loads exceeded 40,000 MW, over 6% of the actual system load went\nunscheduled. This explains why the real-time price is significantly higher than the PX\nprice during periods of high loads. This pattern of load under-scheduling during periods\nof high loads is mainly the result of IOUs hedging the risk of being exposed to a high\nprice in the PX market. By submitting price responsive demand bids to the PX market,\nIOUs are able to hedge against having to pay a high price for their entire load,\nparticularly when they do not own generation that they can bid into the PX. Even though\nload that does not clear the PX market ends up being exposed to a high price in the real-\ntime market, because it is only a small portion of the IOU’s total load, they are relatively\nbetter off.\n        Interestingly, in 1999, the pattern of load under-scheduling is much more\npronounced relative to the pattern in 1998 (Figure 44). A likely explanation for this is\nthat the IOUs own significantly less generation than they did in 1998. The generation\nthat they previously bid into the PX to serve their load is now in the hands of new owners\noperating under very different financial incentives. With less low bid-price energy\navailable in the PX, more load gets shifted to the real-time market. Note, that in high\nload periods, PX prices are generally higher that they were in 1998-reflecting the fact that\ngeneration is bidding a steeper aggregate supply curve into the PX market.\n                                                                            Figure 43\n                                                 Average Energy Prices and Percent of Actual S ystem Load Unscheduled\n                                                                          (July-August 1998)\n                                   15%                                                                                            300\n                                   13%\n                                                                                                                                  250\n                                                   % of Actual System Load not Scheduled\n                                   11%\n       A vg. [61] "          G.              Recent Market Experience Under $750 Price Cap\n        The ISO’s recent experience under a new price cap of $750/MW (implemented\nOctober 1, 1999) shows that situations can arise where market participants can exercise\nmarket power and will do so to the full extent of the price cap. On October 1, 1999), the\nprimary transmission path between southern and northern California (Path 15) was de-\nrated to 900MW in the south to north direction for most hours of the day causing south to\nnorth congestion. In addition, the primary transmission path between the northwest and\nnorthern California, the California-Oregon Intertie (COI), was congested in the north to\nsouth direction. This simultaneous congestion situation meant that to alleviate congestion\non Path 15, the ISO was limited to incremental adjustment bids in northern California\n(NP15). With only a limited supply of incremental adjustment bids in northern\nCalifornia, very high adjustment bids were used and the day-ahead congestion prices\nneared $700/MWh in four hours of the day (Figure 46).\n                                                                      Figure 46\n                                    Path 15 Day Ahead South to North Total Transfer Limits and Initial [64] "the ISO control area and across congestion zones. Historically market power in the\nCalifornia has been exercised to greatest extent during periods of high total ISO load.\n4.       Measuring Market Power in the California Wholesale Electricity\n         Market\n         Borenstein, Bushnell and Wolak (1999) analyze the extent of market power\nexercised in the California energy market by comparing the market-clearing price of\nwholesale energy, in this case the unconstrained PX price, to the market-clearing price\nthat would arise in a fully competitive electricity market. The competitive benchmark\nprice assumes that all generators behave as if they were unable to influence the market-\nclearing price through their bidding behavior. In this case, the market-clearing price each\nhour would equal the cost of producing an additional unit of output beyond the quantity\nof actual total ISO generation during that hour.\n         The Borenstein, Bushnell and Wolak (1999) analysis utilizes hourly metered data\non electricity produced from each generating unit in California and electricity flowing\nover each intertie into the ISO control area. In the process of constructing the\ncounterfactual competitive market price the authors make several conservative\nassumptions against finding market power. In particular, they assume that no market\npower is being exercised by in-state hydroelectric facilities in their bidding and dispatch\ndecision and by must-take facilities in their dispatch decisions. The authors also account\nfor the fact that less imports should flow into the ISO control area in response to lower\nenergy prices in California. This implies that in-state facilities would be required to\nproduce additional energy to make up the imbalance created. They make use of\nadjustment bids submitted across all interties into the ISO control area on a day-ahead\nbasis to construct the new equilibrium level of imports into the state as result competitive\npricing in California. The authors also account for weekly variation in the price of fossil\nfuels to the various in-state fossil facilities in determining the production cost for each\ngenerating unit. Using data from the National Electricity Reliability Council (NERC) on\nforced outage rates for all instate fossil facilities, the authors use Monte Carlo methods to\nintegrate out with respect to the joint outage distribution of all instate fossil facilities to\ncompute the expected fully competitive market price for each hour of the day during their\nsample period. The authors also acknowledge that some generating capacity is not\navailable to provide energy in real-time should system demand rise because it will\ncontinue to be used as system reserve. The authors assume that the amount of capacity\nprocured to provide upward regulation during each hour represents capacity that is\ndedicated to the provision of this reserve and is therefore unable to provide additional\nenergy should the need arise. As a consequence, the authors add this quantity of reserve\ncapacity to total ISO load in determining the appropriate total system demand necessary\nto compute the expected competitive price of electricity each hour.11\n11\n   Copies of the report “Measuring Market Power in California’s Restructured Wholesale Electricity\nMarket,” by Severin Borenstein, James Bushnell and Frank Wolak, which explains this methodology in\ndetail can be obtained from http://www.ucei.berkeley.edu/ucei/ or http://www.stanford.edu/~wolak.\n                            MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 63 of [65] "        For the period June 1998 to November 1998, these authors estimate that the actual\ntotal costs purchasing electricity in the California market was 29% above the expected\ntotal costs that would have resulted from fully competitive pricing in the California\nmarket. This calculation does not attempt to quantify the extent of market power\nexercised in the ISO’s ancillary services market. However, the opportunity cost of\nselling capacity in the ISO’s ancillary services markets is the foregone profits the unit\nowner could have earned in the PX and ISO wholesale energy markets. Therefore, it is\nreasonable to expect that similar amounts of market power exist in these markets as well\nduring the same time period.\n        We hoped to report the results of this analysis for the period June 1999 to\nSeptember 1999 to compare to the 1998 numbers presented in Borenstein, Bushnell and\nWolak (1999). Because complete ISO settlement data, a vital input to this analysis, is\nonly available as of July 26, 1999, this was not possible. Using the available settlement\ndata, we performed this analysis for the months of December 1998 to July 26, 1999. The\nonly difference between the methodology followed in our analysis versus the one in\nBorenstein, Bushnell and Wolak (1999) is that we used $2.5/MBTU as the price of\nnatural gas for all plant locations and hours during our sample period. This was\nnecessitated by our current lack of a complete time series on natural gas prices in\nCalifornia for the sample period.\n        We compute the average hourly percentage increase in the cost of purchasing\nelectricity from the California wholesale electricity market during each month from\nDecember 1998 to July 26, 1999 relative to the pure competitive market benchmark.\nSimilar to what Borenstein, Bushnell and Wolak (1999) found for the months of October\n1998 and November 1998, the total wholesale energy cost increase above the competitive\nbenchmark for the period December 1998 to June 1998 was relatively small. It is\nimportant to remember that during these months the daily peak total ISO is significantly\nless than the daily peak in July, August and September. In addition, during the spring of\n1999 hydroelectric energy was in plentiful supply so that these unit owners were often\nfaced with the choice of spilling water or generating energy with it.\n        For the month of July 1999, first month in 1999 with a sustained period of high\ntotal ISO loads, conditions in the wholesale energy market more closely resembled those\nduring summer of 1998 rather than conditions during the winter and spring of 1999.\nAccording to our calculations, the total wholesale energy costs, excluding energy\nproduced under must-take arrangements, were 20% above those that would have resulted\nfrom the pure competitive market benchmark for the period July 1 to July 26, 1999.\nThese results illustrate that although the wholesale energy market appears to be operating\nmore efficiently in 1999 versus 1998, during periods of high total ISO load there appears\nto be a significant amount of market power exercised in the California wholesale\nelectricity market. The comparable figure for July 1998 was approximately 39%, so that\nalthough a significant amount of market power was exercised this July it is considerably\nless than the amount exercised last summer during same month. Once ISO settlement\ndata for the months of August, September and October is available, the Borenstein,\nBushnell and Wolak (1999) analysis can be repeated for entire summer of 1999. [67] "below, several important structural flaws in the California market design remain, which\nexplains why this market power remains. We then provide various recommendations for\ncorrecting these deficiencies in the market design.\n5.      Remaining Market Design Flaws and Recommendations for\n        Correcting Them\n        The ISO management and Board have worked extremely hard over the past year\nimplementing many changes in the market design that should: (1) increase the efficiency\nof the California electricity market, (2) improve the reliability of the California\ntransmission grid, and (3) lead to a sufficient quantity of new generating capacity in\nCalifornia to meet its growing electricity demand. However, several important market\ndesign issues remain unresolved from previous MSC Reports. We continue to believe\nthat they must be satisfactorily addressed before the California electricity market can\nbecome workably competitive. These issues are: (1) the timing of calls for reliability\nmust-run (RMR) units and dispatch obligations under the new RMR contracts, and (2)\neliminating the restrictions on the ability of demand to respond to high hourly wholesale\nenergy and ancillary services prices.\n        Three issues have grown in importance since the April 1999 MSC Report. They\nare: (1) the impact of market participant non-compliance with ISO dispatch instructions\nor the technical standards necessary to participate in the ISO’s energy and ancillary\nservices market on the prices in these markets and reliability of the ISO transmission\ngrid, (2) the perverse incentives for generation unit scheduling and dispatch caused by the\nISO’s intra-zonal congestion management protocols, and (3) integrating the operation of\nthe firm transmission rights (FTR) market with the ISO’s congestion management\nprotocols. The ISO management is aware of these issues and has taken significant\nactions to address them, particularly the first and third ones. It our understanding that a\nrecommended solution to this problem will be filed along with the ISO’s request for a re-\nhearing on Amendment 19, the ISO’s New Generation Interconnection Policy. Below we\nprovide our analysis of this issue and provide recommended market design changes to\naddress this problem. We also provide recommendations for integrating the market for\nFTRs into the ISO’s congestion management protocols.\n        The final set of issues concern the long-term health of the California electricity\nmarket. Given the importance of attracting new generation investment that is sufficient\nto meet California’s growing electricity demand without leading to significant excess\ncapacity in the California market (which would then lead to a period of depressed prices\nfor energy and ancillary services), these long-term market design issues become very\nimportant. First is designing the appropriate financial and local reliability obligations for\nnew generation entrants when they connect to the ISO grid so that they locate at points in\nthe transmission grid that enhance the efficiency of the market. Second is creating\nincentives for transmission capacity expansions in the ISO grid to substitute for new\ngeneration facilities, where this substitution reduces annual total delivered electricity\ncosts.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 66 of 148\n" [68] "6.      Pre-Dispatch and Scheduling of RMR Energy in the Day-Ahead\n        Market\n        One aspect of the Reliability Must Run (RMR) contract reforms recommended by\nthe MSC in its March 25, 1999 report that has yet to be implemented concerns the timing\nof RMR calls relative to the operation of the day-ahead energy market and the\ncorresponding day-ahead scheduling requirements for units called to provide RMR\nenergy. The structure of the current RMR contracts have been revised to take the basic\nform recommended in the August 1998 Report and further elaborated on in the April\n1999 MSC Report: a fixed annual payment (independent of number RMR calls made\nwithin the year or the number start-ups that are caused by RMR calls) and a variable cost\npayment per unit of RMR energy provided. Currently, RMR calls are made following\nthe close of the day-ahead energy market.\n    We continue to remain convinced that the pre-dispatch and day-ahead scheduling of\nRMR units outlined in the April 1999 MSC report is an essential feature of the RMR\ncontract reform process. The three basic features of our recommendations are:\n1. Pre-dispatch of all RMR units before the start of the day-ahead energy market. Based\n    on its assessment of the load conditions in the California transmission grid, the ISO\n    would determine the minimum reliability energy requirements from each RMR unit.\n2. All RMR unit owners with non-zero minimum reliability energy requirements would\n    have the option to elect to receive, on an hour-by-hour basis, a PX or ISO market-\n    clearing energy price for that hour or that unit’s RMR variable payment rate for this\n    quantity of energy. This election for all hours of the following day would be made\n    before the opening of the day-ahead energy market.\n3. All RMR unit owners with non-zero minimum reliability energy requirements would\n    be required to submit to the ISO in a balanced day-ahead energy schedule a\n    generation quantity from each RMR unit that is greater than or equal to the minimum\n    reliability energy requirement from that RMR unit.\nThe benefits to market efficiency from this scheme are:\n1. It is consistent with the market design principles of the California electricity market\n    where all day-ahead and hour-ahead energy requirements are submitted to the ISO in\n    balanced schedules. The current RMR dispatch scheme requires the ISO to take\n    financial position in the real-time energy market.\n2. It would enhance the efficiency of operation of both the energy and ancillary services\n    markets. Loads would have greater certainty about when RMR energy requirements\n    are scheduled. The ISO, and therefore loads, would no longer run the risk of\n    purchasing capacity for ancillary services in the day-ahead market that cannot be used\n    because of an RMR energy need from that capacity.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 67 of 148\n" [69] "3. It would reduce the volatility of wholesale energy prices in the PX and ISO markets\n    as well reduce average wholesale energy costs.\n4. It would delay less generation scheduling decisions to the real-time market, thereby\n    improving system and transmission grid reliability.\nBecause there do not appear to be any significant costs to market efficiency from\nimplementing this scheme, we strongly urge FERC to adopt this recommendation, given\nits many market-efficiency-enhancing properties.\n        The purpose of this section is to provide the logic underlying our\nrecommendations and conclusions about the impact of pre-dispatch and day-ahead\nscheduling of RMR energy on prices in the PX and ISO markets, as was requested by the\nFERC. To provide the necessary background for our analysis, we first summarize the\ncurrent RMR dispatch protocols. This is followed by an analysis of the impact of the\ncurrent protocols on the operation of California energy and ancillary services markets.\nWe then describe how our recommendations will improve the efficiency of the energy\nand ancillary services markets. Included in this discussion is a qualitative analysis of the\nimpact of pre-dispatch and day-ahead scheduling on prices in the PX and ISO energy\nmarkets.\n        A.     Current RMR Dispatch Procedures\n        Under the current RMR dispatch procedures, after the ISO has received a day-\nahead energy schedules for all generating units and intertie points, it determines the\nminimum necessary operating level, or Minimum Reliability Requirement (MRR), for\neach RMR unit for each hour of the following operating day. This MRR is determined\nbased on local weather conditions, forecast ISO load, and the operating conditions of\nother RMR generating units. For example, all generating units, including RMR units,\nhave a minimum operating level, below which the generating unit becomes electrically\nunstable. Consequently, the Minimum Reliability Requirement for a RMR unit can never\nbe below the minimum operating level for that unit.\n        After determining the hourly Minimum Reliability Requirement for that unit, the\nISO then compares this quantity to the final day-ahead schedule submitted by the RMR\nunit. If the final day-ahead schedule for that hour is below the Minimum Reliability\nRequirement, then that unit’s day-ahead schedule is adjusted upward to the Minimum\nReliability Requirement. The ISO implements this through a Schedule Change to the\nRMR unit owner, which gives the increase in the unit’s day-ahead energy schedule\nnecessary to guarantee that it operates at or above the minimum reliability requirement\nfor that hour. For example, if a unit schedules 20 MW into the day-ahead energy market,\nand its minimum reliability requirement is 40 MW, then a Schedule Change will be\nissued to that RMR unit for 20 MW. If the day-ahead energy schedule for that hour\nexceeds the minimum reliability requirements for that hour, then no Schedule Changes\nwill be issued during that hour for that RMR unit. For example, if a unit schedules 60\nMW into the day-ahead energy market, and its minimum reliability requirement is 40\n                       MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 68 of 148\n" [70] "MW, then no schedule change will be issued because the unit has already included more\nthan its minimum reliability requirements in its day-ahead energy schedule. Dispatch\nnotices are issued to RMR unit owners notifying them of either the ISO’s minimum\nreliability requirement and any schedule change necessary to meet this requirement.\n         If a Schedule Change is necessary, then under the new RMR contracts (that have\nbeen in effect since June 1999), a unit owner has the option of meeting these reliability\nrequirements through either the market or contract path. Under the contract path the\nRMR unit owner agrees to operate at a level that at least meets the minimum reliability\nrequirement from that unit and receives a previously agreed upon contractual variable\ncost payment (VCP) for each MWh of RMR energy provided. Any remaining capacity\nfrom that unit may be used to supply energy or any ancillary service that unit is\ntechnically capable of providing through a market transaction.\n         The market path allows owners to schedule RMR energy in the hour-ahead\nmarket or in the real-time market. Under the hour-ahead market option, the RMR owner\nreceives the hour-ahead PX price or a bilateral transaction price that the unit owner has\nmanaged to negotiate for this RMR energy. Under the real-time market option, the\nincrement to the generator’s day-ahead schedule is treated the same way as any other\nuninstructed deviation from a unit’s final hour-ahead schedule. Under this scheme, the\nRMR unit owner is paid for this incremental energy at the real-time imbalance energy\nprice for that hour. According to the September 1999 report prepared by the ISO’s\nDepartment of Market Analysis (DMA) on pre-dispatch and scheduling of RMR energy\nin the day-ahead market12, since the new RMR contracts have been in effect, less than\n1.4% of total RMR schedule changes issued after the day-ahead market (excluding real-\ntime dispatches) have been compensated according to the market path.\n         It is important to note that under the current RMR protocols, the additional energy\nprovided under a Schedule Change through either the market or contract path is not\nmatched with a corresponding increase in load. The current RMR protocols do not\nrequire that this additional RMR energy be submitted as part of a balanced schedule.\nThis incremental energy obtained through Schedule Changes results in an excess supply\nof day-ahead energy that is unmatched with demand until the real-time market. The\nexistence of this excess supply of energy on a day-ahead basis is inconsistent with a\nfundamental design principle of the California market that day-ahead energy schedules\nshould be balanced.\n         Assume that all Scheduling Coordinators (including the PX) submitted balanced\nday-ahead schedules, and made no changes in their consumption or generation plans\nbetween the close of the day-ahead energy market and the start of the real-time market.\nUnder the current RMR protocols, the ISO would have to decrement energy from\ngenerators in the real-time market equal to the total amount of the Schedule Change\nenergy procured through RMR contract calls following the close of the day-ahead\nmarket. Consequently, the current RMR dispatch protocols require the ISO to take a\n12\n   “Pre-Dispatch and Scheduling of RMR Energy in Day-Ahead Market,” Department of Market Analysis,\nCalifornia [71] "financial position in the real-time energy market as a result of its RMR Schedule\nChanges. This is inconsistent with another basic principle of the California market\ndesign that the ISO not take a financial position in any of the markets that it operates. All\nthe inefficiencies introduced by the current ISO RMR dispatch practices can be traced to\nthe violation of these two basic design principles.\n        B.      Market Inefficiencies Caused by a Current ISO RMR\n                Dispatch Practices\n        The current ISO RMR dispatch practices increase the volatility of real-time ISO\nand PX energy prices and artificially increases the quantity of generation in the ISO’s\nreal-time energy market. This can lead to increased ancillary services purchase costs to\nall Scheduling Coordinators and increased reliability risks for the system operator\nbecause larger discrepancies between the supply and demand for energy from SCs must\nbe balanced in the real-time energy market. As discussed above, the current RMR\ndispatch practices also result in more energy being purchased and scheduled in real-time.\nFinally, by dispatching RMR requirements after the close of the day-ahead energy\nmarket, the current RMR dispatch practices still provides the incentive for generators to\nbid the opportunity cost of their RMR variable payment rate into the day ahead energy\nmarket.\n        Although the revised RMR contracts have significantly reduced the magnitude of\nthe variable payment rate, there are still many hours when the market-clearing price in\nthe PX or real-time energy market is below the variable payment rate for many RMR\nunits. During these periods, RMR unit owners would prefer to receive the variable\npayment rate rather than the PX price or the real-time energy price for their RMR energy.\nIf the RMR unit owner’s marginal cost of production is above the expected PX or ISO\nenergy price, then it is clearly rational for the RMR unit owner not to schedule into the\nday-ahead energy market and to receive a market-clearing price below its marginal cost.\nHowever, because all RMR unit owners have non-RMR units, bidding sufficiently steep\naggregate supply curves into the PX market (so that unit owner does not win a large\nenough quantity to justify including these units in their day-ahead energy schedules to the\nISO) may be profit-maximizing. Occasionally the favorable outcome that the high-priced\nbid necessary to schedule the RMR capacity on day-ahead basis sets the market-clearing\nprice for all units owned by that RMR unit owner.\n        C.      Increased Wholesale Price Volatility and Purchased Energy\n                Costs\n        Under the current RMR dispatch protocols, if all loads submitted their anticipated\ndemand for the each hour during the following day in a balanced day-ahead energy\nschedule, the ISO would be required to decrement energy in the real-time market equal to\nthe quantity of RMR Schedule Changes issued after the close of the day-ahead energy\nmarket. We therefore expect loads to attempt to anticipate the quantity of RMR energy\nthat will called after they submit their day-ahead energy schedules. It is extremely\nunlikely that all buyers of energy will jointly be able to anticipate the precise quantity of\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 70 of 148\n" These RMR Schedule Change forecast\n   errors by loads will increase the price volatility in both the PX day-ahead and hour-ahead\n   markets and the ISO real-time energy markets. In other periods, this price will be significantly higher because loads shift too\n   little demand to the hour-ahead and real-time markets. This conclusion follows because the lower prices due to an\n   unexpected small amount demand bid into the PX will tend to be only slightly lower. The\n   unexpectedly high demand bid into the PX will lead to a much higher price, because in\n   these instances the increased aggregate demand curve will now cross the very steep\n   portion of the [73] "        Figure 51 illustrates this phenomenon by plotting a representative PX aggregate\nsupply curve and three PX aggregate demand curves. The middle curve represents the\naggregate demand curve which perfectly anticipates the amount of aggregate RMR\nenergy that will called after the close of the PX day-ahead market. The market-clearing\nprice and quantity in this case are P0 and Q0. The lowest curve represents the aggregate\ndemand when too much load is shifted to the hour-ahead and real-time market. The\nmarket-clearing price and quantity in this case are P1 and Q1. The highest curve represents\nthe aggregate demand when too little load is shifted to the hour-ahead and real-time\nmarket. The market-clearing price and quantity in this case are P2 and Q2. Note that\nbecause of the very steep slope of the aggregate bid supply curve, P1 is only slightly\nbelow P0, whereas P2 is significantly larger than P0.\n        A similar result holds for the hour-ahead and real-time energy markets because\ntheir aggregate supply bid curves also resemble this reverse L-shape. Consider the case\nof the real-time market. The same logic holds for the hour-ahead market. When too\nmuch load is scheduled in markets other than the real-time market, the real-time price\nwill be slightly below the value that would occur if the all of the loads perfectly\nanticipated the aggregate quantity of RMR Schedule Changes. If too little load is\nscheduled in other markets besides the real-time market, the real-time price will\nsignificantly higher than the value that would occur if all of the loads perfectly\nanticipated the aggregate quantity of RMR Schedule Changes. By this logic, both the\nday-ahead and hour-ahead PX prices and the real-time ISO price will be more volatile\nthan would be the case if RMR energy were pre-dispatched and included in a balanced\nschedule on a day-ahead basis.\n        The more important market inefficiency is the increased expected wholesale\nenergy purchasing costs caused by the combination of the shape of the PX and real-time\nenergy supply curve and loads incorrectly forecasting how much demand to bid into PX\nand ISO energy markets. As noted above, both the PX and ISO aggregate supply bid\ncurves resemble a reverse-L shape. For simplicity we focus on the case of the day-ahead\nPX market and the ISO real-time market. Because final demand is essentially inelastic\nwith respect to the hourly wholesale price of energy, we assume that both generators and\nloads know this quantity is equal to QT. Suppose SPX(p) is the\naggregate bid supply curve into the PX and SISO(p) is corresponding curve for the ISO\nreal-time market. Both aggregate bid supply curves are unknown to wholesale loads at\nthe time they bid. Suppose that DMPX(p) is the aggregate demand bid curve that loads\nwould submit if they collectively knew that all RMR energy was required to be scheduled\non a day-ahead basis according to our recommendations given above. This aggregate\ndemand bid curve would result in the market-clearing price PM in both the PX and ISO\nreal-time markets. The quantity QMPX would be sold in the PX and the quantity QMISO =\nQT - QMPX in the ISO real-time market.\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 72 of 148\n"

 [75] "significantly larger than area AISO, so that total expected wholesale energy costs can be\nsignificantly higher as result current ISO dispatch practices relative to the protocol we\nrecommend where loads will jointly know that all RMR energy requirements will be\nscheduled on a day-ahead basis.\n         The Department of Market Analysis of the ISO in their September 1999 report\nfollows a different methodology to estimate that wholesale energy costs would be\napproximately 2% lower as a result of implementing pre-dispatch and mandatory day-\nahead scheduling.13 This magnitude of estimated cost savings is consistent with our\nanalysis.\n         D.       Current Dispatch Policy Encourages Under-Scheduling of\n                  Load\n         The ISO proposed a policy, which the FERC approved, to charge loads for the\nadditional Replacement reserves that the ISO procures to cover any forecast deficiencies\nin available energy in the real-time market. The cost of additional Replacement reserves\nis allocated to loads in proportion to the extent that their hour-ahead energy schedules are\nbelow their real-time consumption. As discussed above, because loads know that some\nRMR energy will show up in the real-time energy market without a corresponding load,\nthey will rationally attempt to under-schedule their energy requirements on a day-ahead\nbasis to account for this excess supply of energy due to RMR Schedule Changes.\nConsequently, the current RMR dispatch protocols and the FERC-approved policy of\ncharging loads for additional Replacement Reserves based on the amount of under-\nscheduling of demand are in direct conflict with one another. Under-scheduling by loads\non a day-ahead and hour-ahead basis is a rational response to anticipated RMR Schedule\nChanges. However, such responses will result in loads being charged for any additional\nReplacement Reserves procured by the ISO to cover this under-scheduling. These\nincreased costs will cause loads to be less likely to attempt to anticipate this additional\nafter-market supply of energy in their day-ahead energy scheduling decisions.\n         E.       Increased Reliability Risks and Increased Costs of Ancillary\n                  Services\n         Because RMR Schedule Changes supply additional energy to a balanced day-\nahead market, a larger quantity of energy imbalances must be settled in the real-time\nenergy market than would necessary if RMR units were pre-dispatched. This creates\nunnecessary reliability risks for the ISO in managing the transmission grid in real-time.\nAs noted in the DMA’s September 1999 report on the pre-dispatch of RMR units, during\nthe 17 months from April 1998 to August 1999, approximately 25% of the RMR energy\ndispatched after the day-ahead market had to be accommodated by decrementing energy\nfrom scheduled generation in real-time.  [76] "August 1999, the DMA estimated that over 27% of the energy provided under the\ncontract path created the need to decrement other generation in real-time. In many\nregions of the ISO control area, the market for decremental energy is often extremely\nthin. As a result, the ISO is often forced to rely on out-of-market and out-of-control-area\ncalls for decremental energy. The ISO has often had to resolve over-generation\nconditions by accepting negative decremental energy bids. A negative decremental\nenergy bid implies that the generator is being paid by the ISO to not generate, whereas a\npositive decremental energy bid implies the generator is buying back the decremental\nenergy from the ISO.\n         Purchasing energy in the day-ahead market that must subsequently be bought\nback in the real-time market even at a positive price, also increases wholesale energy\nprocurement costs to loads because generators are willing to be decremented only at price\nsignificantly less than the day-ahead price of energy. To the extent that these\ndecremental bids are accepted out-of-sequence in the real-time energy market, the costs\nto loads from the ISO accepting these decremental bids will not be reflected in a lower\nzonal energy price but in higher intra-zonal congestion costs.\n         The process of scheduling additional energy in the form of RMR Schedule\nChanges after the close of the day-ahead market and then decrementing energy in real-\ntime results in a significantly less efficient and more expensive generation dispatch\nprocess. This process also involves greater grid reliability risks relative to an RMR\ndispatch procedure which pre-dispatches RMR generation before running the day-ahead\nenergy market. In order to guard against the increased reliability risks caused by the\ncurrent RMR dispatch protocols, the ISO may need to purchase a greater quantity of\nquick-response ancillary services such as Regulation. By purchasing a greater quantity of\nthis ancillary service, the ISO can expect to pay a higher price. This increased price is\nthen multiplied by the greater demand, resulting in higher ancillary services costs than\nwould be occur under a scheme involving pre-dispatch of RMR units.\n         Under the current RMR dispatch protocols, Schedule Changes are issued after\nday-ahead energy schedules have been finalized and the day-ahead ancillary services\nmarket has been cleared. Because of this sequencing, the ISO must sometimes buy back\nancillary services commitments won by RMR units in the day-ahead ancillary services\nmarket so that the generating unit can meet an RMR Schedule Change for energy.\nUnder current RMR dispatch protocols, the RMR unit owner is paid for the ancillary\nservices that it wins in the day-ahead market as well as for the additional energy it\nprovides under the terms of its RMR contract. Consequently, under the current ISO\nprotocols, an RMR unit owner can be paid for providing both energy and ancillary\nservices from the same increment of generating capacity in the same hour, despite the\nfact the ISO has purchased ancillary services capacity in hour-ahead market to substitute\nfor this unavailable capacity from the RMR unit. During periods when the ISO purchases\nunusable day-ahead ancillary services capacity, it is purchasing more total ancillary\nservices capacity than it would need if RMR energy was pre-dispatched in a balanced\nday-ahead energy schedule. By purchasing an excess amount of ancillary services\ncapacity, the ISO further increases ancillary services prices and total costs.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 75 of  [77] "        During the summer of 1999, the procurement of day-ahead ancillary services\ncapacity that cannot actually be used because it is required to provide RMR energy has\nbecome increasingly frequent, further increasing the ancillary services costs associated\nwith current RMR dispatch protocols.\n        F.       Increased Energy Prices Due to RMR Variable Payment Rate\n        Even though the RMR variable payment rates have been significantly reduced\nrelative to the levels in the original type A RMR Contracts, for many generators, their\ncurrent RMR variable payment rates is often above the market-clearing PX price or real-\ntime energy price. Therefore, during hours when the PX price is expected to be below\nthe unit’s RMR variable payment rate, we would expect the opportunity cost of supplying\nRMR energy at the variable payment rate to be the binding lower bound on the price at\nwhich the unit owner will bid that capacity into the PX. This follows from the same logic\ngiven in the April 1999 MSC Report for the bidding behavior of a generator under a type\nA RMR Contract. An RMR unit owner would bid this capacity into the PX at a price that\nyields at least the same expected profits that it could obtain from providing energy at the\nvariable payment rate under the terms of its RMR contract. Consequently, we would\nexpect that generators bidding the opportunity cost of their RMR units into the PX market\nto result in higher market-clearing PX and ISO energy prices.\n        Because a very small number of the variable payment rates are above $100/MWh,\nnone are above $500/MWh, and the vast majority are below $50/MWh, the impact of\nRMR unit owners bidding the opportunity cost of their RMR variable payment rate into\nthe PX and ISO energy markets is likely to be substantially less than under the old type A\nRMR contracts. As a result, the unweighted average PX and ISO hourly electricity prices\nmay be somewhat higher than those that would result from the pre-dispatch of RMR\nenergy. However, as discussed above the volatility of the PX and ISO electricity prices is\nlikely to be significantly greater and total purchased energy costs (or equivalently, the\nquantity-weighted average price) higher for the reasons discussed above and in the\nDMA’s September 1999 report on the pre-dispatch of RMR units. In addition, total\nancillary services demand and costs are also likely to be noticeably higher as result of\ncurrent RMR dispatch practices relative to the case of pre-dispatch of RMR energy in a\nbalanced day-ahead energy schedule.\n        G.       Recommended RMR Dispatch Protocols with New RMR\n                 Contracts\n        The guiding principles of the California market design provide a clear\nrecommendation for designing RMR dispatch protocols that eliminate the market\ndistortions and increased costs associated with the current RMR dispatch protocols\ndescribed above. This is the recommendation given in the April 1999 MSC to pre-\ndispatch RMR capacity before the start of the day-ahead energy market and require all\npre-dispatched RMR requirements to be submitted as part of a balanced day-ahead\nenergy schedule. While more complex schemes have been proposed by the DMA in its\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 76 of 148\n"  [78] "September 1999 report, there are three features that should be a part of any protocol that\nis adopted.\n1. Pre-Dispatch of RMR Units. The ISO would determine all energy RMR\nrequirements for all hours of the following day before the start of the day-ahead energy\nmarket. We refer to this as pre-dispatch of RMR units. Under this scheme, the ISO\nwould determine the RMR energy requirements from all RMR units and make this unit-\nspecific information available to all market participants before the start of the day-ahead\nenergy market.\n2. Pre-Declare Market or Contract Payment Option. After learning the quantity of\nRMR energy requirements for all RMR units for all hours of the following day, each\nRMR unit owner would have the option to declare for each hour of the following day\nwhether it would like to receive the market price of energy or the RMR contract variable\npayment rate for RMR energy supplied from that unit. The RMR unit owner electing the\nmarket option for a given hour, would have the option of electing to be paid the zonal PX\nday-ahead price, zonal PX hour-ahead price, or ISO real-time zonal price for that hour for\nthe congestion zone that contains their generating unit for energy supplied under the\nterms of the RMR contract.\n3. Unit-Level RMR Energy Must Be Included in a Balanced Day-Ahead Schedule.\nAll RMR units with non-zero RMR energy requirements must have their unit-level RMR\ngeneration obligations included in a balanced day-ahead energy schedule submitted to the\nISO. This requirement places no restrictions on how the unit owner must bid its RMR\ncapacity into day-ahead or hour-ahead PX markets or the ISO real-time energy market.\nIf the RMR unit owner elects the market path for its payment for RMR energy, then the\nunit owner should be able to hedge its RMR energy obligations in any manner it sees fit.\nThe unit owner could bid this capacity into the PX day-ahead or hour-ahead market, or\nthe ISO real-time market. The unit owner could also arrange to hedge this quantity of\nenergy through a bilateral contract. However, it is important to emphasize that no matter\nhow the unit owner constructs a financial hedge for the pre-dispatched energy from its\nRMR units, it must submit a balanced day-ahead energy schedule to the ISO with a total\nquantity of generation from each RMR unit exceeding its pre-dispatch RMR energy\nobligations.\n        To order to clarify how this protocol would work, consider the following\nexample. Suppose a market participant owned two RMR units. At 5 am the day before\nthe actual quantity of electricity would be delivered, the ISO would notify this market\nparticipant of the Reliability Requirement from both of its RMR units. Suppose that the\ncapacity of each unit was 250 MW and that for the hour in question the ISO determined\nthat 100 MW was the Reliability Requirement for each unit. This information and the\nReliability Requirements for all RMR units would be made available all market\nparticipants. All RMR unit owners would then have one hour to notify the ISO which\nhours in the following day they would like to receive the market price (and what market\nprice for energy they would like to receive) and what hours they would like to receive the\nvariable payment rate. Thus, by 6 am, one hour before final bids must be submitted to\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 77 of 148\n"  [79] "the PX day-ahead market, all RMR unit owners would complete their election of how\nthey would like to be compensated for providing the quantity of RMR energy required\nfrom each RMR unit.\n         Following the close of the day-ahead energy market, the RMR unit owner is\nrequired to submit a balanced energy schedule to the ISO for the hour in question that\nincludes at least 100 MW of generation, the Reliability Requirement for that hour, from\neach of the RMR units. It is the responsibility of the RMR unit owner to procure the load\nnecessary to submit a balanced day-ahead energy schedule. One option is to bid the\nquantity of pre-dispatched RMR energy into the PX day-ahead market or hour-ahead\nmarket at a price of zero to guarantee that this generation is balanced against an\nequivalent demand. Another alternative is for the RMR unit owner to sell this energy to a\nthird-party under a bilateral contract. The final alternative is for the RMR unit owner to\nbalance the total unit-specific RMR generation that it must provide in its day-ahead\nenergy schedule with a fictional load. In this case, the unit owner is simply selling this\ngeneration in the real-time energy market.\n         H.      Impact of Pre-dispatch and                         Mandatory          Day-Ahead\n                 Scheduling of Energy Prices\n         The most likely outcome from implementing the above recommendations is a\nnoticeable reduction in total wholesale energy purchase costs from the day-ahead and\nhour-ahead PX energy markets and the real-time ISO energy market. Another benefit\nshould be less energy price volatility because of a reduction in the frequency of price\nspikes in the day-ahead, hour-ahead or real-time energy markets when an unexpectedly\nhigh level of demand is purchased in the day-ahead, hour-ahead or real-time energy\nmarket as discussed above. The constraints a generation unit owner faces when it\nattempts to maximize expected profits by its bids into the day-ahead energy market\njustify the view that these changes in RMR dispatch protocols do not artificially depress\nenergy prices in the PX and ISO markets.\n         The logic for this view goes as follows. Because the maximum amount of total\nRMR energy requirements in any hour rarely exceeds 4,000 MW, and most often is in the\nneighborhood of 1,500 MW, only a small fraction of the capacity of any single generator\nis producing energy under an RMR contract. Consequently, the length of a market\nparticipant’s bid curve that may be bid at a zero price in the PX because of the pre-\ndispatch of RMR energy, is likely to be very small relative to the total capacity a\ngeneration owner would bid into the PX or submit to the ISO in its day-ahead energy\nschedule.\n         In Wolak (1999), optimal bidding strategies for a firm participating in a bid-\nbased-dispatch electricity market are derived.14 Wolak shows that a generation owner’s\noptimal strategy is constrained by the residual demand curve that it faces.  [80] "demand curve is the difference between the aggregate demand bid curve for energy in the\nmarket and the aggregate supply bid curve of all firms besides the firm bidding. If SO(p)\nis the aggregate supply bid curve of all market participants besides the firm under\nconsideration and D(p) is aggregate market demand bid curve for energy, then the\nresidual demand curve faced by the firm is DR(p) = D(p) – SO(p). If S(p) is the firm’s\naggregate supply bid curve, the market-clearing price is determined from the intersection\nof the firm’s residual demand curve with its aggregate supply bid curve, or equivalently\nthe price, p*, that solves the equation DR(p*) = S(p*). The residual demand curve faced\nby the generation owner depends both on an aggregate demand bid curve and the\naggregate supply bid curves of all other firms in the market, both of which are unknown\nat the time this firm submits its aggregate supply bid curve. This implies that the residual\ndemand curve faced by the firm can be thought of as stochastic at the time a generation\nunit owner submits it bids. Consequently, unit owners submit supply bid functions which\nattempt to cross each possible residual demand curve it might face during that hour at a\nprice that maximizes the firm's profits for that residual demand curve. This optimal\nbidding strategy can be used study the impact of the proposed RMR dispatch protocols on\nmarket-clearing prices in the PX and ISO energy markets.\n         Figure 53 graphs the aggregate demand bid curve, the aggregate supply bid curve\nof all other market participants and the resulting residual demand curve faced by the firm,\nDR(p), and a candidate bid curve for the firm, S(p), which passes through the profit-\nmaximizing market-clearing price associated with that residual demand curve. As\ndiscussed in Wolak (1999), at the time the unit owner submits its bid into the energy\nmarket, neither the value of SO(p) nor the value of D(p) is known. Consequently, the\ngenerator must set the bid supply curve, S(p), so that it maximizes the generation unit\nowner’s expected profits over all possible realizations of DR(p). However, if the\ngenerator were able to predict the realization of the DR(p), then a bid curve through the\npoint (PM,QF) would maximize its profits from bidding into this market.\n         By taking the smallest possible residual demand curve that a generator might face\nand computing the profit maximizing price and quantity associated with that residual\ndemand curve yields the end point of the determinant portion of the profit-maximizing\nbid function. Figure 54 plots the highest possible residual demand curve and the\nassociated marginal revenue curve and the lowest possible residual demand curve and the\nassociated marginal revenue curve. The figure also plots the firm’s marginal cost curve.\nOn each residual demand curve the best response price and quantity are noted. Any bid\ncurve that is upward sloping from the origin to the point (Ps,QS) would yield the same\nlevel of expected profits to the firm, because a residual demand curve will never cross\nthis generator’s bid curve at a point to the southeast of the point (Ps,QS) in Figure 54. A\nzero price and positive quantity segment of the bid curve that is of length less than QS\nwill yield the same expected profits to the firm as an aggregate supply bid curve that is\nsteadily increasing from the origin to the point (Ps,QS). If QS is greater than the pre-\ndispatch RMR quantity allocated to the firm, then mandatory submission of the quantity\nof RMR energy in a balanced day-ahead schedule will not affect the firm’s  [82] "         Only if the value of QS in any hour is below the quantity of RMR energy pre-\ndispatched will the recommended RMR dispatch protocols be likely to affect generator\nbidding behavior. There are two additional factors which make it unlikely that QS in a\ngiven hour is less than the quantity of RMR energy required to be supplied by an RMR\nunit owner. First, during the hours in which residual demand faced by the first is likely\nto be particularly small (in the neighborhood of DS given in Figure 54), total ISO load is\nlikely to be small and therefore the transmission grid is not likely to be stressed. In this\ncase a very small quantity of aggregate RMR energy will be required. This in turn\nimplies that even a small value of QS for a specific generation owner will be larger than\nits total RMR energy requirements for that hour. Second, during periods when total ISO\nload is high, the total quantity of energy needed from all generation owners is likely to be\nsubstantial so that the value of QS in these hours is likely to be very high. This implies\nthat a substantial quantity of RMR energy will still be less than QS, implying that the\nrecommended RMR dispatch protocols are likely to have little impact on generator bids\nduring periods with both low and high total ISO system loads.\n         Only if unit owners withhold significant amounts of their generation capacity\nfrom the PX day-ahead market by bidding most of their capacity at high prices in attempt\nto raise market prices in the PX, should this constraint have any impact on generation unit\nowner bids into the PX. We should note that this is precisely the sort of behavior the pre-\ndispatch and a mandatory day-ahead scheduling requirement is attempting to eliminate.\nConsequently, the we do not believe that implementing these recommendations will\nartificially depress PX or ISO energy prices, only eliminate the incentives generators\nhave to exploit their ownership of RMR units to raise market prices.\n         Besides a lowering wholesale energy price volatility and a reducing total\nwholesale energy purchase costs, the other significant benefit of pre-dispatch and\nmandatory submission of a balanced day-ahead schedule containing the unit-specific\nRMR requirements is that the ISO will no longer need to decrement generation in real-\ntime to make room for RMR energy not submitted in a balanced day-ahead schedule.\nBecause units scheduled to provide RMR energy on a day-ahead basis can only supply\nancillary services from unused capacity, this scheme also eliminates the need to\ndecrement ancillary services quantities won in the day-ahead market to allow RMR\nenergy to be supplied from that generating facility.\n         This scheme is also consistent with the ISO’s current policy of charging for\nadditional replacement reserve in proportion to the amount that a load under-schedules its\ndemand on an hour-ahead basis relative to its real-time consumption. Because all pre-\ndispatched RMR energy must be submitted as part of a balanced day-ahead schedule,\nthere will no longer be excess energy appearing in the real-time market as a result of\nRMR Schedule Changes which loads must account for in their day-ahead and hour-ahead\nenergy schedules. Consequently, loads will no longer have an incentive to under-\nschedule in anticipation of this incremental RMR energy in the real-time market.\nBecause all market participants know the unit specific
