This greater certainly about the timing and location of the\nsupply of RMR energy will give loads greater confidence about which markets they\nshould bid their demand into. This will reduce the volatility of prices in both PX day-\nahead and hour-ahead energy markets and the ISO real-time energy market.\n        Finally, the greater certainty about the timing and location of the supply of RMR\nenergy will delay less grid management and generation dispatch activities to the real-time\nmarket and therefore reduce the reliability risk associated with RMR dispatch, which\nshould reduce the ISO’s demand for quick-response ancillary services capacity. This\nshould reduce the price the ISO must pay for these ancillary services, as well as total\nancillary services costs.\n7.      Regulatory Impediments to a Price-Responsive Demand for\n        Energy and Ancillary Services\n        Often regulatory policies designed to solve one market design problem can create\nsignificant market distortions. The stranded asset recovery mechanism, known in\nCalifornia as the Competition Transition Charge (CTC) is an excellent example of this\nphenomenon. The current CTC mechanism creates several impediments to involving\nprice-responsive demand in the day-ahead, hour-ahead and real-time energy markets,\nthereby significantly decreasing the competitiveness of the California electricity market.\nThe market distortions created by the CTC mechanism provide a strong argument in\nfavor of the continued imposition of damage control price caps on all ISO energy and\nancillary services markets until the CTC recovery period ends or some of its major\nmarket distortions are corrected.\n        There are two aspects of the stranded asset recovery process that creates these\nmarket inefficiencies. First is the retail rate freeze and the associated CTC recovery\nmechanism. The second is prohibition against any forward financial contracting outside\nof the PX markets for generation owned by any of the three investor-owned utilities\n(IOUs) in California or load served by the utility distribution companies (UDCs) owned\nby any of the three (IOUs). The separation of wholesale market and retail market\nregulatory oversight in California between FERC and the California Public Utilities\nCommission (CPUC) also creates an additional impediment to increasing the\ncompetitiveness of the California electricity market. We show that certain current CPUC\npolicies significantly dull, if not eliminate, the incentive retail customers have to respond\nto hourly energy and ancillary services prices, thus rendering the California wholesale\nmarket less competitive, particularly during high load periods. This section points out\nthese structural problems with the current design of the California market and suggests\nseveral remedies.\n        The major flaws with the current market design are:\n1. The CTC recovery mechanism eliminates virtually all incentives for the vast majority\nof final loads to be price-responsive with respect to hourly wholesale electricity prices.\n  [84] "2. The only market participants with a financial incentive to take actions to lower\nwholesale electricity prices in any single hour are the IOUs. They achieve a higher CTC\nrecovery rate during hours when energy and ancillary service prices are lower.\nCompetitive energy service providers (ESPs) receive no financial benefit from lower\nhourly wholesale prices during the rate freeze period.\n3. Under the retail rate freeze incentives, the only way for the IOUs to make it attractive\nfor their retail customers to reduce hourly demand in response to high hourly wholesale\nelectricity and ancillary services prices is to pay them to reduce demand. This alternative\nis not financially viable for the ESPs, because they receive do not receive CTC payments.\n4. The prohibition on forward contracting by UDC load outside of the PX limits the\navenues for price-responsiveness available to loads in the California market. This leads\nto higher wholesale prices than would be the case if loads could hedge their electricity\nand ancillary services consumption further in advance of its delivery.\n5. Prohibition of forward contracting by UDCs for ancillary services beyond day-ahead\nmarket unnecessarily forces ISO to take a financial position in the day-ahead and hour-\nahead ancillary services market as buyer of ancillary services requirements for PX load.\n6. Lack of coordination between retail competition policy and wholesale competition\npolicy can lead to market failures in either or both markets. The extent of the price-\nresponsiveness of hourly wholesale demand is determined by the extent that there is a\nprice-responsive hourly retail demand.\n         Although all of these distortions can be traced directly or indirectly to the CTC\nrecovery mechanism, they will not automatically be eliminated when the CTC recovery\nperiod ends. Steps should be taken as soon as possible to eliminate these distortions. We\nmake several recommendations in the regard.\n1. Maintain ISO authority to set maximum purchases prices in energy and ancillary\nservices markets until the CTC recovery period ends.\n2. Eliminate all prohibitions on forward contracting by UDCs outside of PX for energy\nand ancillary services.\n3. When rate freeze ends for a UDC, do not implement a default provider retail rate\nwhich passes through hourly wholesale electricity purchase costs. This locks-in a lack of\nhourly price responsiveness in retail demand with detrimental consequences for\ncompetitiveness of wholesale electricity markets.\n4. Instead, when rate freeze periods for a UDC, require it to offer a default provider rate\nto equal original rate freeze retail or some fraction of rate freeze rate (to account for\nelimination of CTC recovery). All UDCs must offer this new rate to all of its customers.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 83 of 148\n"  [85] "5. After rate freeze period, allow both UDCs and ESPs to offer any bundle services and\nprices in order to create full diversity retail valued-added services. Retail competition\nwith UDC required to offer default provide rate described in point 4 will lead to de facto\nwholesale pass-through tariff it this is desired by customers. CTC Mechanism Eliminates Incentives for Final Load to Be\n                Price Responsive\n        Under the current rate freeze in California, the retail electricity rates are frozen at\ntheir 1996 level less 10%. Define PR as this fixed retail price. Under the current CTC\nrecovery mechanism, generally speaking, this fixed retail price can be broken down into\nthe following components: PR = PE + T&D + CTC + RES, were PE is a weighted\naverage of the various California electricity and ancillary services prices (principally the\nPX price), T&D is the price of transmission and distribution services, CTC is the\ncompetition transition charge, and RES is a residual category charge which pays for a\nvariety items such as demand-side management programs and the rate reduction bonds.\nAn important implication of this equation is that the CTC component is defined so that it\nholds on a monthly basis. Electricity is sold to the final consumer at the price PR.. This\nenergy is purchased from PX and ISO markets, and transmission and distribution charges\nare paid at the rate T&D and the residual category payments are made at the rate RES,\nand any money left over goes to the CTC payment. This means that the difference\nbetween monthly retail revenues and the monthly amounts paid for wholesale electricity,\ntransmission and distribution, and the residual expenses category yields the monthly\namount of CTC recovery.\n        Because retail rates are fixed and final demand is a function of this fixed retail\nprice, the total revenue collected from customers on these frozen retail rates is\nindependent of movements in wholesale electricity prices. Therefore, total retail\nrevenues for the state of California collected from customers on these frozen rates is\nessentially independent of hourly wholesale electricity prices for energy and ancillary\nservices. Because CTC payments are defined as the difference between monthly retail\nrevenues and the monthly amounts paid for wholesale electricity, transmission and\ndistribution, and the residual expenses category, the investor-owned utilities (IOUs) have\na strong incentive to keep electricity prices low during the rate freeze period. Other\nwholesale generation market participants must earn all of their revenues from energy and\nancillary services sales in the PX and ISO markets. They are not entitled to receive any\nCTC payments. For this reason, these generation owners prefer high energy and ancillary\nservices. During the rate freeze period, there is a fixed amount of retail revenues\navailable in the California market that does not depend on the actions of wholesale\n                        MSC Report,  [86] "market participants to influence hourly energy or ancillary services prices. Investor-\nowned utilities receive a larger share of this revenue pool through their CTC payments if\nenergy and ancillary services prices are low. Other generation unit owners receive a\nlarger share if energy and ancillary services prices are higher through direct payments for\nwholesale energy. CTC payments to the IOUs fall by the same amount that revenues\nreceived by the other generation owners increase as result of higher wholesale energy and\nancillary services prices, because the total amount received by all market participants\nmust equal the fixed (with respect to the actions of market participants in the wholesale\nmarket) pool of retail revenues.\n         Because ESPs, compete with the incumbent UDC in supplying retail electricity to\nfinal customers, it is important to understand their incentives during the rate freeze. In\norder to provide retail electricity, an ESP must produce electricity or purchase wholesale\nelectricity from the PX and ISO energy markets. It must purchase transmission and\ndistribution services, as well as pay RES and CTC per unit of electricity delivered to final\nretail customers. To the ESP, the CTC charge is simply a cost of doing business in the\nretail market. The ESP receives no benefit from lower energy prices because the ESP’s\ntotal CTC payments rises to exactly compensate for these lower energy prices on a\nmonthly basis. The only electricity retailers with a financial incentive to take actions to\nlower wholesale electricity prices are the UDCs, because their parent companies will\nreceive larger CTC payments during the months in which wholesale energy prices are\nlow. The ESPs on the other hand, receive no direct financial benefit from lower\nwholesale electricity prices.\n         The combination of the CTC recovery mechanism and the retail rate freeze\nimplies that it is unprofitable or economically irrational for an ESP to supply electricity at\na retail price is below PR. Suppose the ESP sold electricity at a retail price PR* that is\nless than the retail rate freeze price PR. Because the ESP must still pay the same values\nof T&D, RES, and CTC that the UDC must pay for delivering the same amount of\nelectricity to the final customer, the ESP is effectively selling wholesale electricity to the\nfinal customer at a price below PE. However, the ESP must buy its wholesale electricity\nfrom the PX and ISO markets if it does not own any generation. If it does own\ngeneration, the opportunity cost of it selling electricity produced from its generating units\nis the wholesale electricity price in the PX and ISO markets. Consequently, by selling\nretail electricity at a price below the rate freeze price, the ESP is selling wholesale\nelectricity at an average price below what it can be sold at in the PX and ISO markets.\n         This aspect of the CTC recovery mechanism and retail rate freeze explains why\nsuch a small number of residential customers have switched electricity suppliers.\nAccording to the latest California Energy Commission (CEC) figures through May of\n1999, slightly more than 1% of customers of the 3 UDCs—San Diego Gas and Electric,\nSouthern California Edison, and Pacific Gas and Electric—have switched electricity\nsuppliers since the start of the California electricity market.\n         Besides giving little incentive for retail consumers to switch from the incumbent\nUDC to a competitive ESP, the current CTC recovery mechanism and retail price freeze\n                          MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 85 of 148\n"  [87] "also provides little incentive for customers to install real-time metering technology and\npurchase their electricity according to the hourly PX or ISO price. The customer must\ncontinue to pay T&D, RES, and a CTC payment, that increases when wholesale energy\nprices are low and decreases when wholesale energy prices are high, no matter what\ncompany supplies the retail electricity. This implies that a customer electing to purchase\nretail electricity according to some weighted-average hourly wholesale price of electricity\nshould receive little, if any, cost savings from this decision. In addition, either the\ncustomer or the energy supplier (who then must recover this cost from the customer) will\nhave to pay the cost of installing real-time metering technology on customer’s premises.\nConsequently, during the CTC recovery period virtually all retail customers have no\nincentive to install the metering technology necessary to purchase electricity according to\nthe hourly wholesale price.\n         As discussed above, the UDC would like its retail customers to reduce their\ndemand during hours when ISO load is expected to be high in order to reduce wholesale\nprices and increase its rate of CTC recovery. However, the option of a frozen retail price\nand the CTC payment mechanism gives retail customers no incentive to reduce their\ndemands during these time periods. Consequently, all demand reduction mechanisms\nproposed by the UDCs have involved payments to customers for reducing their demand\nduring periods when the wholesale price is expected to be high. In this way the UDC\nshares with the retail consumer the increased CTC revenues that it receives as a result of\nlower wholesale prices.\n         Even though the UDC would like its customers to reduce their demand in periods\nof high ISO load, it has very little incentive to switch these customers to a real-time\nmeter. A customer with a real-time meter can compute precisely how much it is costing\nthe UDC to supply electricity using their hourly electricity consumption and the hourly\nwholesale prices of energy and ancillary services. This customer will be more likely to\nswitch suppliers following the end of the rate freeze period if the UDC’s retail price is not\nas low as the one the customer can obtain from an alternative supplier. By installing a\nreal-time meter on a customer’s premises, the UDC creates a far more sophisticated\ncustomer who has the ability to respond to hourly price signals and can be billed based on\nhis consumption during each hour of the day. A customer whose meter is read on a\nmonthly basis can only be charged based on some function of his total monthly\nconsumption. Consequently, the set of pricing schemes that can be devised to compete\nfor customers with hourly meters are much more sophisticated than the pricing schemes\nthat need to be devised to compete for customers whose meters can only be read on a\nmonthly basis.\n         If a significant number of customers had hourly meters, ESPs and the UDCs\nwould then be able to compete to offer many different types of pricing structures to\nmatch the heterogeneity in the willingness of customers to respond to real-time price\nsignals. We would expect some customers to want to face the hourly price of electricity\nand therefore face the full risk of hourly wholesale price spikes and also receive the full\nbenefits of very low wholesale prices in their month electricity bill. Some customers may\nonly want to hedge against the upside risk of hourly wholesale price spikes and therefore\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 86 of 148\n"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
 [88] "pay more for consumption during hours when wholesale prices are low. Despite the\nlarge potential benefits to both retail and wholesale competition from the widespread\nimplementation of hourly meters, because the incumbent UDCs currently have only\nslightly less than 99% of their original customers, they have little financial incentive to\npay to create more sophisticated customers who they must then compete more vigorously\nto retain.\n        Because ESPs do not receive CTC payments, they cannot offer a payment scheme\nfor demand reduction during periods expected to have high wholesale prices. An ESP\nmay wish to install a real-time meter to offer a customer rate package that is superior to\nwhat the customer currently receives from the UDC. However, the current CTC recovery\nmechanism and availability of service from the UDC at the rate-freeze retail price makes\nit very unlikely that a rate package that causes the customer to switch will be profitable\nfor the ESP. Consequently, the combination of the CTC recovery mechanism and the\nretail rate freeze severely limits the opportunities for retail competition and, more\nimportant, the incentives for the installation of real-time metering technology to increase\nthe amount of final demand that is price responsive on an hourly basis.\n        B.      Prohibition Against UDC Contracting Outside of PX Forces\n                Forward Sales of Energy and Ancillary Services to Day-\n                Ahead Market\n        The prohibition under the CTC recovery mechanism against UDCs forward\ncontracting for any of their load outside of the PX markets further limits the ability of\nloads to be price responsive over longer time horizons than a day ahead-basis. This\nforward contracting prohibition on UDCs requires the vast majority of total ISO system\nload to the hedged on a day-ahead basis. An average of over 80% of total ISO load is\nhedged through the PX energy markets. This implies that over 80% of wholesale energy\npurchase commitments are being hedged on a day-ahead or hour-ahead basis, and\napproximately half of the remaining quantity of total ISO load is purchased at the real-\ntime ISO price. The remaining energy consumed is produced by non-UDC generators\nand sold through bilateral contracts.\n        This prohibition on forward contracting outside of the PX unnecessarily forces\nloads to hedge their forward energy requirements with no more advance notice than a\nday-ahead basis. While the recently introduced PX block forwards market for energy is\ntremendous step in the right direction, loads still need more opportunities to be price-\nresponsive with a longer lead-time that the day before delivery of energy takes place.\n        These limitations on forward contracting reduce the competitiveness of the\nCalifornia energy market. Most of the UDC’s load is known with a very high degree of\ncertainty far in advance of the day before the electricity is actually delivered to final\ncustomers, and for this reason the UDC would therefore prefer to have the option to\nhedge its load further in advance. By prohibiting forward contracting outside of the PX\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 87 of 148\n"  [89] "far in advance of the delivery date, a UDC unnecessarily gives up any advantage it has\nbecause of its superior information about the nature of its final demands in the near\nfuture. In a market with unrestricted forward contracting, the UDC would be able to\nexploit this superior information to obtain more attractive energy prices when signing\nforward financial commitments with generators. In a market which allows many\ndifferent avenues for forward financial contracting far in advance of delivery, loads\nwould negotiate larger forward financial commitments with generation owners during\nhours when they expect their demand for electricity to be unusually high. If UDCs have\nsome discretion as to when unexpected load increases can occur they may move them to\nthose periods when they are able sign particularly attractive forward hedge contracts.\nOnce these forward financial commitments are signed, generation owners holding the\nother side of the hedge contract will find it in their financial interest to bid more\naggressively in the day-ahead, hour-ahead and real-time energy markets. As shown in\nWolak (1999), these forward contracts commit generation unit owners to compete\naggressively to supply at least their forward financial positions made in the day-ahead,\nhour-ahead or real-time energy markets.15\n         On a day-ahead basis, UDCs have very limited opportunities to reduce their\npurchases of wholesale electricity. However, on a day-ahead basis it is very easy for a\ngeneration unit to reduce its supply of electricity. It simply shuts down. Therefore, on a\nday-ahead basis the threat of generation owners not supply into the market is far more\ncredible than the threat of loads not to purchase from the market. Consequently, during\nhours forecast to have a high total ISO demand, loads must purchase energy and ancillary\nservices on a day-ahead basis at very high prices. A year or even a month before the\nhour or hours under consideration, a load can plan in advance not to consume if it expects\nto pay very high prices. With enough advance notice, a load can commit not to consume\nelectricity for a significant period of time at a fairly low cost. The shorter the time lag,\nthe more costly it is for loads to reduce their demand for electricity and ancillary services.\nGiving loads more advance notice reduces the asymmetry in the bargaining position\nbetween generation owners and loads that occurs on day-ahead basis. Loads should\ntherefore be able purchase forward commitments for energy and ancillary services on\nmore favorable terms far in advance of delivery than on a day-ahead basis as is required\nduring the CTC recovery period. By restricting the forward contracting activities on the\npart of the UDCs, the ability of the new generation owners in the ISO control area to\nexercise market power in the day-ahead and hour-ahead energy and ancillary services\nmarkets is unnecessarily enhanced.\n         This asymmetric treatment of UDC load and generation relative to that of the new\ngeneration owners (NGOs) (who are not prohibited from forward contracting outside of\nthe PX market) unnecessarily handicaps UDCs in their attempts to limit the exercise of\nmarket power by the NGOs. Even if the UDCs are able to predict accurately more than\none day in advance that loads will be extremely high and the likelihood of the exercise of\nmarket power during several hours in that day will be very high, they must wait until the\n15\n   F.A.  [90] "day-ahead market to hedge their energy purchases and contract for their associated\nancillary services requirements. In the markets for most all products, consumers are\nallowed to benefit through lower prices by their ability to intelligently plan ahead for\nunforeseen market contingencies through their advance-purchasing decisions. The\nCalifornia market design prohibits UDCs and their retail customers from realizing many\nof these benefits from advance planning, even although the NGOs are able to contract to\nsell or purchase energy far in advance of the actual delivery date, in any manner they see\nfit and with any other market participant.\n        The prohibition on forward contracting outside of the PX also forces the ISO to\ntake an unnecessarily active role in the ancillary services market as the agent to purchase\nall ancillary services requirements for the PX on a day-ahead or hour-ahead basis. Under\ncurrent ISO rules all scheduling coordinators, including the PX, have the opportunity to\nself-procure their ancillary services requirements. The PX currently does not run a\nforward ancillary services market on behalf of their customers through which they could\nself-procure their own ancillary services requirements. For example, the PX could offer\nto pay all of the market participants whose capacity did not win in PX a some fraction of\nthe PX price for the right to use this capacity to meet some or all of its ancillary services\nrequirements. Rather than simply notifying the ISO of its day-ahead energy schedule and\nallowing the ISO to serve as its agent in purchasing ancillary services from the day-ahead\nand hour-ahead ancillary services markets, PX could become an active participant in\nancillary services markets.\n        This prohibition also puts the ISO in the uncomfortable position of needing to be\na strategic player in the ancillary services markets or face the prospect of extremely high\nprices in this market. Because total ISO load is largely exogenous to wholesale energy\nprices, the total hourly demand for ancillary services capacity is, for the most part,\nperfectly price inelastic. The ISO’s Rational Buyer algorithm has introduced price-\nresponsiveness for each ancillary service individually, but the total quantity of capacity\ndemanded is still inelastically demanded. Consequently, the ISO must take actions\nthrough its purchasing behavior in the day-ahead and hour-ahead markets to limit the\nability of other market participants to exercise market power in these markets.\nOtherwise, very high prices would occur in these markets during periods of high demand.\nBy eliminating the prohibition on forward contracting outside of the PX for ancillary\nservices and energy, the ISO would no longer need to be placed in this position. All\nloads in the ISO market would have the opportunity to self-procure their ancillary\nrequirements through long-term bilateral negotiations, forward financial contracts-for-\ndifferences linked to the day-ahead ancillary services price, or through inter-SC trades. If\na load did not like the forward contract for ancillary services that it had, it could switch to\nanother supplier whose terms it liked better. Under this scheme the ISO could be\neffectively eliminated from the process of ancillary services procurement. The ISO’s\nancillary services markets would simply become day-ahead and hour-ahead imbalance\nmarkets for ancillary services were market participants can buy or sell incremental\nancillary services capacity.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 89 of 148\n"  [91] "         We would still expect occasional price spikes in these incremental ancillary\nservices markets because of temporary capacity shortages and the associated scarcity\nvalue of generating assets. These should also continue to occur in the real-time energy\nmarket, as they do in all spot markets. However, it is important to note that under this\nforward contracting scheme, loads would only have to pay these very high prices for the\nincremental demand for ancillary services beyond the quantities they contracted for in\nadvance of the day-ahead or hour-ahead market, not for their entire ancillary services\ncapacity, as is the case under the current prohibition on forward contracting for ancillary\nservices outside of the PX.\n         As evidence that both generators and loads would prefer to hedge significantly\nless energy on a day-ahead basis than occurs under current CTC recovery mechanism, we\nnote that less than 20% of total annual electricity sales in the Nordic Power Exchange\n(Nordpool) are hedged through the day-ahead market.16 The Nordpool has been in\nexistence for almost ten years and has grown from initially serving just Norway to now\ninclude Sweden, Finland and Denmark, yet the annual fraction of energy hedged on a\nday-ahead basis has never been more than 20% of total annual sales. The vast majority\nof transactions on this market are arranged according to long-term contracts signed far in\nadvance of the day before the energy is delivered. This fact provides evidence consistent\nwith the view that the efficiency of the California energy and ancillary services markets\nwould be significantly enhanced if the prohibition on UDC forward contracting outside of\nthe PX was eliminated.\n         In closing, we would like to emphasize that we do not recommend that the current\nrequirement under the CTC mechanism that all UDCs use the PX as their scheduling\ncoordinator be eliminated. Particularly during the initial stages of the California market\nwhen many design flaws remain and others are yet to be discovered, the PX provides the\nextremely valuable service of providing a transparent and deep day-ahead market for\nenergy. Throughout the CTC recovery period, with the resulting market efficiencies that\nit creates, this very important role of the PX seems more than worth the potential\nproductive inefficiencies that may arise because of the PX’s statutory monopoly in\nproviding Scheduling Coordinator services to the UDCs for their load and generation.\n         C.       Separate Regulation of Wholesale and Retail Competition\n                  Can Harm Both Markets\n         In the United States, FERC regulates wholesale electricity supply and the state\npublic utilities commissions regulate retail electricity supply. As the above discussion\nhas illustrated in the restructured electricity industry in California, these two activities are\nhighly inter-related. A retail competition policy that does not foster the development of a\nprice-responsive hourly final retail demand will not result in a price-responsive hourly\nwholesale electricity demand. As has been discussed in the previous two MSC reports, a\n16\n   See Wolak, F.A., “Market Design and the Behavior of Prices in Restructured Electricity Markets: An\nInternational Comparison,” (1998),  [92] "price-response hourly wholesale electricity demand will significantly enhance the\ncompetitiveness of the California electricity market. However, as described above, many\nof the retail competition policies and stranded-asset recovery policies enacted at the state\nlevel are contrary to the goal of a price-response hourly wholesale electricity demand.\n        One example of such a policy is the CPUC decision to allow a direct access\ncustomers to switch from the UDC to an ESP without installing an hourly meter. Instead,\nthis customer is billed according to a representative load profile which effectively\nallocates the customer’s total monthly electricity consumption to all of the hours during\nthe month. These allocated hourly consumption amounts are then multiplied by a\nweighted-average hourly wholesale price to arrive at the customer’s estimated hourly cost\nand these are added together over all hours to yield that customer’s monthly bill for\nenergy. However, as is well known, a customer whose monthly bill is determined\naccording to a representative load profile receives the same cost savings from a 1 KWh\nreduction in consumption during an hour when the PX price is $700/MWh as he does for\nby 1 KWh reduction in an hour when the PX price is $0/MWh. Even in a world without\nthe CTC recovery mechanism, a customer billed according to a load profile has little\nincentive to substitute consumption away from hours in the month when PX or real-time\nISO prices are extremely high. This customer only has an incentive to reduce total\nmonthly consumption during months when the average wholesale energy prices are high.\nHowever, he will most likely do this during hours that when it is cost for him to reduce\ndemand in rather than hours when the PX or ISO price is extremely high, as would be\nrequired to have a price-responsive hourly retail demand. By allowing retail competition\nwith load profiling, virtually all of the financial incentives have been eliminated for any\nmarket participant to foster the formation of a price-responsive hourly final demand for\nelectricity vital for a workably competitive wholesale market during high ISO load\nperiods.\n        Without a retail market that has a large fraction of final demand facing an hourly\nprice for each unit of consumption during that hour that is tied directly to the wholesale\nprice of electricity during that hour, it is impossible for electricity suppliers to credibly\nbid into the day-ahead and real-time markets to reduce their demand in response to high\nwholesale prices. Currently, the UDCs and other market participants bid price-\nresponsive demands into the PX day-ahead and hour-ahead markets. However, all\nmarket participants know that the vast majority of these demand-side bids are not\ncredible commitments to reduce final demand in response to high prices. They\nunderstand that because all but a very small fraction of final customers in California\npurchase electricity at fixed retail prices, final UDC demand does not depend on the\nvalue of the hourly PX or ISO energy price. Therefore, any UDC load obligations that\nare not hedged in the PX day-ahead or hour-ahead markets must be purchased at the real-\ntime ISO price. Consequently, as noted in Section 3, during high periods of high ISO\nload, generation unit owners are able to set extremely high prices, with the only limit\nbeing the ISO’s purchase price cap.\n        Without coordination between the CPUC and FERC to foster a price-responsive\nhourly final demand for electricity, it will be extremely difficult to develop a price-\n                         MSC  [93] "responsive wholesale electricity demand to mitigate against the exercise of market power\nand reduce the frequency of extremely high wholesale electricity price spikes during\nperiods of high ISO load.\n         D.       Limiting Market Inefficiencies Caused by CTC Recovery\n                  Mechanism\n         The most direct way to eliminate the market inefficiencies caused by this\nmechanism is to end the rate freeze. As discussed above, because of the incentives\ncreated by the CTC recovery mechanism, very few final customers have an incentive to\nalter their hourly demand in response to high hourly wholesale prices. Therefore,\nthroughout of the rate freeze period, virtually all final customers are indifferent\nmovements in hourly wholesale energy and ancillary services prices. During this period,\nall generation owners (except the UDCs) prefer high hourly wholesale energy and\nancillary services prices. Only UDCs would prefer low wholesale electricity prices to\nincrease the amount of CTC payments they receive. However, none of the three UDCs\nbesides Pacific Gas and Electric own a significant quantity of flexible generation capacity\n(non-must-take capacity) to exert a substantial influence on wholesale energy or ancillary\nservices prices. Even Pacific Gas and Electric’s flexibility is severely limited during\ncertain times of the year because the most of its non-must-take capacity is hydroelectric.\nConsequently, for the remainder of the rate freeze, the economic agents with the greatest\nability to limit hourly wholesale prices—final customers—have virtually no incentive to\ndo so, and the only agents with any incentive to limit hourly wholesale prices have a very\nlittle ability to do so relative to the first year of the market, when all three UDCs owned a\nsignificantly larger quantity of flexible generation capacity.           All remaining market\nparticipants have strong incentives to take actions to set high wholesale prices.\n                  1.      Necessity of Maximum Purchase Price Caps During Rate Freeze\n         Other mechanisms must therefore be put in place in order to more quickly end the\nrate freeze period and the reduce the amount of time the market must tolerate the market\ninefficiencies described above. One such mechanism is a price-cap on the ISO’s real-\ntime energy market and the ancillary services markets. Because the retail price paid\nduring the rate freeze and CTC recovery period is fixed for the vast majority of\ncustomers, when total ISO load is high to due to hot weather or other factors, energy and\nancillary services prices can get extremely high. Generation unit owners know that even\nextremely high prices will be met with little, if any, reduction in total ISO load and\nancillary services demand. The only limit on the market-clearing prices during days of\nvery high total ISO load is the purchase price cap, which is frequently hit during several\nhours of the day in the real-time energy market and in several of the ancillary services\nmarkets.\n         If the authority of the ISO to set and adjust this purchase price cap is removed, it\nis unclear how high prices will go in these markets during the very high ISO load periods.\nThe non-UDC generation unit owners understand the very limited incentives final\ndemand has to respond to hourly prices during the rate freeze period and the limited\n                           MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 92 of 148\n"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
 [94] "ability the UDCs have to limit price spikes with their available generation capacity. They\nshould therefore correctly perceive that it is very unlikely that extremely high prices bid\ninto the real-time energy and ancillary services market will result in significantly less of\ntheir generation capacity being sold in these markets. Therefore, during the high total\nISO load days, there would be virtually no limit, besides ISO software constraints (which\ncan accept enormous bid prices) on how high a price might be set in the energy market or\nin any ancillary services market. The only way these high prices may cause final\nconsumers to reduce their demand is when wholesale prices are so high, for so many\nhours during the month, that total monthly CTC payments are in fact negative. This\nwould occur if the difference between monthly retail revenues and the sum of monthly\nwholesales energy costs, transmission and distribution costs, and the residual category\nexpenses is negative. Consequently, one very strong justification for the continued\nimposition of the ISO’s purchase price cap is the CTC cost recovery mechanism and\nassociated retail rate freeze. Until the incentives against developing retail competition\nand price-responsive hourly demand caused by the CTC mechanism are eliminated, ISO\nenergy and ancillary services markets without a purchase price cap are at risk for periods\nof enormous wholesale energy and ancillary services prices. These periods of high prices\nwill further delay the end of the rate freeze because CTC payments will comprise a\nsmaller fraction of monthly California retail electricity revenues, which lengthens the\ntime until the retail competition and a price-responsive final demand becomes a\nsignificant part of the California electricity industry.\n         Because of the potential for very high energy and ancillary prices without a\npurchase price cap during the rate freeze regime and the fact that frequent high prices will\ndelay the end of the rate freeze, a prudent policy would be to allow the ISO to continue\nhave the authority to set a maximum purchase price cap on the energy and ancillary\nservices markets. The logic presented above also argues in favor of a price cap that is\nshaded downward relative to the level of a “damage control” price cap, in order to speed-\nup the CTC recovery rate and shorten the length of time the California electricity market\nmust tolerate the market inefficiencies caused the CTC recovery mechanism. The very\nlimited incentive final demand has to respond to hourly wholesale energy and ancillary\nservices prices implies that whether the purchase price cap is set at $250/MWh or\n$750/MWh it will most likely be hit during the same the hours during the month.\nGeneration unit owners have a very good idea of what system load conditions allow them\nto hit the price cap. These load conditions are virtually independent of the level of the\nprice cap given the limited amount of price-responsive hourly final demand in the\nCalifornia market.\n                2.      Policies to Improve Efficiency of ISO Markets After End of Rate\n                        Freeze\n         The CPUC should prepare for the end of the retail rate freeze for all UDCs by\nputting in place policies that promote the form of retail competition necessary to increase\nthe competitiveness of the wholesale electricity market. There are three major policies\nthat should be put in place as soon as possible. The first is to end the prohibition on\nforward contracting outside the PX for all UDCs. The second is the elimination of any\ncost-based cap on retail electricity prices in the service area of any UDC that ends its rate\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 93 of  [95] "freeze.17 The third is the elimination of any regulated revenue recovery for electricity\nmeter installation, reading and repair for any UDC as soon as it ends its retail rate freeze.\n         The design of the California electricity market anticipates that the PX will face\ndirect competition from other scheduling coordinators once the rate freeze ends.\nHowever, for the reasons cited above, we believe it is prudent to continue the requirement\nthat all UDCs use the PX as their SC until the rate freeze ends for all UDCs. Continuing\nthe prohibition on forward contracting outside of the PX unnecessarily perpetuates the\nmarket inefficiencies described above. We believe that all prohibitions on forward\nfinancial contracting outside of the PX should end.\n         The end of the retail rate freeze is a very important event in the process of\nfostering meaningful competition for electricity supply and metering services. Recall the\nequation described above relating the rate freeze retail price to the CTC:\n                                           PR = PE + T&D + CTC + RES.\nAt the end of the rate freeze, the CTC component of this equation is set equal zero.\nBecause monthly the CTC contribution has been positive for all months since start-up of\nthe California market, there is an opportunity for significant price reductions as result of\nthe end of the rate freeze for customers in that UDC’s service area. However, as noted\nearlier, the availability of real-time metering technology and other information systems\nnecessary for final demand to become a more sophisticated participant in the California\nmarket is currently very limited and likely to stay so for remainder of the rate freeze\nperiod for the reasons described above.\n         However, policies can be put in place at the end of the rate freeze to provide\nmaximal incentives for final demand to become an active market participant, so that the\nfull benefits of retail and wholesale competition can be realized by all California\nconsumers. To this end, we recommend retail competition policies that will create the\nopportunities for the kinds of retail competition necessary for a workably competition\nwholesale electricity market. This policies should also increase the likelihood that\nvibrant retail competition will occur as rapidly as possible following the end of the rate\nfreeze period.\n         Two keys features of this retail competition policy are: (1) rely on competition\nwherever possible to limit retail prices, and (2) where output price caps are deemed\nnecessary to protect the UDC’s less sophisticated existing customers, do not set these\ncaps based on the UDC’s cost of production. By allowing competition rather than\nexplicit price regulation to limit retail prices, ESPs and the UDC have the maximal\nincentive to offer the full diversity of products and services consumers demand. One of\nthe anticipated benefits of retail competition is that it will create incentives for innovative\nways to provide electricity and other services in bundles that provide tangible benefits  [96] "retail customers. In order protect consumers who may be initially unwilling or\napprehensive about becoming active participants in the retail electricity market, we\nrecognize the necessity of a regulated default provider rate. However, for all of the\nreasons that cost-of-service regulation was abandoned in favor of competition, we believe\nthat this default provider rate should not be set based on the UDCs costs, but using a\nrevenue cap approach. Directly passing through wholesale energy and ancillary services\ncosts in a default provider rate significantly dulls the incentives for the retail competition\nto occur or result in the sort of final demand necessary for a workably competitive\nwholesale market. Fortunately, because of the structure of the CTC mechanism, the rate\nfreeze price can easily be used as a starting point for a revenue cap approach to setting\nthe default provider rate.\n         Therefore, we recommend that following the end of its rate freeze, the UDC be\nrequired to offer the rate freeze retail price or some fraction of this retail price to all\ncustomers as a default option. Otherwise, there should be no cap on the prices the UDC\nis allowed to charge its retail customers besides this requirement that the UDC continue\nto offer this modified rate freeze tariff option as the default provider rate. This modified\nrate freeze rate could be determined by taking the total amount of CTC dollars paid over\npast year by that UDC’s customers divided by the total amount electricity sold to these\ncustomers. Call this the average CTC recovery rate, CTCA. Some fraction of CTCA,\nsay 50%, could then be subtracted from the original rate freeze price to determine the\nnew default provider rate (DPR). Under this scheme, the DRP would be approximately\nanother 10% below the rate freeze average price. Customers that choose not to switch to\nan alternative ESP or to different tariff structure with the UDC should be able to purchase\ntheir electric according to the DPR.\n         There should be no restrictions on the other tariffs the UDC is allowed offer, or\nthe tariffs that other ESPs offer. Specifically, the UDC should be allowed to offer a tariff\nwith average prices for electricity above the DPR. Unless this tariff involves the\nprovision of additional value-added services that a customer values highly, we would not\nexpect a customer to choose this tariff over the DPR. Tariffs that do not deliver\nconsumer benefits will not exist for long. First, any ESP has the option to undercut the\nrate offered by the UDC and provide the same or superior services, if the UDC is making\nexcessive profits from certain tariff. Second, if the consumer is not receiving any benefit\nfrom these the supposed value-added services bundled with a new tariff, he can always\nelect to purchase electricity under the DPR. A higher priced tariff can only survive\nbecause the UDC or ESP offers a bundle products and services that the customer finds\nsuperior to the DPR.\n         The UDC should also have the opportunity to offer tariffs with average prices\nbelow the DPR. Clearly, this option also exists for ESPs. It is certainly possible to do so\nbecause the UDC and other ESPs in that service area no longer have to pay the CTC\ncharge per unit of electricity delivered to final customers. We would expect that\ncompetition among the ESPs and the UDC to provide bares-bones retail electricity would\ndrive average prices to something approximating the average wholesale price of\nelectricity plus T&D and the RES expenses. However, by placing no restrictions on retail\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 95 of 148\n"  [97] "prices set by the UDC (besides the requirement to offer the DPR) creates the possibility\nof a retail margin from serving some classes of customers during the initial period\nfollowing the end of the rate freeze. A retail margin is necessary to justify many of the\nup-front investments necessary for new and existing retail competitors to provide value-\nadded retail services such as hourly metering and real-time load-monitoring information\nsystems to final customers.\n        Mandating that the UDC offer a default provider rate that passes through a\nweighted average of the hourly wholesale energy and ancillary services prices using\nrepresentative load-profiles eliminates the incentive for the development of these value-\nadded services. This in turn, eliminates any opportunities for the price-responsive hourly\nfinal demand necessary for a price-responsive hourly wholesale electricity demand and a\nworkably competitive wholesale electricity market. This cost-of-service regulation\ndefault provider strategy is unnecessary if one believes that retail competition is viable.\nWe believe that the international experience from markets further along than California\nprovides ample evidence on the viability of retail competition. The competitive process\ncan be relied upon to offer this bare-bones retail pricing option if this is what retail\ncustomers demand. However, mandating a wholesale price pass-through rate for all\ncustomers virtually guarantees that any benefits from retail competition will be delayed\nalmost indefinitely and the adoption of real-time metering and electricity load monitoring\nand control information technology dramatically slowed.\n        A strategy that should provide more long-term consumer benefits is to rely on the\ncompetitive process to set the diversity of price and service quality options for final retail\ncustomers with the DPR option described above. Competition among ESPs and the\nUDCs should then allow customers to find the combination of price, metering\ntechnology, information systems (e.g., mechanisms for notifying customers of wholesale\nprices and technologies for automating their response) and other product characteristics\nthat best suit their preferences. One of goal of introducing competition into a former\nmonopoly industry is to serve the full diversity of consumer demands by offering a far\nwider range of products than the former monopolist. Those electricity retailers (ESPs or\nthe UDC) that provide true value-added to consumers in their retail product offerings will\nbe profitable and remain in the industry. Those that contribute no value-added will exit\nthe industry. Only by allowing this competitive sorting out process to take place will the\nfull benefits of retail competition come to pass in a timely manner. The end of the CTC\ncollection mechanism provides this opportunity.\n        Perhaps the most complex and difficult aspect of fostering retail competition is\ndetermining how much to charge each entity for metering services. One way to think of\nthe UDC’s existing metering infrastructure is as a stranded asset that is likely to be\nuneconomic on a going forward basis in the new competitive retail market. Clearly,\nremote metering reading technologies are more cost-effective on a going-forward basis\nthan the labor-intensive procedures currently used. Consequently, one way to handle the\nissue of charging ESPs for metering services, is to include any remaining unrecovered\nmeter installation costs on the UDC’s accounts as a stranded asset. Once the rate freeze\nends the UDC no longer receives any regulated cost recovery for meter installation,\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 96 of 148\n"  [98] "reading and repair costs. An equivalent alternative that does not involve creating\nadditional stranded assets allows the recovery of any remaining historical metering\ninstallation costs in the UDC’s regulated distribution rates, but includes new meter\ninstallation costs and meter reading and repair costs in the competitive supply side of the\nUDC’s business. These costs must then be recovered out of retail rates, rather from the\nregulated distribution tariff. Coupled with the above recommendation of only requiring\nthe post-rate-freeze UDC to offer the DPR described up, shifting all metering services to\nthe competitive side of the UDC’s business creates additional opportunities for\ncompetitive entry into the provision of hourly metering services and the associated\ninformation systems necessary to use these hourly meters to manage the customer’s\nelectricity consumption in response to hourly prices.\n        One aspect of the mechanism by which real-time metering technology creates a\ncompetitive wholesale electricity market in California deserves emphasis. For the\nbeneficial effects of a price-responsive final demand to effect the bidding behavior of\ngeneration owners, total consumption over some time horizon does not have to be lower\nas a result of high prices during some hours of that time period. What is more important\nto disciplining the exercise of market power is that demand be able to shift hourly\nconsumption from hours when prices are high to hours when prices are low. Although\nthe ability to reduce total daily consumption in response to high prices during the day is\ncertainly desirable, the major benefit of a price-responsive wholesale demand in\ndisciplining generator bidding behavior is the ability to shift demand to other hours in the\nday in response to high prices, thus creating a more price-elastic aggregate hourly\nwholesale electricity demand.\n        A more price-responsive aggregate hourly wholesale electricity demand function\nwill cause all generation owners to bid more aggressively into the wholesale electricity\nmarket. These firms know that if they bid too high they will not be dispatched in that\nhour because a significant amount of load will decide not to consume during that hour in\nresponse to high prices. By this logic, it is easy to see that all loads, even those that are\nnot price-responsive on an hourly basis, benefit in terms of lower prices and reduced\nprice volatility from a significant amount of price-responsive demand in the market. This\nsuggests that there are benefits accruing to all consumers from the existence of price-\nresponsive consumers, and that a significant fraction of these benefits are not captured by\nthe customers providing them. This positive externality that price-responsive customers\nprovide to all other customers implies that it may be desirable to subsidize the installation\nof hourly metering technology. For many customers the private benefit of installing\nhourly meters does not exceed the private cost, but the social benefit to that customer\nfrom installing an hourly meter may exceed his private cost.\n8.  [99] "generator compliance with ISO system operator dispatch instructions.              This non-\ncompliance took two forms.\n        In the first, a market participant would promise specific quantity of generating\ncapacity that met certain technical specifications, yet they would be unable to deliver this\nquantity of capacity according to these technical specification when called to do so. One\nsuch example of this problem occurred frequently in the Regulation reserve market. A\ngenerator might bid to supply 100MW of upward regulation and all of this capacity\nwould win in the ancillary services market. However, after 50 MW of the upward\nregulation capacity purchased was used and ISO requested that the unit regulate upward\nfurther, the generating unit would notify the ISO that certain modifications of the unit\nwere necessary before it could proceed to this higher level of regulation and that these\nmodifications would take a some time to implement. Under the ISO’s current ancillary\nservices market software, there is no way to detect and modify or reject a regulation bid\nof this type. Consequently, this created the need to purchase a larger nominal quantity of\nregulation reserve to insure that the ISO had sufficient regulation capacity that met the\ntechnical specifications necessary to meet its reserve requirements.\n        The second form of non-compliance occurred primarily in the real-time energy\nmarket. This problem arose primarily during periods of very high ISO prices. Under\nthese circumstances, when generators were quite certain that the hourly ex post price for\nimbalance energy would be quite high, they would begin to supply more than their day-\nahead energy schedule in anticipation of being paid for this according to an attractive\nhourly imbalance price. When this activity occurred on a large enough scale, it could\ncreate an oversupply of energy to the ISO grid so that the ISO system operator would\nthen have to call on decremental bids in the real-time energy bid stack. However, at these\ntimes, generators in the real-time bid stack were extremely reluctant to reduce their\ngeneration given that they knew net energy imbalances would be paid for at an attractive\nex post real-time price. Consequently, unit operators often did not comply with the\nterms implied by their decremental energy bids. The ISO system operator would then\nhave to move down to the next unit owner in the BEEP sequence while the over-\ngeneration situation became even more extreme. The likelihood of this non-compliance\nwith obligations associated with bidding into the real-time energy market further\nincreased the ISO’s demand for reserve capacity to guard against shortages of available\ngeneration to manage the grid in real-time.\n        It is important to bear in mind that the vast majority of these interactions between\nthe ISO operations staff and generation unit owners took place via the telephone.\nTherefore the amount of time spent attempting to find some generating unit willing to\nsupply the service usually made system reliability problem even larger. Guarding against\nthis compounding of problems due to time delays when non-compliance occurred further\nincreased the nominal demand for ancillary services reserve capacity.\n        Although it is difficult to quantify the cost of these non-compliance problems, it is\neasy to imagine instances when the costs can be extremely large. To address these issues,\nthe ISO is in the process of implementing the Automated Notification, Acknowledgement\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 98 of 148\n"
