[100] "and Logging Operations Program Environment (ANALOPE) to provide clear,\nindisputable dispatch instructions from the ISO to its market participants and an\nautomated repository of responses to those instructions. ANALOPE is designed to\nintegrate with the operation of the real-time energy market to accomplish a timely and\ntransparent dispatch. It will log, archive, and easily retrieve all information associated\nwith the dispatch process. ANALOPE will send an electronic dispatch instruction to a\nSC, receive response acknowledgement, log the transaction, and store the information to\nsupport dispute resolution. The information collected from ANALOPE will be essential\nto resolving disputes over non-compliance with ISO dispatch instructions or technical\nspecifications for the provision of an ancillary service.\n        In order to eliminate non-compliance behavior to the greatest extent possible, we\nencourage the ISO to publicize particularly egregious instances to all market participants\nand impose the maximum penalties possible under the terms of the ISO tariff.\n        Additional aspect of the non-compliance problem in the real-time energy stack is\ncurrently acknowledged and tolerated by the ISO system operator in an effort to increase\nthe depth of the real-time energy bid stack. Although the BEEP process dispatches\nresources in ten-minute intervals based on economic merit, in practice the ISO has been\naccommodating in this process several pre-dispatching resources with minimum run-time\nrequirements such as: (1) interties, (2) large base-load units, (3) hydro resources for water\nmanagement, and (4) gas turbines. These resources are dispatched for the whole hour\nwhether they are in the 10-minute BEEP stack or not. Currently, resources pre-\ndispatched in-sequence with minimum run-time requirements set the real-time market-\nclearing price for each of the six, ten-minute intervals in the hour, even if these resources\nare not marginal. Resources pre-dispatched in-sequence receive payments, or charge,\nbased on 10-minute BEEP market-clearing prices, not hourly ex post prices. Resources\npre-dispatched out-of-sequence receive payments, or charge, based on “as bid” prices.\nResources pre-dispatched out-of-market receive payment, or charge, based on Hourly Ex\nPost prices. This process of accepting bids with minimum run-times requirments has\ncreated an undue reliance on dispatcher’s judgement in determining which bids to accept,\nand because this judgement affects the hourly ex post price, this has lead to disputes\nbetween the ISO and market participants. Given the ISO market rules, allowing this\nform of non-compliance is unnecessary.\n        While during the initial stages of the ISO’s existence, it may have been necessary\nto compromise the market rules to insure that sufficient generation was available to\nmaintain system balance at all times and points in the grid, this is no longer necessary or\nadvisable. Under the current ISO rules, loads with minimum run-time requirements can\nparticipate in the ISO market by paying for deviations from 10-minute instructions given\nby the ISO according to the provisions of the current ISO tariff, under the same\nconditions that generating units without minimum run-time requirements now participate\nin the real-time energy market. Both types of generating units have the opportunity to\ndeviate from their hour-ahead energy schedules and ignore ISO dispatch instructions in\nreal-time if it is in their financial interest to do so. The ISO tariff charges resources\ndifferentially for instructed and uninstructed deviations from schedule to provide\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 99 of 148\n" [101] "incentives for resources to follow real-time dispatch instructions. There are no further\npenalties for either type of deviation. By symmetric treatment of all resources using the\ncurrent ISO rules these slow-response resources can maintain their minimum run-time\nrequirement, yet bear they full cost that this requirement imposes on the real-time energy\nmarket. By treating these resources differently from resources that are able to respond\nmore quickly, the ISO is subsidizing slow-responding resources at the expense of quick-\nresponding resources. This differential treatment also dulls the incentive these slow-\nresponding resources have to undertake the investments or regulatory rule changes\nnecessary to become more responsive to 10-minute dispatch instructions. A frequent\ncomplaint of market participants is the lack of transparency in the real-time energy stack.\nGenerators complain that they often do not understand why a bid to produce in real-time\nwas not accepted. By treating all resources symmetrically in the BEEP dispatch process,\nmuch of this lack of transparency will be eliminated.\n        It is our understanding the ISO is currently considering a proposal to dispatch all\nresources on 10-minute dispatch interval and streamline payment or charge methods\nthroughout the 10-minute interval for all resources. For the reasons discussed above, we\nstrongly support this proposal.\n        As the California market matures, the ISO should continue to take steps to\ntransfer more of the risk associated with maintaining system reliability to those market\nparticipants best able to manage it. Because the California market design allows\ngenerators and loads the flexibility to deviate from their hour-ahead energy schedules and\nmake up the imbalances in the real-time energy market, the ISO must use financial\nincentives to manage the system in real-time. This is a major strength of the California\nmarket design relative markets where generators are explicitly penalized for deviations\nfrom day-ahead commitments. Generators in the California market are not unduly\nconstrained by day-ahead commitments should system conditions change from those\nanticipated on a day-ahead basis. However, this strength can be one of the market\ndesign’s greatest weaknesses if the economic signals generators receive in real time are\nnot closely matched with current conditions in the ISO system. For example, suppose\nelectricity demand in the ISO grid is currently rising, yet real-time energy prices are low\nbecause of delays in reflecting electricity supply and demand conditions in the real-time\nprice of electricity. This lag in system operations between economic signals to generators\nand the current supply and demand condition within the grid can increase rather than\ndecrease the shortfall between electricity supply and demand. Consequently, given the\nCalifornia market design, it is extremely important to the efficiency of the ISO’s market\nthat the physical condition of system as closely as possible match the financial conditions\nin market. For this reason, increasing the responsiveness of all resources or making them\npay the full cost of their lack of responsiveness is critical to the success of the California\nmarket design.\n [102] "9.       Intra-Zonal Congestion Management, New Zone Creation, and\n         Interconnection by New Generators\n     This section deals with three interrelated issues: (1) intra-zonal congestion\nmanagement, (2) the conditions for new congestion zone creation, and (3) the terms and\nconditions under which a new generation owner can interconnect with the ISO grid. The\nfirst issue has to do with the day-to-day operation of the ISO grid, while the second two\nhave to do more with the long-term operation of the California electricity industry.\nCurrent ISO policies for creating a new congestion zone depend on the frequency of\ncongestion along transmission paths within an existing congestion zone on a six-month or\nannual basis. Consequently, the incentives that generators have for managing intra-zonal\ncongestion directly impact the number of new congestion zones and when and where\neach new congestion zone is created. Continuing this logic, the timing and location of\nnew congestion zones and the methods for managing congestion within these zones is a\nmajor factor in new generation location decisions within the ISO grid. For these reasons,\nwe believe these issues should be dealt with in a sequential manner, because the proper\nintra-zonal congestion management policy will make formulating a new zone creation\npolicy significantly more straightforward. An intra-zonal congestion management policy\nthat provides the best incentives to eliminating intra-zonal congestion combined with a\nnew zone creation policy that does not unnecessary favor new or existing entrants will\nsimplify the process of formulating a new generation connection policy.\n     The major market design flaws identified in this section are:\n1. The ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion management policy rewards the creation\n     and subsequent mitigation of intra-zonal congestion. For certain grid conditions,\n     strategically located generators can earn significant revenues from causing and then\n     mitigating intra-zonal congestion.\n2. Under ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion management policy, no market participant\n     has any incentive to eliminate intra-zonal congestion. Intra-zonal congestion costs\n     are simply a cost of selling energy in that congestion zone.\n3. The ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion management policies make an artificial\n     distinction between intra-zonal congestion management and local grid reliability.\n     Supplying energy to relieve intra-zonal congestion or for local grid reliability reasons\n     are observational equivalent from an economic perspective. In both cases, generation\n     units are being called to supply energy out of the bid sequence within a zone.\n4. The ISO’s new zone creation policy does attempt to control for the extent to which\n     the frequency of intra-zonal congestion along a transmission path depends on the\n     economic incentives faced by generators within the congestion zone. A major\n     determinant of the frequency of congestion along a transmission path (besides load\n     conditions on either side of the path) is the profitability of intra-zonal congestion on\n     this path to generation unit owners on either side of the path.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 101 of 148\n" [103] "5. The opportunities for generators to exercise market power in the ISO’s day-ahead\n    ancillary services markets are considerably enhanced during periods when ancillary\n    services are procured on a zonal versus a statewide basis.\nOur major recommendations for correcting these market design flaws are:\n1. Revise ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion management protocols in one of the\n    following two ways:\n    •    Contract in advance for generation units to provide intra-zonal congestion relief\n         services on an annual basis at variable cost for an up-front annual payment similar\n         to the current RMR contracts. Procure these services through an annual\n         competitive bidding process which involves loads and transmission operators.\n    •    Manage intra-zonal congestion by using RMR units to supply the incremental\n         generation to relieve the intra-zonal congestion unless the unrestricted zonal\n         market can provide this energy. Generators are decremented according to their\n         bid prices to relieve intra-zonal congestion, but they must buy back the\n         decremental energy at the ex post hourly real-time price, not their decremental bid\n         price.\n2. Do not implement a policy to mitigate intra-zonal congestion in the forward market\n    until a policy with strong incentives to eliminate real-time intra-zonal congestion is in\n    place. Otherwise, generators may very likely be able to create intra-zonal congestion\n    in the forward market, get paid to relieve it, and then create it again in the real-time\n    market and get paid to relieve it there as well.\n3. Because of the increased opportunities to exercise market power in small congestion\n    zones, do not create any new congestion zones, including the current proposed\n    congestion zone south of Path 26 as a way to reduce intra-zonal congestion costs.\n    Unless creating a new congestion zone substantially improves the system reliability,\n    this process should be delayed until there is sufficient experience with the revised\n    intra-zonal congestion management protocols. An intra-zonal congestion management\n    policy that has incentives for all or some generators to eliminate intra-zonal\n    congestion should significantly reduce the frequency of intra-zonal congestion and\n    therefore eliminate the need to create a new congestion zone.\n4. Any viable new generation connection policy must contain a policy for managing\n    intra-zonal congestion. For the reasons discussed above, any analysis of the\n    economic efficiency properties of any new generation connection policy will crucially\n    depend on the intra-zonal congestion management policy in force.\n    The remainder of this section describes the current ISO policy for intra-zonal\ncongestion management and the incentives it creates for generator behavior. We then\npresent evidence from the operation of the ISO markets over the past year which\nillustrates the significantly increased opportunities for the exercise market power in the\n [104] "ISO’s day-ahead ancillary services market when they are cleared on a zonal basis. This\nfollowed by a discussion of the ISO’s new zone creation policy, with specific application\nto the zone south of Path 26. We then discuss the ISO’s new generation connection\nproposals.\n    We then turn to our recommendations for a revising the current intra-zonal congestion\nmanagement protocols. The incentives for generator behavior provided by each policy\nare described. A discussion of the pros and cons of each proposal follow. We then give\nthe rationale underlying our recommendation against new zone creation as means to\nreduce intra-zonal congestion costs using our methodology for determining workably\ncompetitive congestion zones described in Section 13. Finally, we discuss the ISO’s new\ngeneration connection proposal, and the logic underlying our recommendation that it\nmust contain an mechanism for giving market participants the incentive to eliminate\nintra-zonal congestion.\n         A.        Current Intra-Zonal Congestion Management Policy\n         In order to gain a better understanding of the intra-zonal congestion problem in\nthe California, it is instructive to clarify the distinction between intra-zonal congestion\nand inter-zonal congestion. The ISO’s market-clearing process uses incremental and\ndecremental energy bids within the same SC to relieve inter-zonal congestion in both the\nday-ahead, hour-ahead and real-time markets. This implies that the outcome of accepting\ndecremental bids on one side of a inter-zonal transmission path and incremental bids on\nthe other side of the zonal transmission path will increase the market-clearing price in one\nzone and decrease the market-clearing price in the other congestion zone. Higher\nincremental energy bids lead to higher market-clearing zonal prices on the uncongested\nside of the path and lower decremental bids lead to lower market-clearing prices on the\ncongested side of the path. In contrast, under the ISO’s current intra-zonal congestion\nmanagement protocols, if the markets on both sides of the intra-zonal path are deemed\nworkably competitive, then the generator with the lowest incremental energy bid that can\nrelieve this congestion is paid his bid price for the additional energy generated. The\ngenerator with the highest decremental energy price that can relieve this congestion buys\nback the necessary energy at his bid price. If either side of the intra-zonal path is not\ndeemed workably competitive, then RMR units, if they are available, are used to relieve\nintra-zonal congestion on that side of transmission path.18\n         Neither bid prices nor the RMR variable payment rates (if RMR units are used to\nrelieve intra-zonal congestion) sets the zonal market-clearing price. By definition of\nintra-zonal congestion, one or both of these dispatch instructions are out-of-merit-order\nbecause there are lower-priced incremental energy bids and/or higher-priced decremental\nbids within the congestion zone that cannot be taken because they cannot relieve the\nintra-zonal congestion. Due to their location in the grid, only certain generators can\nrelieve the intra-zonal congestion, so their bids are the only ones that can be accepted.\nThe generator called out-of-merit-order in the real-time energy bid curve will not affect\n18\n   Currently the only intra-zonal congestion path deemed to have workably competitive generation markets\non both sides is the Path 26 interface.\n [105] "the hourly price of energy in that zone. Total hourly intra-zonal congestion costs are paid\nby all SCs serving load in that congestion zone and exporting power from that congestion\nzone in proportion to the amount of electricity they consume or export during that hour,\nregardless of the location of the resources used to mitigate the intra-zonal congestion. As\nconsequence, intra-zonal congestion costs simply become an unavoidable cost paid by all\nSCs serving load in that congestion zone. There is no way for any SC serving load in that\narea to reduce its intra-zonal congestion costs without also reducing the intra-zonal\ncongestion costs of its competitors in that zone by exactly the same amount per unit of\nelectricity sold.\n        These rules for managing intra-zonal congestion create the following incentive for\nday-ahead scheduling and bidding into the supplemental energy market. Assume that\nduring a given hour, a 500 MW generator must sell its power along a path with 200 MW\nof remaining capacity. Suppose the day-ahead market has been run and the zonal price of\nenergy is $20/MWh and this generator won a hedge quantity of 500 MWh at this price.\nThis generator then schedules 500 MW of capacity along a path that can only take 200\nMW. Suppose that this generator is the only facility that can alleviate congestion along\nthis path in real time and it bids $10/MWH for decremental energy. When the ISO\nattempts to dispatch energy in real-time it will be forced to take the generator’s\ndecremental bid of $10/MWH for 300 MW of capacity, because only 200 MW of the 500\nMW scheduled can actually be produced in real-time.                   This generator pays\n($10/MWh)*(300 MWh) = $3000 to buy back the 300 MW of capacity that it cannot\ndeliver in real-time. Consequently, a generator that knew it was only able to sell 200\nMWh along the path receives (500 MWh)*$20/MWh = $10,000 for day-ahead energy\nsales, and net revenues from both these and the real-time purchase of 300 MW at\n$10/MWh, of $7000. Despite the fact that the day-ahead zonal price was $20/MWh, by\nscheduling capacity in this manner, the generator was able to receive an average price of\n$7,000/200MWh = $35/MWh for the energy it sold during that hour.\n        How confident a generator is that it owns the only facility that can alleviate the\nintra-zonal congestion will determines the level of its decremental bid price. For\nexample, a generator that knows with virtual certainty that it owns the only unit that can\nrelieve the intra-zonal congestion may bid the negative real-time energy price cap of\n-$750/MWh for decremental energy. In this case, the generation would be paid\n$750/MWh for each MWh that it sells back to the ISO in real time. This case the\ngenerator would receive $225,000 = ($750/MWH)*300 MW for these decremental\nenergy purchases in addition to the $10,000 for day-ahead energy sales for an average\nprice for 200 MWh of energy delivered of $1,175/MWh = $235,000/200 MWh.\nAlthough this example may seem to be extreme, during the first few weeks of June 1999\na generator was in this very favorable position for many hours and frequently submitted\ndecremental energy bids at the negative real-time energy price cap at that time of\n-$250/MWh.\n        The profitability of the above strategy relies on the fact that: (1) generators are\npaid their decremental bid to reduce the amount of energy they are willing to produce in\nreal time, and (2) only a small number of generation owners are able to relieve this intra-\nzonal congestion. If there were a large number of firms able to relieve the intra-zonal\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 104 of 148\n" [106] "congestion, then we would expect competition among market participants to raise the\nprice of decremental energy bids. Viewed from this perspective, we can see that there is\nno meaningful distinction between an RMR call for local reliability reasons and an RMR\ncall to mitigate intra-zonal congestion when the market to relieve intra-zonal congestion\non one side of the transmission path is not workably competitive. In both cases the\ngeneration unit owner is the only entity, or one of a very small number of entities, that\ncan provide this essential service. If a spot market was run for the provision of this\nservice, then the generator could bid virtually any price to provide either service--intra-\nzonal congestion mitigation services or local grid reliability services—and it must be\ntaken.\n        Consequently, intra-zonal congestion mitigation in the case that the market on one\nside of the path is not workably competitive is observationally equivalent to the provision\nof local reliability services in those instances when a generator’s location in the grid\nmakes a minimal amount of energy from it essential to maintain the integrity of the grid.\nFor the case in which the uncongested side of the path is not workably competitive, the\nlevel of output from this unit necessary for local grid reliability is amount supplied after\nthe increase in generation necessary to relieve the intra-zonal congestion. In the case in\nwhich the congested side of the path is not workably competitive, the level of output from\nthis unit necessary for local grid reliability is the amount supplied after the decrease in\noutput necessary to relieve the intra-zonal congestion.\n        Although the vast majority of intra-zonal congestion costs during the first year\nISO operation was due to congestion along Path 26, over the past few months intra-zonal\ncongestion has frequently occurred on many other transmission paths. In addition,\ndespite concerns about the competitiveness of the energy market one or both sides of\nthese paths, there are often no RMR units which can be used to relieve this intra-zonal\ncongestion. Consequently, the prospects for larger intra-zonal costs along many paths in\nthe ISO control area over the coming year may result in the creation of more congestion\nzones. However, as shown above, because no market participant has an incentive to\nreduce intra-zonal congestion costs, yet, depending on system conditions, all generation\nunit owners have an incentive to cause intra-zonal congestion. The ISO’s intra-zonal\ncongestion management protocols should be revised to create incentives for market\nparticipants to eliminate intra-zonal congestion.\n        B.      Competitiveness of ISO’s Zonal Ancillary Services Market\n        The advantage of the ISO’s zonal market design is that if market participants have\nthe strong incentives not to cause intra-zonal and inter-zonal congestion, then competition\namong market participants to supply energy and ancillary services will be over the largest\nmarket possible. This implies that generators will have strong incentives to bid\naggressively to win in the statewide market for energy and ancillary services. However,\nwhen either inter-zonal or intra-zonal congestion occurs, this creates smaller markets for\nthe provision of both energy and ancillary services. Under these conditions, a generation\nunit owner may be able to exercise significantly greater market power over the smaller\nmarket that occurs as a result congestion.\n                        MSC [107] "        We investigate the extent that this logic is true for the ISO’s ancillary services\nmarkets in two ways. In the first, we compare market-clearing zonal prices for ancillary\nservices when the ISO’s markets clear on a zonal basis versus statewide, controlling for\ndifferences in total ISO load across these two market outcomes. In the second analysis,\nwe compared the monthly frequency that at least one of the three IOUs or at least one the\nof the new generation owners was pivotal in the ISO’s ancillary services markets when\nthe markets were cleared statewide versus on a zonal basis.\n        Our methodology for determining the impact of zonal market-clearing on zonal\nancillary services prices uses the regression equation used to determine the average ISO-\nload-adjusted ancillary services prices last summer versus this past summer discussed in\nSection 3. The only difference is that we estimate separate equations for each congestion\nzone, separately for the period from June 1, 1998 to December 31, 1998 and for the\nperiod January 1, 1999 to August 17, 1999. The dependent variable in each regression is:\nPAS(c,i,j) = the market-clearing day-ahead price for ancillary services i, for congestion\n        zone c, during hour j\n        The variable of interest in this case is the coefficient associated with\nCONG(j) = an indicator variable that equals one if the ISO procures ancillary services on\n        a zonal basis.\nThe coefficient associated with this variable measures the ISO-load-adjusted difference in\nancillary services prices in the congestion zone that results from procuring ancillary\nservices on a zonal basis. For each congestion zone and each hour for the 1998 and 1999\nseparate sample periods, we regress PAS(c,i,j) on a constant term, a sixth order\npolynomial in ISOLOAD(j), a complete set of DAY, HOUR, MONTH indicator\nvariables, and the indicator variable CONG(j).\n        Table 7 reports the values of the coefficient associated with CONG and associated\nstandard errors for the NP15 and SP15 congestion zones for the June 1, 1998 to\nDecember 31, 1998 time period. The results presented in this table tell a very plausible\nstory about the impact of zonal procurement of ancillary services in light of the CTC\nrecovery mechanism in place and the large amount of generation capacity in the NP15\ncongestion zone owned by Pacific Gas and Electric for much of 1998. When ancillary\nservices were procured on a zonal basis, prices tended to be significantly higher in SP15,\nwhich is consistent with the fact that NGOs, who receive greater revenues from higher\nancillary services prices, owned the vast majority of capacity able to provide ancillary\nservices in SP15. In NP15, zonal procurement of ancillary services led to lower prices.\nThis is consistent with the fact that over the majority of this sample period Pacific Gas\nand Electric was the major supplier of ancillary services in the NP15 and its incentives\nare to keep energy and ancillary services prices low in order to increase its CTC recovery.\nThe conclusion to be drawn from this time period is that the overall impact of zonal\nprocurement is ambiguous. Those in NP15 tend to pay less and those in SP15 tend to pay\nmore.\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 106 of 148\n" Because all bidders submit their ancillary services bids at the\n         same time, a bidder can only learn if it is pivotal after all bids have been submitted.\n                 Figure 55 repeats our construction of a residual demand curve for the case in\n         which the bidder is pivotal. In this case, SO(p), the supply curve of all other market\n         participants besides the firm under consideration, becomes vertical before it crosses the\n         aggregate demand curve QD. For simplicity, we have drawn aggregate demand to be\n         completely price inelastic. For the reasons discussed above, this is not an unrealistic\n         assumption for the aggregate demand for of any of the ISO’s ancillary services markets\n         over the time period we study. The resulting residual demand curve for the firm is\n         DR(p). The minimum amount that SO(p) falls short of QD is equal to QP. This implies\n         that the firm faces a completely price inelastic residual demand for the quantity QP. From\n         the diagram it is clear that the firm earns the greatest revenues by bidding all of its\n         capacity at the price cap of Pmax. This strategy sets the market price at Pmax and earns the\n         unit owner (Pmax)x(QP) in total revenues. Consequently, during periods in which a\n         generator estimates that with very high probability it is pivotal, this is the optimal supply\n         bid function so long as QP is not too small. Note that the larger Pmax is the smaller QP can\n         be and still result in the optimal bidding strategy being all of the generator’s remaining\n         capacity at the price cap.\n [110] "        In a market without a price cap, if a generator knows with very high probability\nthat during a certain hour it will be pivotal then there should be no upper bound on its\neconomically optimal bid price. (There may be other constraints on how high a price a\ngeneration unit owner can bid.) What the generator loses on the volume of sales, it can\nmake up in the bid price for those sales. To the extent that a market participant is able to\naccurately forecast when it will be pivotal and the frequency that this event occurs are\nboth measure of the extent of potential market power possessed by that market\nparticipant. It seems reasonable to assume that if the event occurs more frequently, then\nit should be easier for the market participant to forecast when this event will occur.\nConsequently, we take the frequency of this event as our measure of potential market\npower.\n        Because of confidentiality concerns we do not report pivotal bidder frequency by\nindividual market participants. First, when the ancillary services\nmarkets were cleared on a statewide basis the pivotal bidder frequencies for the summer\nof 1998 were significantly higher than the pivotal bidder frequencies for the summer of\n1999. The other conclusion that holds across both years, is that when the markets are\ncleared on a zonal basis, the pivotal bidder frequency is significantly higher than when\nthe markets clear on a statewide basis. These results argue in favor of the view that the\nmany of the market structure and market rule changes over the past year have reduced the\nextent of market power in the ancillary services market. However, there are two\nimportant caveats associated with this conclusion. The first is that when markets clear on\na zonal basis, even during the summer of 1998, the pivotal bidder frequencies are\nextremely high for several ancillary services. Second, some portion of the reduction in\npivotal bidder frequencies for both the IOUs and NGOs when these markets clear on a\nstatewide basis between the summer of 1998 and summer of 1999 can be attributed to the\nreduced demand for ancillary services in 1999 due to mild weather conditions. A major\nreason for the lower pivotal bidder frequencies in the day-ahead ancillary services\nmarkets in 1999 is the ISO’s policy, implemented in April 1999, to delay some day-ahead\npurchases to the hour-ahead market in order to lower total ancillary services costs and\nincreased the liquidity of the hour-ahead market. These results provide significant\nevidence that this strategy has be effective at reducing the potential for generation unit\nowners to exercise market power in the day-ahead ancillary services markets.\n         C.     ISO New Zone Creation Policy\n         ISO’s tariff allows for the creation of a new congestion zone according two\ncriteria: (1) the cost of intra-zonal congestion mitigation, and (2) the existence of a\nworkably competitive market in each of the two new zones. The ISO tariff states that if\nthe cost of intra-zonal congestion mitigation over a 12-month period exceeds at least 5%\nof the product of the rated capacity of the path and the weighted average The proposed structure of the new\nzone north of Path 26 and south of Path 15 (SP15-NP26), the new SP15-NP26 zone will\ntake approximately 3,000 MW of generation capacity from the old SP15 zone, but it will\nonly have approximately 300 MW of load within the zone. Path 26 had a 3,000 MW bi-\ndirectional rating until November 1998. It was reduced to 2,400 MW for the 1998-99\nwinter season and increased to 2,800 for the summer of 1999. When there is congestion\nflowing from north to south on the SP26 interface, load in this new zone will only be\nreduced by approximately 300MW, but it will now have to be served by approximately\n3,000 MW less capacity. One can expect that during these periods, the opportunities to\nexercise market power in the energy and ancillary services markets within the SP26 zone\nare significantly greater than the opportunities that previously existed under similar load\nconditions in the old SP15 zone. In addition, if SP26 transmission path is de-rated, then\nwe would expect an even greater imbalance between load and available generation\ncapacity within the zone, leading to even greater opportunities to exercise market power\nin the new zonal market for energy and ancillary services beyond what was possible in\nthe original SP15 zone.\n        D.      New Generation Connection Policy\n        The two main proposals considered by the ISO Board for charging a new\ngenerator to interconnect are summarized below. The economic efficiency properties of\neach New Generation Interconnection Policy (NGIP) proposal are then analyzed. We\nargue that neither the Advance Congestion Cost Mitigation (ACCM) proposal nor the No\nGrandfathering of Transmission Rights (NGTR) proposal provides the proper economic\nincentives for when and where to construct new transmission and generation facilities to\nalleviate intra-zonal congestion. This is due in large part to the current ISO protocols for\nrelieving intra-zonal congestion.\n        The zonal nature of the California electricity market and the current ISO protocols\nfor managing intra-zonal congestion, combined with the fact that transmission upgrades\ncan often substitute for generation capacity in meeting many local reliability needs makes\ndesigning an NGIP an extremely complex task. An NGIP must give generation\ncompanies locational price signals for siting new facilities which increase the efficiency\nof the energy and ancillary services markets. Transmission owners must face price\nsignals which cause them to make transmission upgrades when these result in a lower\ncost solution to local reliability problems than investment in new generation capacity.\nTransmission owners should also have a financial incentive to maintain the amount and\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 112 of 148\n" [114] "geographic distribution of transmission capacity necessary for the energy and ancillary\nservices markets in California to function efficiently.\n        Designing an NGIP requires trading off the financial gains of some market\nparticipants against those of other market participants. One conclusion to emerge from\nour discussion of these proposals is the necessity of a revision of the ISO intra-zonal\ncongestion management protocols to provide incentives for market participants to\nalleviate intra-zonal congestion. Given an intra-zonal congestion management policy that\nenhances market efficiency, designing an appropriate NGIP becomes a significantly more\nstraightforward task.\n                 1.      New Generation Interconnection Policies under Consideration\n        If the owner/representative of a new generating unit (NewGen) would like to\nconnect that unit to the ISO grid, the NewGen must request a system impact and facilities\nstudy (Impact Study) from the associated Participating Transmission Owner (PTO). That\nstudy will identify reliability issues as well as incremental intra-zonal congestion caused\nby the NewGen. The ISO Tariff states that the NewGen must mitigate any reliability\nissues identified by the Impact Study. The NewGen may accomplish this by paying for\ntransmission system upgrades to correct the problem or, in some cases, by implementing\na Remedial Action Scheme (RAS) that would change the unit’s operations as necessary\nto relieve the reliability concern. However, the ISO Tariff is not clear on whether or how\nthe NewGen must address incremental congestion, specifically intra-zonal congestion,\ncaused by the new unit.\n    On this issue, the ISO Board considered two primary policy options:\n    1. “Advance Congestion Cost Mitigation” (ACCM): With this policy, NewGens\n        would be required to either pay for transmission upgrades or implement operating\n        procedures (e.g., curtail their generator’s output) that would, under certain\n        circumstances, mitigate the incremental congestion they cause. In addition, this\n        policy would require “future generators” (those that connect to the grid after\n        NewGen’s project) to complete the same mitigation measure. As a result,\n        congestion in the local area surrounding NewGen will be approximately the same\n        after it and any future generator connects in the area.\n    2. “No Grandfathering of Transmission Rights” (NGTR): With this policy,\n        NewGens would not be required to pay to mitigate the increased intra-zonal\n        congestion “caused” by their projects, nor would any future generators be\n        required to mitigate the additional intra-zonal congestion. SCs would use existing\n        ISO real-time energy market tools to manage any future intra-zonal congestion.\nUnder both the ACCM and NGTR approaches, NewGens would be required to address\nall grid upgrades necessary to maintain the reliability of the ISO grid. Under both\nproposals, NewGens could voluntarily invest in grid upgrades and would be entitled to\nany “system benefits” that arise as a consequence of their investment. These system\nbenefits result primarily from the lumpy nature of transmission upgrades, and the fact that\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 113 of 148\n" [115] "only a portion of the upgrade is necessary to mitigate the intra-zonal congestion caused\nby the NewGen’s entry.\n        If the connection of the NewGen to the grid leads to excessive intra-zonal\ncongestion and results in the creation of a new zone based on ISO Tariff Section 7.2.7,\nthere should be no difference between the two methods. This is because the Tariff allows\nthe new zone to be created only if there is a competitive generation market in each of the\ntwo new zones. If this is the case, the NewGen would have to be exempt from paying to\nmitigate intra-zonal congestion, because it will now be inter-zonal rather than intra-zonal\ncongestion, and the former can be mitigated through the inter-zonal congestion\nmanagement across the competitive zonal markets. The two methods would lead to\ndifferent results only when the NewGen connection leads to excessive intra-zonal\ncongestion, but there is insufficient competition to allow creation of a new zone.\nHowever, one can imagine instances where the mitigation measure undertaken by the\nnew entrant under the ACCM proposal would reduce the frequency of intra-zonal\ncongestion so that a new zone would not need to be created. Whereas under the NGTR\napproach a new zone will be created because no mitigation measures were undertaken in\nadvance of entry.\n        To determine the impact of the NewGen on intra-zonal congestion in the “impact”\nstudies, the “worst-case” scenario (for the most severe credible contingency in the hour\nwhere the system is most stressed) is compared with and without the NewGen. If an intra-\nzonal interface is congested with the NewGen with a flow increase of 5% or more\ncompared with the no NewGen case, the NewGen is assumed to be responsible for\ncreating the intra-zonal congestion. Implicitly, it is assumed that such a condition could\neventually lead to the creation of a new zone if the cost of congestion exceeded 5% of the\nannual access fee and there exists competitive generation markets on both sides of the\nzone which is created. To determine whether or not congestion can be mitigated through\ncompetitive markets, the ISO Board has adopted the 20% rule, i.e., to have a competitive\nmarket no one firm can own more than 20% of generation in the new zone.\n                2.      Analysis of Two Proposals\n        The main question we address is whether the ACCM or NGTR will lead to the\nmost efficient market for electricity in California given the current ISO protocols for\nmanaging intra-zonal congestion and creating new congestion zones. The ACCM assigns\nresponsibility for all additional intra-zonal congestion to the new entrant, despite the fact\nthat this new entrant sometimes provides benefits to all consumers within the zone or the\nstate by relieving intra-zonal congestion at a lower price or setting a lower state-wide or\nzonal price for energy. In this dimension, the ACCM is inferior to the NGTR. However,\nthe NGTR does not address the incentives in a zonal electricity market, such as the one\nthat exists in California, for new generators to locate where they can create and benefit\nfrom intra-zonal congestion. For this reason, the NGTR proposal in its current form is\nnot recommended. Finally, neither proposal provides incentives for the Participating\nTransmission Operator (PTO) to undertake transmission upgrades necessary to reduce the\nincidence of intra-zonal congestion or to substitute for additional generating capacity\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 114 of 148\n" [116] "when a transmission upgrade yields a lower cost solution to a local grid reliability\nproblem.\n                3.      ACCM Proposal\n        Any firm considering whether to enter the California market must determine if it\nwill be able to recover all of the up-front fixed costs associated with constructing a new\ngenerating facility and connecting it to the ISO grid from selling electricity in the\nCalifornia market. Any increase in the up-front cost necessary to enter the California\nmarket will tend to raise the average price of electricity in California necessary to cause\nnew generation to enter the market. Because the ACCM charges all incremental intra-\nzonal congestion costs to the new entrant, this policy implies that a higher average market\nprice will be required to trigger new entry into the California electricity market. The\nNewGen must recover these up-front congestion charges from the revenues it expects to\nearn from participating in the market.\n        However, if the NewGen has a lower marginal cost than existing generators, there\nwill be times when the zonal or statewide price of electricity will be lower because this\nfirm is present in the market. In addition, there will also be times when this firm is able\nto relieve intra-zonal congestion at a lower price than existing firms. Because all\ncustomers in a zone pay the same price of energy and pay intra-zonal congestion costs in\nproportion to their electricity consumption, the presence of this firm provides tangible\nbenefits to consumers during many hours. The ACCM proposal does not compensate\ngenerators for these system benefits, but requires them to pay all of the incremental intra-\nzonal congestion costs they impose on the transmission grid. This asymmetry of\ncharging new entrants for the costs they impose on the system without netting out all of\nthe benefits they provide to the system can increase the cost of entry by new generators.\n        Unfortunately, it is extremely difficult to compute the benefits that a new entrant\nprovides to the market. During periods when the new entrant sets the market price, the\ndifference between the price bid that would clear the market without the new entrant and\nthe bid that actually cleared the market could measure of how much lower prices are as a\nresult of the new entrant. However, this measure does not capture the impact of more\naggressiveness bidding by other market participants as a result the presence of a new\nentrant. In addition, if the new entrant was rewarded with a portion of the benefits that it\nprovided to market as defined by the above measure, it may distort its bidding behavior to\nset lower market prices.\n        In addition, it is extremely difficult to determine the cost of incremental intra-\nzonal congestion that a new entrant imposes on existing firms. Such a calculation will\nrequire value judgements that are likely to exert and a large influence on the results.\nSpecifically, the cost of intra-zonal congestion depends on the bids generators submit and\nthe ISO accepts to relieve the congestion. It is also very difficult to distinguish grid\nupgrades required for reliability reasons and those undertaken to relieve intra-zonal\ncongestion. Clearly grid upgrades made for reliability a very likely to reduce the level of\ngrid investment necessary to relieve intra-zonal congestion. Also, depending on the\nfinancial incentives a generator faces, it can produce in a manner that does not adversely\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 115 of 148\n" [117] "impact grid reliability yet causes intra-zonal congestion, produce in a manner that\nadversely impacts grid reliability yet does not cause intra-zonal congestion, or produce in\na manner that does not adversely impact grid reliability or cause intra-zonal congestion.\n         Because the ACCM policy charges the new entrant for incremental intra-zonal\ncongestion in the form of an up-front payment that does not net out the benefits that this\nentrant provides to other market participants described above, ACCM creates two\npotential sources of efficiency losses. First, existing generators are able to earn higher\nprices as a result of the up-front payment charged to new entrants under the ACCM\nscheme, because an upper bound on the annual average price of electricity in California is\nthe expected average total cost of a new entrant. Second, new entry may be delayed\nrelative to the case in which the ACCM scheme does not exist, because new entrants\nmust wait longer for sufficient demand growth to occur and produce wholesale electricity\nprices that are high enough to make new generation capacity economic.\n         A new entrant treats the ACCM as a sunk cost of entry, i.e., a cost which cannot\nbe recovered upon exit from the industry. Furthermore, this cost is not paid by existing\ngenerators. The higher are the perceived sunk costs of entry, the higher market prices can\nbe above the marginal cost of production and not trigger new entry. One major goal of an\nefficient market design is to eliminate unnecessary barriers to entry. Efficient entry is\nencouraged if entrants are charged for the negative externalities their entry imposes on\nother market participants, and credited for any positive externalities their entry imposes\non other market participants. Net entry charges in excess of those implied by this\nprinciple constitute unnecessary barriers to entry.\n         An additional shortcoming of the ACCM scheme arises because it assigns an\nunwarranted level of significance to the current level and location of intra-zonal\ncongestion by requiring new entrants to maintain the pre-entry level of intra-zonal\ncongestion. There is no definitive evidence that the current level and location intra-zonal\ncongestion is the optimal in the sense that it leads to the most efficient mode of operation\nof the California energy and ancillary services market. By requiring new entrants to\nmitigate intra-zonal congestion to current levels with grid upgrades, the ACCM may\nunnecessarily prevent some of market-efficiency-enhancing upgrades of the transmission\ngrid, or require too many upgrades of other transmission paths.\n         The potential barrier to entry caused by the ACCM may be even greater for\nsubsequent entrants. Because the ACCM requires all new entrants pay to enhance the\ntransmission grid so that the level of intra-zonal congestion is approximately same as\nbefore it entered the market, the cost of this intra-zonal congestion mitigation measure\nunder the ACCM proposal could be even larger for subsequent entrants. Consequently,\nentry barriers may rise over time, delaying subsequent new entry and increase the price of\nelectricity necessary to attract such new entry. Alternatively, because of the lumpiness of\ntransmission enhancements, the second entrant could “free ride” off of the proposed\nupgrades of the first entrant and therefore incur very small or even zero ACCM\npayments. This free-riding problem could be so extreme that neither entrant wants to be\nfirst into the market. As result, neither firm enters the market first, despite the fact that\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 116 of 148\n" This could create a circumstance where all market\nparticipants recognize the need for new generating capacity in California, but no new\ninvestment occurs, because no prospective entrant wants to be the first to commit to a\nnew generation project and pay the significantly higher first-entrant ACCM charge. This\ncould also create the situation that once entry occurs and the first mitigation measure is\ncomplete, there would then be a rush to be the one of the next entrants that do not have to\nundertake costly mitigation measures. In theory, coordination between entrants to\nmitigate intra-zonal congestion could solve these free-riding problems, but whether such\ncoordination will be achieved in practice is an open question.\n        The analysis up to now has assumed that the cost to enhance the grid so that the\nlevel of intra-zonal congestion is the same as before the new entry occurred is known, or\nat least relatively easy to calculate. However, determining the magnitude of this cost is\nlikely to be an extremely contentious process particularly because the new entrant must\npay it. For this reason, existing firms have a strong incentive to inflate these costs. In\naddition, because the PTO has a financial stake in this process, it has incentives to\nproduce Impact Studies for new entrants that favor its financial interests. Consequently,\nimplementing this proposal is likely to cause disputes over the mitigation measures\nrequired, which themselves could delay entry.\n                 4.      NGTR Proposal\n        The NGTR proposal does not create potential barriers to entry similar to the\nACCM proposal, because new entrants do not have to pay up-front to mitigate\nincremental intra-zonal congestion. Both new entrants and existing generators are treated\nsymmetrically in terms of the intra-zonal congestion they cause. Under the NGTR\nscheme, if a new generator can produce energy more cheaply than an existing generator,\nthat generator will find it profitable to enter and undercut the existing generator. Because\nthe sunk costs of new entry are lower under the NGTR scheme than under the ACCM\nscheme, we would expect that lower electricity prices would be required to attract new\nentry. In addition, new entry could occur more rapidly in response to a growing demand\nfor electricity than it would under the ACCM scheme.\n        However, the NGTR scheme can lead to excessive entry if entrants cause\ncongestion and thus impose negative externalities on existing generators. Even more\npointedly, NGTR also fails to address the major problem with the ISO’s intra-zonal\ncongestion management protocols that can lead to incentives for new entrants to locate\ntheir facilities to increase intra-zonal congestion. As noted above, current intra-zonal\ncongestion management protocols allow unit owners to buy back energy commitments on\nthe congested side of a path according to their unit-specific decremental bid prices, and\nsell additional energy on the uncongested side according to their unit-specific incremental\nbid prices. If generators on the congested side of the path whose decremental bids are\naccepted have some of their forward energy commitments met by the ISO, they receive\nthe difference between the forward energy market price and their decremental bid for the\namount of capacity that is decremented.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 117 of 148\n" [119] "         It is important to emphasize, that by definition of intra-zonal congestion, at least\none payment to relieve intra-zonal congestion is out of merit order, because there are\nlower-priced incremental energy bids and/or higher-priced decremental bids within the\ncongestion zone cannot be taken because of intra-zonal congestion. Due to their location\nin the grid, only certain generators can relieve the intra-zonal congestion, so their bids are\nthe only ones that can be accepted. The generator called out-of-merit-order in the real-\ntime energy bid curve will not affect the hourly price of energy in that zone. Any out-of-\nmerit-order decremental or increments payments will not affect the hourly real-time price\nof electricity in that congestion zone.\n         The NGTR proposal combined with the current ISO market rules may make it\nprofitable for a firm to enter at points in the California grid which satisfy two criteria: (1)\nsupplying more electricity at this point will increase the frequency of intra-zonal\ncongestion, and (2) the generation owner is the only market participant able to relieve this\nintra-zonal congestion. If there are other generators able to relieve this intra-zonal\ncongestion, the above strategy of scheduling to cause intra-zonal congestion should be\nless profitable, because there will be competition to supply the decremental energy bids\nnecessary to relieve this congestion.\n         The shortcomings of the current ACCM and NGTR proposals described above\nhighlight the challenges that must addressed by any NGIP because of the current ISO\nprotocols for relieving intra-zonal congestion. The major goal of an NGIP is to give the\nlocational price signals for new generators to enter where they provide the greatest\nbenefits to California electricity consumers. A second goal is to provide incentives for\nPTOs to undertake transmission upgrades that alleviate intra-zonal congestion along a\ntransmission path at a lower cost than out of merit purchases and sales of electricity. A\nthird goal is to involve loads in the intra-zonal congestion management process to the\ngreatest extent possible. Currently, all loads within the zone pay higher prices because of\nintra-zonal congestion in form of charges levied on all energy consumed in the\ncongestion zone, regardless of the load’s location in the zone. This mode of pricing intra-\nzonal congestion provides very muted incentives for loads to consume in a manner that\nreduces the cost of relieving intra-zonal congestion. All of these goals for a NGIP require\nthe ISO to have an intra-zonal congestion management protocol that gives as many\nmarket participants as possible strong incentives to eliminate intra-zonal congestion. In\nthe next section we describes changes in the ISO’s intra-zonal congestion management\nprotocols that come closer to achieving this end.\n         E.      Recommended Changes                    in      Intra-Zonal     Congestion\n                 Management Protocols\n         The major problem with the ISO’s intra-zonal congestion management protocols\nis that they provide no market participants with a strong incentive to eliminate intra-zonal\ncongestion and give many market participants the incentive to cause intra-zonal\ncongestion. Both of our recommended modifications eliminate some of the incentives to\ncause intra-zonal congestion by giving other market-participants strong incentives to\nreduce the amount of intra-zonal congestion. One approach builds off of the logic\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 118 of 148\n" [120] "described earlier about the false distinction between local grid reliability services and\nintra-zonal congestion mitigation services. In this case, we propose to use RMR units to\nmitigate intra-zonal congestion because intra-zonal congestion mitigation is economically\nequivalent to providing local reliability services. The second approach attempts to use a\nmore market-based solution. For this reason it may be more risky in terms of the\nopportunities for the exercise of market power, but it also has the greater upside in terms\nof solving the current incentives to cause intra-zonal congestion.\n                 1.     Cost-Based Intra-Zonal Mitigation\n         The first scheme relies on the logic expressed earlier that the distinction between\nrequiring energy from a single unit or one of a small number of units for local grid\nreliability reasons is difficult to distinguish from a requiring energy from a unit or one of\na small number of units to relieve intra-zonal congestion. In both cases, the generator is\nrequired to provide this service regardless of the magnitude of its bid price relative to the\nmarket-clearing price. Consequently, this scheme would use RMR calls whenever it is\nnecessary to skip over bids in the real-time energy bid stack to relieve intra-zonal\ncongestion. Specifically, if the ISO is required to skip over bids on either side of a\ncongested path, then it would be required to call on a RMR unit to relieve congestion on\nthat side of the path. If the congestion on one side of the path could be satisfied without\nskipping over bids in the real-time energy stack, then that bid would be taken. For\nexample, if incremental energy to relieve intra-zonal congestion happens to set the\nunconstrained 10-minute price in the zone, then there is no need to use an RMR unit to\nrelieve intra-zonal congestion. However, if relieving intra-zonal congestion in the\nincremental and/or decremental direction requires skipping over bids in the real-time\nenergy bid stack, then RMR units should be used to meet the incremental and/or\ndecremental energy.\n         This scheme would eliminate the somewhat artificial distinction between local\nmonopoly power because of local grid reliability concerns and local monopoly power\nbecause of the unit’s location relative to the location of intra-zonal congestion. This\nscheme prevents RMR unit owners from exercising market power at times they are a\nmonopoly or part of a duopoly for intra-zonal congestion mitigation. Clearly, because\nbids are being skipped, an unrestricted zonal market for energy is no longer operating\nsimilar to the case that it would be necessary to skip bids to pick generation units in\nspecific locations to solve local grid reliability problems which motivated the creation of\nRMR contracts.\n         Under this scheme, the threat of RMR calls if the unrestricted zonal energy\nmarket does not operate gives a strong incentive for this group of market participants to\ndispatch all of their generation units (RMR and non-RMR) to reduce the likelihood of\nintra-zonal congestion preventing this outcome from occurring. RMR unit owners now\nhave a financial interest in eliminating intra-zonal congestion and supporting an\nunrestricted zonal market. Under the current RMR contracts they are paid variable cost\nfor supplying RMR energy, and would clearly prefer to receive a market-determined\nprice above their variable cost. Under this scheme they will receive such a price only if\nthe unrestricted zonal market clears.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 119 of 148\n" Charging PTO’s for RMR calls give them a financial incentive to make the\nappropriate grid upgrades if this is cheaper than paying for RMR calls to relieve intra-\nzonal congestion. This logic is also in line with our view that there is no essential\neconomic distinction between local reliability services and intra-zonal congestion\nmitigation under local monopoly or duopoly situations. The PTOs currently pay for\nRMR calls for local reliability services, so that this requirement would make our scheme\ninternally consistent with this logic.\n         This scheme could also allow other market participants--loads and new generation\nentrants--to relieve intra-zonal congestion. Given these bids, the PTOs\ncould then decide instead to reduce their RMR unit capacity requirement and the\nmagnitude of associated up-front payments. They would undertake transmission grid\nexpansion to reduce the level of intra-zonal congestion. In this way, a trade-off between\nnew generation and transmission upgrades would enter into the process for relieving\nintra-zonal congestion.\n         The downside of this scheme is the increased reliance on RMR contracts, which\nruns contrary to the ISO Board’s stated goal of reducing the number of RMR units.\nDespite this apparent increased reliance on RMR contracts, it does not follow that there\nwill be more RMR units or a larger quantity of energy provided under the terms of RMR\ncontracts. The PTOs will undertake transmission upgrades to eliminate the need for\nRMR units where the costs of relieving intra-zonal congestion from RMR calls is more\nthan the cost doing so through a transmission upgrade. Because RMR unit owners have a\nfinancial stake in reducing the level of intra-zonal congestion, they will have a financial\nincentive to dispatch all of their units to reduce the likelihood of intra-zonal congestion\nduring periods expected to have high zonal energy prices. This should result in as much\nenergy as possible being sold through an unrestricted zonal energy market, which could\nresult in a smaller total quantity of energy sold under the terms of the RMR contracts than\nunder the current intra-zonal congestion management protocols.\n         Under the ISO’s current congestion management protocols, the creation of new\ncongestion zones is unlikely to solve the incentives generation unit owners have to cause\nintra-zonal congestion, despite the fact that creating a new zone transforms some intra-\nzonal paths into inter-zonal paths. [122] "mitigate the market power problems associated high ISO load periods more efficiently\nthat the current California zonal market would do with RMR units used in this manner.\n        In light of the above discussion, it is appropriate to think of RMR units as\nproviding liquidity to the zonal energy and ancillary services markets. By supplying\nenergy at certain points in the grid from RMR units and other units the firm owns, it can\nincrease the likelihood that an unrestricted market for energy and ancillary services can\noperate within the zone. This generator is compensated for providing this liquidity\nthrough the fixed payment it receives as an RMR unit owner. Allowing competition from\nPTOs (in the form of transmission upgrades), existing loads and generation, and new\ngeneration entrants to provide a portion or all of this local reliability service, should yield\na market-determined up-front payment, which pays for the cost of providing this liquidity\nto the market.\n        This designation of RMR units as market liquidity providers unifies their use for\nboth local grid reliability and intra-zonal congestion mitigation during times when the\nunrestricted zonal energy market does not clear. By facing these unit owners with risk of\nan RMR call at a cost-based rate to mitigate intra-zonal congestion, gives them strong\nincentives to reduce the likelihood of intra-zonal congestion particularly in the periods\nwhen zonal energy prices are likely to high. Zonal energy prices are likely to be high\nparticularly during the periods when total ISO load is high, so that this scheme provides\nthe greatest incentives to eliminate intra-zonal congestion during periods when the\nincentives other market participants have cause intra-zonal congestion are greatest. In\nexchange for taking on the task of eliminating intra-zonal congestion, RMR unit owners\nare paid an up-front annual payment which is determined through a competitive bidding\nprocess.\n                2.      Market-Based Intra-zonal Congestion Management Scheme\n        The second proposed intra-zonal congestion management scheme treats\ndecremental energy supplied for congestion mitigation as if it was a deviation from the\ngenerator’s hour-ahead schedule. All decremental measures taken to relieve intra-zonal\ncongestion are settled at the ex-post hourly real-time price. During any period when the\nunrestricted zonal incremental energy market fails to clear (bids must be skipped over to\nrelieve intra-zonal congestion), incremental energy would be provided by RMR unit\nowners at their variable cost, similar to the previous proposal. However, if this RMR\nunit’s variable cost is above the current zonal price, then this variable cost will set the\nzonal market-clearing price. Under this proposal, decremental bids would be used to\ndetermine the order in which out-of-sequence bids are used to decrement units able to\nrelieve intra-zonal congestion.\n        This scheme provides very strong incentives for all market participants not to\nattempt play to the so-called decremental energy game described earlier. This is because\nall generators know that if they cause intra-zonal congestion and must be decremented,\nthere may be a corresponding generator in that zone who is incremented to maintain\nbalance within the zone. The ten-minute price must also be above this generator’s bid in\norder for it to be dispatched in unrestricted zonal market. Consequently, a generator\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 121 of 148\n" [123] "playing the decremental energy game faces a significant risk of having to buy back\nenergy at an ex post price that is significantly above the day-ahead energy price or other\nenergy price its day-ahead energy schedule was hedged at. In those instances when an\nout-of-bid-sequence call must be made for incremental energy, an RMR unit would\ninstead be used to provide this energy. Even in this case the decrementing generator\nfaces the risk that this RMR unit’s variable payment rate will set the zonal price.\n         The downside of this scheme is that because all intra-zonal congestion must be\nmitigated as imbalance energy and generators can only be called to supply energy if the\nreal-time price is above their bid price, there are concerns about the potential exercise of\nmarket power in the incremental energy market. However, existence of the RMR energy\nbackstop in the those instance when an out-of-bid-sequence call would be required for\nincremental energy limits the extent of market power than can be exercised to the\nvariable cost of the RMR unit owner able to relieve the intra-zonal congestion. In\naddition, working against this incentive of one or a small number of generators to\nexercise market power in selling real-time energy is the incentive of generators on the\ndecremental side of market who stand the risk of having buy back imbalance energy at\nthe real-time price. These market participants would like to reduce to the zonal price of\nenergy during that hour to reduce the costs of selling back their decremental energy.\nBecause every congested intra-zonal interface has generation on the other side of it, this\nscheme always has a market participant with an incentive to limit the likelihood of intra-\nzonal congestion.\n         F.     New Zone Creation Recommendation\n         The evidence presented earlier on the impact of zonal market clearing on ancillary\nservices prices argues in favor keeping as few zones as possible in the California market.\nImplementing either of the intra-zonal congestion mitigation recommendations described\nabove should significantly reduce the incidence of intra-zonal congestion, thus\neliminating the necessity of undertaking the costly process of creating a new congestion\nzone. Embarking on a new zone creation process for the Path 26 interface may solve this\nproblem at the expense of significant market power when there is inter-zonal congestion\non paths across the newly created zones. In addition, the ISO may ending up having to\ncreate more congestion zones in the near future as a result of more market participants\nbeing able to exploit the flaws in the current intra-zonal congestion management\nprotocols. A superior strategy seems to be to first implement a revised intra-zonal\ncongestion management protocol. Then monitor the incidence of intra-zonal congestion\nto determine if the creation of a new zone is necessary under these protocols. This\nstrategy eliminates the very significant risk of increased market power when there is\nnorth to south congestion across the zonal interface between NP26 described above.\n         Only if the ISO management and Board feels that the improvements in system\nreliability along Path 26 as result of creating a new zone significantly outweigh the\nincreased market power risks from creating a zone should this new zone be created\nwithout some period of observation of the interface under the revised intra-zonal\ncongestion management protocols.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 122 of 148\n"
