[124] "        G.       New Generation Connection Policy Recommendation\n     As the above discussion has hopefully made clear, without changes to the current\nintra-zonal congestion management protocols, any new generation connection policy is\nnot likely to lead to the geographic distribution of new generation entry and transmission\nupgrades that will enhance the efficiency of the California electricity market.\nConsequently, it seems prudent to incorporate into any proposed new generation\nconnection policy a revised set of intra-zonal congestion management protocols. Without\na clear statement of these new congestion management protocols, it will be extremely\ndifficult to assess the efficiency properties of any new generation connection policy.\n     To this end, it our understanding that the ISO management is in the process of\nformulating revised intra-zonal congestion management protocols that are largely\nconsistent with the recommendations for revising the existing intra-zonal congestion\nmanagement protocols given above, and these protocols will be included in its New\nGeneration Connection Policy filing.\n10.     Transmission Pricing and Firm Transmission Rights (FTRs)\n     We continue to have concerns about the release of FTRs with scheduling priority for\nall available capacity, as required by the FERC in its May 3, 1999 order. Such FTRs are\nnot required in order for market participants to be able to hedge congestion risks; such\nhedging can occur using purely financial transactions. The release of this magnitude of\nFTRs also will tend to make the ISO's markets for inter-zonal congestion, using\nadjustment bids, thinner and more volatile. Furthermore, the concentrated ownership of\nFTRs with scheduling priority could well enable some companies to obtain market power\nover transmission rights, with adverse implications for energy markets themselves.\n     Given that plans are well along for the release of these FTRs with scheduling priority,\nwe strongly favor imposing position limits on these FTRs. Position limits are ultimately\na way of preventing any one entity from assembling a dominant position in the provision\nof transmission over a congested interface, with the market power dangers attendant to\nsuch a position. Put simply, we regard it as prudent to begin the FTR experience by\nflatly prohibiting the monopolization of FTRs that include scheduling priority. Indeed, if\na dominant position in FTRs would yield genuine market power, economic theory warns\nthat a single player would have the incentive to assemble just such a position, to the\ndetriment of those who are likely to require transmission across the interface during\ncongested period of time. With a position limit equal to 40% of the available\ntransmission capacity, for example, we do not believe that legitimate business uses of\nFTRs are likely to be blocked in any significant way, yet no one company could assemble\na dominant FTR holding on a specific interface.\n     We realize that a imposing position limits requires a certain degree of monitoring and\nreporting regarding FTRs. Certainly, meaningful compliance would require monitoring\nof the secondary market for FTRs, not just the transactions associated with the initial\nrelease of FTRs. To simplify compliance, secondary FTR transactions could be subject\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 123 of 148\n" [125] "to self-reporting, with the ISO performing after-the-fact verification of the accuracy of\nsuch reports, imposing penalties and sanctions in cases of non-compliance. It is our\nunderstanding that with self-policing and after-the-fact verification of compliance,\ninformation from the ISO's Secondary Registration System (SRS) could be used with few\nchanges or additions.\n     We will, of course, have more to say about FTRs by December 1, 2000, when the\nFERC has instructed us to file a report on the experience with FTRs. Certainly we will\nbe better able to assess the impact of FTRs if we are able to monitor FTR holdings. We\nalso hope to observe how FTRs are being used, to determine whether in fact there are\nlegitimate business purposes that might require relatively concentrated holdings, e.g., in\nexcess of 40% of the available transmission capacity.\n     We realize that possible abuses of FTRs are just that—possible but not proven, and\nperhaps not even all that likely. But our experience with the transition to competitive\nmarkets to date has shown us that many market participants are sophisticated and quite\nable to maximize their profits subject the regulatory rules constraining their behavior.\nBecause we see no compelling reason why large assemblages of FTRs are needed, and\nbecause we remain relatively ignorant of how these FTRs will actually be used, we\nbelieve that California consumers will be best served by at least starting the FTR release\nwith meaningful position limits and reporting requirements in place.\n11.       PG&E Divestiture\n     PG&E controls over 4,500 MW of hydroelectric capacity in Northern California of\nwhich approximately 3,500 MW is subject to divestiture. This capacity spans five major\nwatersheds and includes the 1,200 MW Helms pumped storage plant. As a number of\nobservers have pointed out, this capacity is an extraordinarily valuable asset both for\nPG&E and for the electric power system in California. PG&E ownership of the hydro\nsystem, even after divestiture of its fossil units, is sufficient to give it market power over\nprovision of ancillary services under certain load conditions, and over PX energy prices\nwhen transmission paths into Northern California are constrained. At present, PG&E has\nstrong incentives to use its hydro capacity to constrain rather than raise prices, because it\nis still subject to the rate freeze and CTC recovery mechanism. However, once the hydro\nassets are divested under California’s restructuring plan, the new owner or owners will\nhave every incentive to do the opposite, potentially exacerbating volatility and above-\ncompetitive prices in these already concentrated markets.\n     A number of competing proposals have been advanced by PG&E and others for\ndivesting the hydro system. PG&E originally proposed to divest the major part of the\nsystem to an unregulated subsidiary. The California legislature has not accepted this\nproposal and PG&E reportedly is proceeding to sell the system off to unaffiliated buyers.\n     The timing and terms of the sale are important to the successful functioning of the\nNorthern California power market. The proceeds of sale of the facilities are likely to be\nwell in excess of book value of the facilities. The value over book will reduce the\n                          MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 124 of 148\n" As the ISO’s\nDepartment of Market Analysis has pointed out, selling the assets to a single buyer or to a\nbuyer that owns other fossil-generating units in Northern California, can increase the\nlikelihood that generation owners can exercise market power in the ancillary services\nmarkets. (The DMA paper is attached as Appendix B). The DMA suggests alternative\nstructural, contractual and “behavioral” measures to migrate potential exercise of market\npower. The Committee concurs in the DMA’s assessment that the terms of this\ndivestiture (which ultimately will have to be approved by the Commission under §§ 8\nand 203 of the Federal Power Act) are critical to the functioning of California’s ancillary\nservices markets, and that effective market power mitigation measures must be put in\nplace. The Committee’s view is that “behavioral” mitigation measures (such as bidding\nrules and minimum capacity availability requirements) are complex and difficult to\nenforce. Structural mitigation measures, such as a requirement that the hydroelectric\nsystems be sold off on a watershed-by-watershed basis to separate companies that are\nindependent of major owners of Northern California generation, are better designed to\neffectively mitigate market power, and are the preferred coverage. For this reason we\nstrongly recommend the assets be divested on a watershed-by-watershed basis to a buyer\nunaffiliated with PG&E or other major generation owners in Northern California.\nStructured in this manner, the divestiture of PG&E’s hydro system can decrease, rather\nthan increase market power in California’s wholesale electricity market.\n12.       Maximum Purchase Price Caps\n     The Commission’s May 26 Order (Redondo Beach Docket No. ER98-2843-005 et.\nal., May 26, 1999) allows the ISO to retain its current authority to set maximum prices at\nwhich it will purchase ancillary services and imbalance energy only until November 15,\n1999. After that date, the ISO’s authority to set maximum purchase prices, which the\nOrder refers to as “price caps”, will be eliminated.19 The ISO sought rehearing of the\nMay 26 Order and on September 17, 1999, filed tariff amendments which; if approved,\nwould extend the maximum purchase price authority until through November 15, 2000.\nOn August 26, 1999, the ISO Board also took action under its existing maximum\npurchase price authority to increase the price limits on ancillary services from $250 to\n$750 effective October 1, 1999. If its authority is extended for 12 months as requested,\nthe price limits will stay at this level unless the ISO makes a subsequent determination to\nchange them.\n19\n   The term “price cap” may be a misnomer since it is authorization for the ISO to decline to purchase\nancillary services and real-time energy when bid prices exceed a particular level, not a limit on what\ngenerator can bid into the market. When the ISO sets maximum purchase prices, it specifies the highest\nprice it will pay for ancillary services. Generators are free to sell real-time energy or ancillary services at a\nhigher price if they can find a buyer (such as a self-providing SC or an out-of-state purchaser).\n [127] "      On June 24, 1999, the ISO’s Market Surveillance Committee and the PX Market\nMonitoring Committee (“MMC”) submitted a joint memorandum to the ISO and PX in\nwhich the two Committees stated that they concurred with the FERC that the then-current\n$250 purchase-price limits on ancillary services and imbalance energy should be raised as\nsoon as possible consistent with the maintenance of competitive markets for electricity in\nCalifornia. The Committees stated, however, that they strongly believed that the price\ncaps should not be raised until the ISO’s redesign of its ancillary services markets and the\nreform of the Reliability Must-Run (“RMR”) contracts were fully implemented. In their\nview, setting a date certain for the removal of the price caps that is independent of the\ncompletion of these necessary redesign and reform efforts, leaves the California markets\nunprotected from massive unanticipated price movements that could arise from market-\ndesign flaws or the exercise of market power.20\n      The MSC has been extremely reluctant to recommend imposing purchase-price caps\non the energy and ancillary-services markets in California. However, we continue to\nhave concerns about the competitiveness of the California energy and ancillary-services\nmarkets, as we have detailed in Sections 3 and 4 of this report. For that reason, we\nbelieve that until the market-design problems identified in our prior reports are remedied\nand it is clear that any remaining generator market power has been mitigated, purchase-\nprice limits should be retained on the imbalance-energy and ancillary-services markets.\nThe Committee also believes that until there is sufficient confidence that the structure of\nthe California wholesale electricity market allows unrestricted market forces to yield\nefficient results, there will still be a need for a maximum purchase price limitation or\nother mechanism by which the ISO and the PX can facilitate the smooth functioning of\nthe market and protect California consumers from inefficiently high prices for energy and\nancillary services.\n      As the MSC has emphasized in this report and in its August 1998 and March 1999\nreports to the FERC, the California markets for energy and ancillary services are highly\ninterdependent. In particular, given the sequential structure of the California electricity\nmarkets, expectations about prices in the ancillary-services markets have a major impact\non prices in the PX day-ahead market, and the expected price for imbalance energy has\nstrong effects on the energy prices in both the PX day-ahead and day-of markets.\nConsequently, the PX is heavily dependent on the ISO’s authority to establish maximum\nprices that it will pay for real-time energy, and on the ISO’s exercise of any such\nauthority. Since a price limit in the ISO real-time energy market will effectively serve as\na price constraint on the PX day-ahead and day-of energy markets, the ISO’s authority to\nestablish maximum purchase prices for ancillary services and imbalance energy protects\nboth sets of markets.\n20\n   The Committees also stated that the specific choice of a November 15, 1999 termination date was\nespecially 60-day\nnotice provision of the Federal Power Act.\n                              MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 126 of 148\n" 
[128] "    Finally, although the California electricity market is unique in some respects, the\nMSC believes that the issues of market-supporting interventions that now face the ISO\nand the PX in California have arisen and will continue to arise in other newly deregulated\nelectricity markets that are emerging in other parts of the U.S., particularly in New\nEngland. The Committee believes that the FERC should deal with these questions now\nin a way that will have general application and not wait to address these issues in the\ncontext of emergency situations that are very likely to arise in different jurisdictions.\n    In the remainder of this section we discuss the need for market protecting\ninterventions and, in particular, the basis of our recommendations to retain for the next 12\nmonths, the maximum purchase price limits for ancillary services and imbalance energy\nin the California electricity markets.\n        A.      The Role of Purchase-Price Caps\n        With a strong consensus among market participants that all the flaws in the design\nof the markets for energy and ancillary service had been eliminated, with a large number\nof consumers purchasing energy or ancillary services at the hourly spot price, and with a\nfairly full and robust set of forward and financial contracts available to market\nparticipants, there would be very little reason to consider price-intervention mechanisms\nin the California electricity market. But the California market presently falls far short of\nthis. In the near term, until the market-design problems that have already been identified\nare remedied, there is a continuing need for the ISO to have authority to set maximum\npurchase prices. In the longer term, when those design flaws are corrected but price\nresponsive demand and robust markets for forward and financial contracts are not yet\nfully developed, the ISO will still need a mechanism to ensure orderly and efficient\nmarkets for energy and ancillary services. That is, once the current price caps are lifted,\nthe ISO must retain some residual authority to intervene during market emergencies to\nlimit the prices it will pay for energy and ancillary services.\n                1.       Market Flaws Remain\n        The California market for electricity has been in operation for 18 months.\nAlthough the Committee hopes that the most market-design flaws have been identified,\nonly experience with the new market design when all the necessary changes have been\nimplemented will enable us to determine whether more problems remain. Some flaws\ncreate opportunities that can produce extremely high prices, and without a damage-\ncontrol purchase-price caps, there is no limit to how high these prices could go.\n        If the ISO lacks the authority to limit the prices at which it purchases energy or\nancillary services, it will be forced as it was in July 1998 to accept bids of $5,000 or\n$9,999 per MWh for ancillary service, even in times of moderate demand and ample\nsupply. A market perturbation in thin ancillary services markets -- such as the one that\noccurred on May 30, 1999–could have extraordinary impacts on prices and costs. In that\ncase, the unavailability of one large hydroelectric facility drove regulation prices to $250\nfor 10 hours. For those 10 hours, regulation capacity costs totaled $4.1 million. If the\nISO had not had authority to limit the price at which it purchased regulation, and the\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 127 of 148\n" [129] "market had cleared at $5000 as it did on July 9, 1998, California consumers would have\nhad to pay 20 times more than they did for the service. This would come to more than\n$80 million for one day. Had the market cleared at $9,999 (as it did on July 13, 1998),\nthe cost to consumers would have been almost 40 times more than it was. Market\nperturbations in the broader PX markets, such as the one that occurred on October 1,\n1999, and is described in Section 3, can have even greater consumer cost impacts.\n        The Commission’s May 26th Order leaves the ISO with no residual authority to\ncope immediately and directly with severe market perturbations that may occur after\nNovember 15th. Unless the Order is modified, it effectively requires the ISO to return to\nthe FERC to seek remedial authority after any problem occurs. By the time the\nCommission acts on such a request, California consumers may have incurred many\nhundreds of millions of dollars in higher energy costs.\n                2.      The Importance of Price-Responsive Final Demand\n        As we discuss throughout this report, an essential element of a smoothly\nfunctioning competitive market for electricity is a price-responsive demand-side of the\nmarket. When final customers--residential, commercial, and industrial--can respond in\nreal-time to spot prices for energy and ancillary services, the market itself provides an\nappropriate and effective check on the ability of supply-side participants to raise prices to\ninefficient levels. Until the demand-side of the market becomes much more price\nresponsive, there need to be other checks on the exploitation of market-design flaws and\nthe exercise of market power; market-intervention measures by the ISO are a prime\ncandidate.\n                3.      The Need for Forward Contracts\n        The current California market rules present various impediments to consumers\nwho might try to set an implicit purchase-price cap in the energy and ancillary services\nmarket through creative financial forward-contracting schemes, just as those rules\ndiminish the effects of actions by those who might financially benefit from shifting their\nconsumption in response to hourly electricity prices. Consequently, without some\nchanges in these market rules and some period of time to adjust to such changes, it would\nbe inadvisable to remove the ISO’s ability to invoke some damage-control market\nintervention in its energy and ancillary services markets.\n                4.      Legal Sufficiency\n        Because it leaves California consumers unprotected from exercise of market\npower by generators selling into the state’s electric power market, the Commission’s\ncurrent policy with respect to maximum purchase price raises fundamental questions of\nlegal sufficiency. All generators in California (other than Federal and state agencies and\nmunicipalities) that sell energy or ancillary services to the ISO or PX are “public utilities”\nunder the Federal Power Act because they make sales for resale in interstate commerce.\n16 U.S.C. § 824(e). Under §§ 205 and 206 of the FPA, 15 U.S.C. §§ 824d and 824e, the\nprices at which these sales are made must be “just and reasonable.” The Commission has\nremoved cost-based price caps on these generators’ sales and allowed them market-based\nrates, after making an explicit finding in each case that the generator cannot exercise\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 128 of 148\n"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
[130] "market power over generation or transmission and cannot erect other barriers to entry by\ncompeting generators.21 If the Committee’s analysis presented in this report is correct, the\npredicate for allowing market-based rates may be incorrect. The Committee’s analysis\nindicates generators are capable of exercising market power at certain times in some\nmarkets. Under well established precedent, seller rates need not be regulated if, but only\nif, regulation of the buyer is sufficient to ensure just and reasonable rates. FPC v. Texaco\nInc., 417 U.S. 330 (1974). For that reason, in a circumstance where sellers have market\npower, the Commission need not regulate the sellers rates directly by imposing cost-\nbased price caps on the sellers, so long as it can assure itself that buyers will be able to\ndiscipline sellers’ market power. Giving buyers (in this case the ISO and PX) authority\nto impose maximum purchase price limits is one mechanism for doing so. However, we\nfail to see how the Commission, in the face of significant evidence of the exercise of\nmarket power by generators in the California markets, can remove all price caps on\nsellers and at the same time disable the ISO as buyer, from protecting itself and\nCalifornia consumers from the exercise of seller market power. The Supreme Court in\nthe Texaco case reiterated that no particular rate-making methodology is required under\nthe just and reasonable standard of the Natural Gas Act. Texaco 417 U.S. at 338. That\nstandard is identical to the just and reasonable standard in §§ 205 and 206 of the Federal\nPower Act. Under both statutes, the Commission and the courts look to the end result.\nFPC v. Hope Natural Gas Co., 320 U.S. 591, 602 (1944).22\n         According to legal analysis provided to the MSC, the Commission cannot\nlawfully abandon its statutory duty to assure that the mechanisms it adopts result in just\nand reasonable rates under FPA §§ 205 and 206. It has no general authority to waive this\nfundamental requirement. Market- based rates can be consistent with the statute only in\nthe absence of market power. Thus, “[t]he Commission allows power sales at market-\nbased rates if the seller and its affiliates do not have, or have adequately mitigated,\nmarket power in generation and transmission and cannot erect other barriers to entry.”23\nThis approach is endorsed by the courts. Cajun Elec. Power v. FERC, 28 F.3d 173, 176\n(D.C. Cir. 1994); Elizabethtown Gas Co. v. FERC, 10 F.3d 866, 870 (D.C. Cir. 1993).\nThe Commission acts unlawfully, however, if it seeks to stimulate supply “by sales freed\nfrom meaningful regulation”24 that do not assure just and reasonable rates. FPC v.\nTexaco, supra; cf. Farmers Union Cent. Exchange, Inc. v. FERC, 734 F.2d 1486, 1502-\n1504 (D.C. Cir. 1984). (“. . . Workable Competition and New Zone Creation\n     Our ultimate aim is to help assure that the various electricity markets25 in California\nperform in an efficient fashion, bringing reliable electricity to consumers at least cost\nover the long run. If these inter-related markets are as close to this ideal as can be\nexpected in practice, we say they are “workably competitive.” The concept of a market\nbeing “workably competitive” is clear enough: we do not expect “perfect competition,”\ni.e., price-taking behavior by all market participants, but neither does any one firm enjoy\nsignificant market power; nor is there collusion permitting the collective exercise of\nmarket power. But how is this concept to be made operational in California’s electricity\nmarkets?\n     Beyond the general interest in assessing whether competition is “working” in\nCalifornia’s electricity markets, for the purposes of creating new zones to manage\ncongestion, the ISO is required to assess whether the market for electricity generation in\neach of the two new proposed zones is “workably competitive” a substantial portion of\nthe time. We indicate here the steps we believe should be followed in making such an\nassessment.\n         A.        General Principles\n         In a market for a homogeneous good such as electricity, the ideal of perfect\ncompetition is easily defined: each supplier, acting independently and lacking the ability\nto affect the market-clearing price, maximizes its own profits by bidding in its generating\nunits at marginal cost. Likewise, each buyer, also acting independently and lacking the\nability to affect the market-clearing price, bids in its demand at its willingness-to-pay.26\n25\n   The principles articulated here apply equally to markets for ancillary services, or transmission rights for\nthat matter, to markets for energy itself.\n26\n   Even if the supply side of a market is highly competitive, the buyer(s) could still exert monopsony\npower. Under perfect competition, both buyers and sellers are price-takers.\n                             MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 131 of 148\n" [133] "The resulting equilibrium prices and quantities are efficient in two senses: (1) least-cost\nproduction of the electricity that is actually produced, and (2) the quantity of electricity\nmaximizes total net value (benefits to buyers less cost of production).\n          In practice, this ideal can only be approached, raising the question of how “close”\na given market must be to the ideal for us to declare victory and characterize that market\nas “workably competitive.” Economists have been grappling with the concept of\n“workable competition” for over 50 years, and have yet to identify a set of diagnostics\nthat can be applied to determine reliably whether or not a market is in fact “workably\ncompetitive.”\n          While some market participants and observers may seek a simple formula or\nbright-line test to determine whether an electricity market is “workably competitive,” we\ndo not believe that any formulaic approach is likely to be reliable. Just as the Department\nof Justice and the Federal Trade Commission regard market shares as a starting point for\nevaluating the effects of horizontal mergers, not the end of the analysis, we favor an\napproach that looks at a variety of market indices, and may incorporate substantial\ninstitutional detail, for assessing the state of competition in a given electricity market.\n          This is not to say that the proper inquiry is unpredictable or unfocused. To the\ncontrary, we believe that research findings and practical experience from both antitrust\nand regulatory spheres provide substantial guidance for assessing the state of competition\nin a given electricity market.27 Drawing on that body of knowledge, and on our own\nexperience evaluating competitive conditions, we sketch here some of the key questions\nthat we believe should be addressed when determining whether a given electricity market\nis “workably competitive.28” We express these tests through a list of (cumulative)\nconditions that tend to support a conclusion that a given electricity market is “workably\ncompetitive.” This list is intentionally designed to apply to short-term bidding markets\nfor a homogeneous good subject to substantial fluctuations demand, in which a market-\nclearing price (MCP) is determined through the equating of supply and demand.\n          B.       Significant Quantity is Bid But Not Called\n          If there is a “thick” stack of bids at prices just above the MCP, it is unlikely that\nany single supplier can exert meaningful control over price. If Supplier X were to\nattempt to withhold its capacity, or raise its bid, the MCP would change little if at all:\nSupplier X’s electricity (or capacity) would simply be replaced with electricity (or\ncapacity) bid by others at or near the MCP.\n27\n   See Severin Borenstein, “Understanding Competitive Pricing and Market Power in Wholesale Electricity\nMarkets,” University of California Energy Institute, August 1999, for a well-reasoned discussion of pricing\nand investment decisions in competitive electricity markets.\n28\n   We focus here on “workable competition” among suppliers, assuming that monopsony power is not a\nsignificant problem, either because demand is unconcentrated or because buyers are unable to reduce\ndemand to depress prices. However, the same principles developed here can be used to assess buyer power\nin electricity markets.\n                            MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 132 of 148\n" [134] "          For a given set of bids by suppliers, it is relatively straightforward to determine\nthe (residual) demand curve facing any given supplier: if that supplier raised its bids, or\nreduced its supply, what would be the impact on market price? In general, if a single\nsupplier (a) has a significant market share, and (b) has the ability to materially affect the\nMCP through its bidding behavior, that supplier is likely to possess some meaningful\nmarket power. Using bid data, the ability of any single market participant to elevate the\nMCP can be directly estimated.\n          The ISO’s Department of Market Analysis (DMA) has developed a summary\nmeasure, called the “Residual Supply Index” (“RSI”), that partially captures the\n“thickness” of the stack of bids above the MCP. (See Annual Report on Market Issues\nand Performance, California ISO, June 1999, pages 7-4 through 7-20.) Define “Bid\nSufficiency,” B, as the ratio of total quantity bid (at the highest allowable price) to the\ntotal quantity demanded (taken as fixed, i.e., independent of price). Define the “share of\nsupplier X,” SX, as the quantity bid by supplier X as a fraction of total demand. The RSI\nfor a given supplier is then defined as RSIX = B - SX. The RSI is meant to capture the\nsufficiency of suppliers other than X to meet demand. A high value of RSIX thus tends to\nindicate that supplier X lacks market power.\n          We agree with the DMA that their RSI can be a useful way of summarizing “bid\nsufficiency” in a given electricity market at a given point in time. However, we should\npoint out that a high value of RSI may be consistent with significant market power if the\nsupply bids are well above the MCP. For this reason, the RSI seems better suited to\nevaluating whether the market is in danger of not clearing at all (due to bid insufficiency)\nrather than assessing the degree of market power of any individual supplier.29 Put\ndifferently, there is no reason to restrict attention to a summary measure such as the RSI\nfor the purpose of assessing market power when we have available the full set of bids.\nWe believe that this is also the position of the DMA, which proposes to use the RSI for\nscreening purposes when the information, the resources, or the time is not available to\nconduct an in-depth study of market power. DMA has also proposed a refinement which\nwill examine RSI for bids under certain price level, such as $100/MWh. This can help to\naddress the question whether the supply bids are well above MCP.\n          C.       Bids are Close to Marginal Cost\n          The strongest single piece of evidence that a given supplier lacks market power is\nthe observation that this supplier bids its energy and/or capacity into the market at or near\n29\n   The DMA offers a classification system (see p. 7-4) in which a Bid Sufficiency of greater than 150%\nindicates “Low Potential Market Power.” While we agree that the RSI can be a useful and practical\nindicator of likely market power, and an RSI of greater than 150% may in practice be highly correlated\nwith the absence of significant market power, we would prefer to look directly at the thickness of bids just\nat or above the MCP. Situations could arise in which there is ample Bid Sufficiency, but the rejected bids\nare well above the MCP. In this situation, one or more suppliers could indeed enjoy significant market\npower. Of course, if for some reason information about the level of bids above the MCP were not\navailable, but the total quantity bid were available, the RSI could be observed, but not the ability of any\nindividual bidder to elevate the MCP; in this situation, the RSI could well be the best observable measure\nof likely market power.\n                             MSC Report, October 18, 1999, [135] "its marginal cost.30 Although we can readily observe bids in California’s electricity\nmarkets, we may have some difficulty comparing these bids to marginal cost if the latter\nis difficult to observe or estimate.\n         If a supplier bids some or all of its capacity into the market well above marginal\ncost, we ask ourselves why such a bid was more profitable than bidding at, or slightly\nabove, marginal cost. The most likely answer is that this supplier believed it could (with\nsome likelihood) cause the marginal to rise by raising its own bids. The larger is the\nsupplier’s share of the market, and the larger is the gap between the supplier’s marginal\ncost and its bid, the greater is the inference of market power.\n         We hasten to add that we do not in any sense regard such bidding as\nobjectionable; its is merely the result of profit-maximization by the supplier possessing\nsome power over price (at least probabilistically). But the observation, or inference, that\nthis supplier (and perhaps others) enjoys market power may well be relevant for policy\ndecisions such as the lifting of a price cap or the creation of a new zone.\n         We also should emphasize that we would expect suppliers lacking market power\nto bid at marginal cost even during periods of peak demand. What is different during\npeak periods is that more costly units (as measured by marginal cost) are active, which\nrequires a higher MCP. Units with lower marginal costs will thus enjoy the largest\nmargins (between MCP and marginal cost) during these periods. Naturally, the\nfrequency and intensity of these peak periods affects investment incentives.\n         Some commentators have pointed out that in many markets firms are unable to\nrecover their fixed costs if they price at marginal cost, suggesting therefore that to view\nprices in excess of marginal cost as indicative of market power must be faulty. We have\ntwo main responses to this assertion. First, the mere fact that a supplier bids marginal\ncost does not been that the price received by this supplier equals marginal cost. To the\ncontrary, the MCP exceeds the bids of all suppliers except the marginal supplier(s), i.e.,\nthose with the highest bids that are accepted. So most suppliers most of the time will\nreceive a margin equal to the gap between the MCP and their marginal cost (which equals\ntheir bid) under competitive conditions. Second, in many other markets where a\nsupplier’s bid indeed determines the price it receives, we have differentiated products, so\nindividual firms are not price-takers. It is usually recognized that these firms—from\nrestaurants to manufacturers of branded consumer goods to publishers of movies and\ncomputer software—indeed have some technical market power (but usually not any\nmeaningful market power for antitrust purposes), and that this is a necessary reward for\nincurring the fixed costs necessary to produce a differentiated product valued by\nconsumers. We do not explore this point further here as the markets of concern to us\ninvolve homogeneous goods; we merely wish to point out that drawing analogies\nbetween bidding markets for a homogeneous good and posted-price markets for\ndifferentiated products is perilous.\n30\n   By “marginal cost” we mean the true (economic, not accounting) incremental cost of fulfilling the bid.\nFor a supplier that is capacity-constrained, the marginal cost may be an opportunity cost, e.g., of not selling\nthat same power or capacity in another market.\n                             MSC Report, October 18, 1999, [136] "          D.        Supply is Not Concentrated\n          Market concentration is the single most commonly-used measure of whether a\nmarket is “competitive” or not. In many antitrust cases, for example, including both\nmergers and monopolization cases, both the antitrust enforcement agencies and the\nCourts look to market shares as a measure of market power.\nWe certainly believe that market shares, and market concentration, are important\nmeasures in electricity markets as well. However, we would like to stress that market\nshares are usually employed as a proxy for market power because the direct measurement\nof market power is difficult or impossible with available data. Happily, we have\nexcellent data about prices and quantities in California’s electricity markets. So, we\nregard market shares as a useful additional measure, but not the very best available\nmeasure of market power in California’s electricity markets. Our preferred measures are\nthose two indicated just above: the “thickness” of bids at or just above the MCP, and the\n(percentage) gap between various suppliers’ bids and their marginal costs.31\n          E.        Buyers are Flexible\n          Market power by sellers is inevitably reduced if buyers have the flexibility to\nreduce their demand in the presence of high prices and/or to turn to other sources of\nsupply (either a substitute product or the same product provided from a different\ngeographic area).\n          So far, wholesale buyers of electricity in California have sadly little ability to\nreduce demand in the presence of high prices. And the ISO has very little ability to\nreduce its demand for ancillary services or real-time energy given its duty to meet various\nreserve requirements and assure grid reliability. The fact that demand is extremely\ninelastic (insensitive to price) in the short run in most of California’s electricity markets\nis arguably the single most important factor preventing these markets from being\n“workably competitive.”\n          F.        There Are No Unnecessary Institutional Barriers to Rivalry or\n                    to Demand Flexibility\n          Given the elaborate regulatory regime in place in California’s electricity markets,\nit is all too easy for regulations to impede “workable competition.” We have previously\nexpressed concerns about the Reliability-Must-Run rules and the impact they have on\nbidding behavior; hopefully the new arrangement for RMRs will greatly alleviate those\n31\n   Having said this, we hasten to add that we expect firms with relatively large market shares to be precisely\nthe ones that enjoy and exercise market power. Basic economics tells us that the optimal markup of price\n(bid) over marginal cost depends directly upon the number of “infra-marginal” units sold by the supplier in\nquestion, i.e., units of output that would be sold at a slightly lower bid. The number of such units can be\nconsidered proportional to the supplier’s market share. However, a supplier with a small market share\ncould have power over price if that supplier is the marginal supplier (at the MCP) and there are few bids\njust above the MCP.\n [137] "concerns. We have previously expressed concerns that the tariff governing the ISO has\nlimited the ISO’s flexibility as a buyer of ancillary services and thus made it harder for\ncompetition to work; hopefully the new “Rational Buyer Protocols” will go far to address\nthose concerns. But these are merely two examples of how various institutional rules or\nregulations can serve to exacerbate market power problems. Generally speaking, an\nassessment of whether a market is “workably competitive” will include an evaluation of\nwhether there are institutional features that reduce rivalry among actual and potential\nsuppliers, or than hinder buyer flexibility.\n         G.     Collusion is Difficult\n         Collusion has no place in a “workably competitive” market. If collusion is easily\nachieved, or at least a dangerous probability (e.g., because of a concentrated market\nstructure or because the suppliers have ample opportunities to meet and reach illegal\nagreements), a market may fail to be “workably competitive.” To date, we are not aware\nthat collusion has been a major problem in California’s electricity markets, but\nconsumers, regulators, and the California and Federal antitrust agencies must, as always,\nbe vigilant about detecting and punishing any price fixing or market division agreements.\n         H.     Entry into the Market is Easy\n         The final factor that should be considered in evaluating whether a market is\n“workably competitive” is the ease of entry into that market. In California’s electricity\nmarkets, we would expect entry typically to come in one of two ways: (1) the supply of\nenergy or ancillary services from outside the State (these suppliers would just as well be\ncalled market participants as “entrants”), and (2) the construction of new generation\nfacilities. Evaluation of these two types of entry is quite distinct. The ability of imports\nto come in California in increasing quantities as needed is the key to evaluating that type\nof entry. And the entry obstacles and costs faced by new generators are key to the second\ntype of entry. Of course, entry by new generators is more likely to undermine market\npower in the long run than in the short run.\n         I.     Application to the Creation of New Zones\n         Section 7.2.7 of the ISO Tariff contains provisions for the creation, modification,\nand elimination of zones. The Tariff lists two main necessary conditions for the creation\nof a new zone within an existing zone: (1) the presence of significant congestion on a\npath within that zone; and (2) the existence of workably competitive generation markets\non both sides of the corresponding interface for a substantial period of the year.\n         As an example, intra-zonal congestion on Path 26 recently satisfied the first\ncriterion for the creation of a new zone. Thus, it became necessary to assess whether\ngeneration markets on both sides of Path 26 were in fact “workably competitive.”\n         Applying the methodology above to this example, we would look at the demand\nand supply of energy and ancillary services on both sides of Path 26 to see if there were a\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 136 of 148\n" [139] "14.     Appendix A\n       ISO MARKET SURVEILLANCE COMMITTEE OPINION ON FIRM\n                         TRANSMISSION RIGHTS PROPOSALS\n        The Market Surveillance Committee (Frank Wolak and Carl Shapiro), and its\nadvisors (Robert Wilson, and James Bushnell) have analyzed the current two proposals\nfor the creation of firm transmission rights (FTRs) for the California electricity market.\n        It is the opinion of the Committee that the issuance of a set of FTRs with an\naggregate capacity equal to 100% of the current physical capacity of the system could\npotentially lead to several serious, negative consequences to electricity consumers in\nCalifornia. The committee is particularly concerned about the allocation of FTRs that\ninclude a scheduling priority to be invoked when the ISO adjustment markets do not\nclear. There is concern that an issuance of such rights equivalent to 100% of\ntransmission system capacity could eliminate the incentive of rights holders to participate\nin ISO congestion protocols and weaken the ability of the ISO to oversee the reliable\noperation of the transmission resources under its jurisdiction. Several negative\nconsequences may ensue from a marginalization of the ISO’s role in congestion\nmanagement:\n        1. The transparency of transmission prices could be seriously reduced or\n             eliminated. The lack of a transparent and reliable price signal for transmission\n             congestion could undermine the ability of both producers and consumers to\n             effectively participate in a regional market. Without clear signals about the\n             costs of moving power throughout the California grid, decisions about where\n             to locate new generation or what transmission paths should be upgraded and\n             when become extremely difficult to make. Market participants will be forced\n             to make decisions that affect congestion costs without a clear idea of what\n             these costs are.\n        2. The movement of the majority of transmission market transactions to\n             secondary, and perhaps non-transparent markets may seriously impede the\n             ability of the ISO and other institutions to monitor market abuses in\n             transmission, energy, and ancillary service markets. More importantly, the\n             ISO would lose the ability to monitor FTRs holdings, and therefore find it\n             significantly more difficult to detect the exercise of market power that arises\n             from concentrated holdings of FTRs, until that market power has actually\n             been used.\n        3. The potential lack of price-transparency and concentration of scheduling\n             priorities may lead many non-rights holding consumers and producers to shift\n             their scheduling decisions from day-ahead markets to real-time markets.\n             Significant differences between day-ahead schedules and real time operations\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 138 of 148\n" [140] "            would place increased strain on the ISO’s ability to maintain reliability in the\n            real-time balancing of the system.\n        While it is not certain that all, or any, of these negative consequences may\nactually arise, there is sufficient concern to warrant a cautious approach to the issuance of\nFTRs in this market. The committee recommends an initial issuance of FTRs equal to no\nmore than 1/3 of the aggregate capacity of the associated transmission interfaces. These\nrights would have a duration of one year. If needed, to provide adequate incentive for the\nowners of existing transmission contracts (ETCs) to convert their rights and enter the ISO\nsystem, 100% of the capacity of these ETCs could be converted to FTRs upon entering\nthe ISO system, if this initial level of FTRs is not found to cause serious market power\nand system reliability problems. After this one year experiment, there should be a\nrigorous assessment of: (1) the performance of the market for evidence of market power,\n(2) the impact of the FTRs on congestion management, and (3) the need for additional\nFTRs or the need to continue with these experimental FTRs at all.\n        The MSC and its advisors see no significant economic benefit to California\nconsumers from giving scheduling priority to holders of financial transmission rights.\nHedging inter-regional price differentials due to transmission constraints can be\naccomplished by purely financial transmission rights with no scheduling authority, if all\nscheduling coordinators submit incs and decs in accordance with the ISO’s congestion\nmanagement protocols. If scheduling coordinators submit sufficient bids on all links,\ncongestion will be cleared and there will there no need to impose the default usage\ncharge, and use the scheduling priority. Consequently, given the significant potential\ncosts to the market and California consumers discussed above, a very cautious policy\ntowards FTRs seems prudent at this time.\n [141] "15.      Appendix B\n            Divestiture of PG&E Hydro Resources and Market Power Mitigation\n              Anjali Sheffrin, California ISO Department of Market Analysis\n                                       August 6, 1999\n                                         Summary\nThe legislature has requested that we analyze the market power risks of several\nalternatives to the plan to transfer the entire PG&E hydro portfolio to a non-regulated\nsubsidiary (the whole transfer). Since we do not know what the final divestiture design\nwill be, we reviewed four possible divestiture scenarios and evaluated the potential\nmarket power risk of each. Based on our preliminary analysis, we believe that potential\nrisks from alternative disposition of the PG&E hydro portfolio can be mitigated in each\nalternative. In each case, it will be necessary to have the flexibility to design measures\nto mitigate the specific risks that will emerge. It is important that legislation not attempt\nto prescribe one specific remedy in advance.\nIn analyzing the specific scenarios, we find there is an increased likelihood of market\npower if the divested hydro asset is owned by a market participant who also operates\nthermal or other generation resources in the California energy market. We expect there\nwill be less chance that a participant could exert market power if the hydro asset is\ndivested among many owners having no other generation resources. The key provisions\nof the principles proposed by PG&E and the ISO for mitigating market power for the\nwhole transfer (the “Principles”) can be applied to most of the divestiture scenarios.\nHowever, the specific percentage of minimum bid quantity requirement may need to be\nmodified for different conditions. In the event that the new hydro owners also operate\nother thermal resources in the California energy market, the bid requirement should be\nextended to the combined portfolio of the new owner to effectively mitigate the potential\nfor market power.\nIn designing market power mitigation, our overriding principle is to create correct\nincentives for market participants rather than relying on extensive and continuous\nmonitoring and imposing quantity and price restrictions. The need for monitoring\nbehavioral rules can become burdensome if there are numerous market participants\nsubject to these restrictions. In those cases structural remedies such as divestiture to a\nlarge number of suppliers, or contractual remedies, such as requiring the output of the\nfacility to be sold in advance so there is no profit from manipulating market prices, are\nworthy of consideration. In all cases, the ISO would require the flexibility to design the\nmost effective rules.\nBackground\nThe traditional sources of market power in any market are inelastic demand in the\nmarket (demand not responsive to price changes) and concentrated supply with limited\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 140 of 148\n" [142] "capacity. The ISO ancillary service markets face both of these problems. Ancillary\nservices purchase quantities are fixed amounts based on reliability criteria and cannot\nvary in response to prices. As a result, the ISO's demand for ancillary services is inelastic.\nThe available supply of ancillary services is also smaller than that for energy generation\ndue to the requirement that generation units be able to immediately respond to dispatch\ninstructions. The ancillary service capability is concentrated among few suppliers with\nPG&E hydro units being the dominant supplier in many hours of the ancillary service\nmarkets. These factors constitute the market power risk of hydroelectric generation\noperation.\nThere are three main options for market power mitigation in California energy market:\n•   Structural. Divesting hydro resources among a large number of suppliers.\n•     Contractual. Allowing contractual agreements, such as Contracts for Differences\n    (CFDs), under which an owner, in effect, sells output at a fixed price under a long-\n    term contract. Currently, CFDs cannot be used in California’s markets due to CPUC\n    restrictions on investor-owned utility loads entering into bilateral contracts.\n • Behavioral Rules. Rules on bid quantities and prices like those proposed in the\n     Principles developed by the ISO and PG&E.\nThe current ISO/PG&E Principles, proposed to apply to the transfer of PG&E’s\nhydroelectric portfolio to an unregulated subsidiary, are an example of behavioral rules\nand include the following key provisions:\n    •   Constraints on both price and quantity of bids in energy market and ancillary\n        service capacity market;\n    •   The new owner must to act as a “price taker” when it has market power to set\n        prices for ancillary services (A/S)\n    •   Minimum bid quantities and bid price caps for A/S markets are set so the owner\n        can earn an equal or greater profit than if its capacity was committed to energy\n        markets\n    •   When competitive market conditions exist, the owner is allowed to bid in all\n        markets\n    •   Bi-lateral sales are subject to restrictions to ensure that the subsidiary may not\n        inappropriately withhold the purchased capacity from the market or that PG&E\n        cannot transfer any “market power” to its subsidiary.\nThe exact requirements for any possible divestiture outcome must consider specific\nfactors such as:\n  • The total amount and type of generation resources owned by the entity.\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 141 of 148\n" [143] " • The amount and type of other generation resources available relative to demand in the\n      California energy and ancillary service markets.\n• The possibility that other means to mitigate market power mitigation, such as\n    Contracts for Differences and long term contracts may become available.\nScenario Analysis\nThere are a number of ways in which PG&E’s hydro generation could be divested.\nCompared to whole transfer option, there can be increased or reduced market power risk.\n− Base Line Scenario: A transfer of the entire hydro portfolio to one unregulated\n    company not operating any thermal generation units in the California energy market.\n    The proposed Principles are designed to mitigate market power under this scenario.\n    This is used as a basis to compare the market power of other scenarios.\n− Increased Market Power Scenario: The entire hydro portfolio or a majority of it is\n    transferred to a company who also operates thermal generation units in the California\n    energy market. In this scenario, increased market power mitigation is required. The\n    requirements of the Principles would have to be extended to the owner's entire\n    portfolio.\n− Medium Market Power Scenario: No new owner of the hydro facility owns more than\n    50% of the PG&E hydro capacity and any resulting combined hydro and thermal\n    capacity is less than the original PG&E hydro capacity (about 5000 MW), then the\n    new owner will have significant market power but less than in the Base line scenario.\n− Low Market Power Scenario: No new owner holds more than 20% of the PG&E\n    portfolio (about 1000 MW) and, either owns no other generation capacity or has\n    combined capacity of less than 20% of the total capacity in North of Path 15 zone.\n    Under this scenario the new hydro owner would have limited market power.\nWe can apply the behavioral rules of minimum quantity bid and bid price rules to market\npower mitigation in each of these scenarios. The general principles remain the same with\nspecific value for minimum bid quantity and maximum bid price adjusted to reflect the\nportfolio of the new owner. In the case when a new owner owns other generation in\naddition to the hydro capacity purchased from PG&E, a critical modification of the\nprinciples would be to base restrictions on the combined generation capacity of the new\nowner. The bid requirement, for example, would be calculated based on the combined\nportfolio and applied to both new hydro capacity and existing capacity.\nThe reason to apply the bid restriction to the combined capacity of the new owner is that\neven if the new owner were to be a price taker by bidding its entire new hydro capacity at\nzero price (which would be more than fulfilling the minimum requirement), it may still\nhave more market power with its other resources than before the purchase. It can be\ndemonstrated that a new owner who purchased 1000 MW of PG&E hydro and owns\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 142 of 148\n" The 1000 MW of\nhydro capacity, although bid at zero price, will receive the market clearing price inflated\nby its actions and earn a profit higher.\nWhen the new owner operates more than 5000 MW of generation in California, the\nminimum bid quantity requirement, both in terms of the absolute MW value or the\npercentage of its total capacity would need to be increased to effectively mitigate its\nmarket power. Due to the increased market power risk, this scenario should be avoided if\npossible.\nIt is very likely, however, that the current percentages in the Principles will be adequate\nfor the medium market power and low market power scenarios. Under the low market\npower scenario, the bidding restrictions outlined in the Principle can be used as a\nsafeguard, although they may be relaxed or eliminated when a new owners has\ndemonstrated [145] "                                      Methodology\n                         Options to Mitigate Market Power\nThere are three mains options for market power mitigation in California energy market:\n•   Structural. This includes divestiture of the hydro resource to a large number of\n    suppliers. One option is divestiture by watershed to a number of different owners.\n    The issue of whether each individual watershed is significantly small so that an entity\n    holding only that one set so resources would need to be addressed by a more detailed\n    study. In addition, for this option to provide an effective mitigation against market\n    power, entities purchasing hydro assets must not own significant other thermal\n    resources, so that transfer of ownership reduces or protects market power, rather than\n    creating or exacerbating market power.\n•   Contractual. This option includes contractual agreements, such as Contracts for\n    Differences (CFDs), under which an owner, in effect, sells output at a fixed price\n    under a long term contract. If the quantity of an owners portfolio that is effectively\n    “sold” under such long-term contracts is sufficiently large, this can removes an\n    incentive for the owner to exercise market power to raise market prices by\n    withholding capacity form the market (or bidding capacity at very high prices and\n    increasing revenues by selling less at a higher price). This contractual form of\n    mitigating market power is widely used in England, Australia, and is being proposed\n    in New York. CFDs are currently prevented from being applied in California’s\n    markets due to CPUC restrictions on investor-owned utility loads entering into\n    bilateral contracts.\n•   Behavioral Rules. These are restrictions on bid quantities and prices, such as have\n    been proposed in the Principles developed by the ISO and PG&E. These Principles\n    were developed as a set of market power mitigation measures that would be sufficient\n    to cover a scenario in which the entire PG&E’s hydro portfolio were sold to an\n    unregulated subsidiary. The bidding restrictions are designed to restrain the two\n    means to exercise market power: bidding excessive price and withholding capacity.\n    The generation owners can either bid significantly above cost or reduce its supply in\n    the market (with or without excessive bid price) and thus reduce total market supply\n    and push up market price. Bidding restriction must be set both as a quantity\n    requirement and bid-price cap. The proposed Principles for transfer of the PG&E\n    hydroelectric portfolio to a subsidiary is an example of behavioral rules used in\n    market power mitigation.\nThe appropriateness and details of using any of these approaches (individually or in\ncombination) must be addressed on a case by case basis, based on factors such as:\n  • The total amount and type of generation resources owned by the entity.\n  • The amount and type of other generation resources available relative to demand in the\n     California energy and ancillary service markets.\n                         MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 144 of 148\n" [147] "than 1000 MW of hydro. Other firms may fall in the low market power category if each\nbuys only one block of the PG&E hydro and does not own significant amount of other\ngeneration capacity. The increased market power scenario becomes possible if one\ncompany purchases the entire hydro capacity and also owns other generation capacity or\nacquires additional generation capacity in the future.\nMarket Power of Alternative Divestiture Scenarios for PG&E Hydro\nSystem Configuration\nBased on the system configuration and our two assumptions, there are, at most, 5 blocks\nof PG&E hydro system subject to sale or divestiture. (The misc. block can be further\ndivided, but considered as one block for market power analysis due to its small capacity).\nBased on these assumptions, we have attempted a crude classification of market power\nrisk based on FERC's rule that no one owner should control more than 20% market share.\nWe recommend further evaluations of the appropriate market power mitigation\nmeasures, and a more carefully look at the structural remedies and contract for\ndifferences methods for mitigating market power.\nAlternative Divestiture Scenarios Using the 5 Blocks\nScenario 1. PG&E retains greater than 50% share of hydro system.\nIf PG&E or its subsidiary retains the majority share of the current PG&E hydro system\n(50% or more), including Helms pump storage, then PG&E should be subject to some\nmonitoring and bid restrictions.\nThe Principles discussed by the ISO and PG&E can be modified to apply to PG&E in this\nscenario. The price cap should remain the same. The minimum quantity required for\nancillary services and forward energy market may need to be adjusted. There are two\nmain factors that affect these requirements: they would have lower market share which\nreduces market power, therefore it would be possible to reduce the minimum quantity\nrequirements; however the higher market power of other hydro owners (especially if the\nnew owners also own thermal resources) may require increased PG&E supply to curb\nothers’ market power. Additional study would be required to determine the appropriate\nquantity rules.\nAny buyer who purchases less than 1000 MW of hydro and does not own other\ngeneration capacity would be considered a low risk of having market power. They would\nnot be subject to any restriction initially and would be monitored. Restrictions may be\napplied if a significant market power problem is detected.\nAny buyer who purchases more than 1000 MW of hydro or owns other generation\ncapacity would be considered to pose a market power risk. See discussion in Scenario 4.\nScenario 2. Full divestiture to 5 non-thermal owners – The Helms owner will be the main\nmarket power concern. Others pose low market power concerns.\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 146 of 148\n" [148] "In this scenario, PG&E retains less than 50% of total hydro. The 5 blocks would be\ndivested to five different firms who do not already own thermal or other generation\nresources.\nIn this scenario, only the firm who owns Helms pump storage facility may be subject to\nrestrictions. Other new hydro owners should be considered as low risk for market power.\nThe restrictions on the owner of Helms would be different than those in the Principles.\nFirst, the new Helms owner has a moderate market share ( less than 35%). Second,\npumped storage has special characteristics. The current principles would be modified\nsignificantly for Helms.\nScenario 3. Full Divestiture to Small Thermal Owners – Market power concern slightly\nmore than scenario 2\nUnder the following conditions, this scenario will be similar to scenario 2:\n1. Helms does not go to a thermal owner;\n2. Other buyers each have less than 1000 MW new hydro capacity;\n3. Each new owner’s combined hydro and thermal capacity is less than 20% of total\n    NP15 ISO market generation capacity.\nIn this case, the Helms owner may be regulated as in scenario 2, and the other firms will\nbe considered low risk in market power and will need only to be monitored.\nScenario 4. Divestiture to Large Thermal Owners – higher market power risk, may be\nhigher market power than the base line case.\nThis scenario covers the following high market power risk conditions:\n1. Helms goes to a company who also operates thermal or other generation capacity in\n    ISO market; or\n2. Any new owner purchases more than 1000 MW of hydro; or\n3. Any new owner with thermal or other generation capacity and its total capacity\n    including the new hydro capacity in NP15 is more than 20% of the total capacity in\n    NP15.\nAny of these conditions can potentially result in significant market power. If a new\nowner’s combined capacity is more than the current PG&E hydro portfolio (about 5000\nMW), it may have market power greater than the base line whole transfer case. Due to\nthe serious market power concern, we recommend that no new owner of PG&E hydro\nshould operate a combined generation capacity of more than 5000 MW in California\nEnergy market.\nThese owners should be regulated by some measures. Possible options include:\n1. Bid Cap and Quantity requirement to both hydro and thermal units of the new owner.\n    When a large new owner operates both hydro and thermal, restriction on hydro alone\n                        MSC [149] "    may not be effective. Thermal units may be put under variable cost-based bidding\n    under certain market conditions, and will be required to bid more than certain\n    minimum quantities. When the new owner operates more than 5000 MW of\n    generation in California, the minimum bid quantity requirement, both in terms of the\n    absolute MW value or the percentage of its total capacity may be increased to\n    effectively mitigate its market power.\n2. Contracts for ancillary services such as Contracts for Differences. With properly\n    designed contracts, spot market prices do not change the contract holder’s revenue\n    and profit. The contract holder, therefore, has no incentive to inflate market prices.\nAdditional Study\nThis has been a cursory evaluation. We recommend further research to properly design\nthe restrictions. Areas that will require further study are the following:\n − When and how often will ancillary services be purchased separately for NP15 and\n     SP15?\n − What season and hours do these split purchases happen? What is the system load and\n     the ancillary services requirements under these conditions? What are the ancillary\n     services prices under these conditions?\nThis research will assist us in reaching a conclusion on how often we would expect to see\nmarket conditions that could be prone to market power problems.\n                        MSC Report, October 18, 1999, Page 148 of 148\n"
